Demonstrations of any kind were previously banned in the traditionally repressive nation, where authorities have cracked down hard on anti-government protests.

The rebel group, which has been warring with the Burmese government for four months, issued a statement saying they would cease hostilities but would defend themselves against government troops if necessary. The fighting has mostly occurred in Shan state along the border with China.

On 21 July 2015, Brigadier General Saw Kyaw Thet and Colonel Saw San Aung of the DKBA Benevolent were dismissed from the group after fighting between the DKBA Benevolent and BGF on the Asia Highway in July 2015. Both men would go on to engage in clashes with the BGF in October 2015 and, in January 2016, announced they had reactivated the old DKBA (for coding purposes now designated as DKBA Buddhist 2016). Maj. Na Ma Kyar is also part of this DKBA Buddhist 2016 group.
Security measures: The Parliament approved a 90-day extension of the State of Emergency and Martial Law in Kokang Self-Administered zone.

Looting: On 22 Sept 2015, in Kong Weng village in Maw Tong sub-township, Muse Township, Shan State, allegedly searching for Ta'ang National Liberation Army (TNLA) forces, the Burma Army Battalion No. 99 seized money from villagers.

ACTOR2: PNLO/PNLA: Pa-Oh National Liberation Organization/Pa-Oh National Liberation Army
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 21 September 2017, in Insein, Insein township, Yangon (North) district (Yangon Region), Yangon Regional Police arrested a person and seized one gun, a grenade, 7 bullets, and drugs at Air Port Inn hotel. The arrestee said he was the person in charge of security and transport for the PNLO but PNLO refuted the claim.
Around 09-October-2017, in Tin May, Buthidaung township, the village appeared to be burning. Unclear who was responsible for the burning.
Displacement: On 16 October 2017, in Maungdaw township, Maungdaw district (Rakhine State), thousands of Rohingyas fled Rakhine State to join the 536,000 Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh.
Weapons seizure: On 29-October-2017, in Maungdaw township, Rakhine state, forty hand-made mines were found underneath a bridge in Myo-U village.
Displacement: On 3 November 2017, in Paletwa township, Mindat district (Chin State), about 300 civilians were displaced due to clashes between Myanmar army and AA.
Arrests: On 07-November-2017, in Harbi village, near Maungdaw, Rakhine state, 38 men were detained for suspected involvement in the August 25 attack on police and military bases.

Displacement: On 7 November 2017, in Loi An village (coded as Kyaukme), Kyaukme township, Kyaukme district (Shan State), about 100 local people fled to Kyaukme town from fear of recruitment from TNLA. According to the villagers, fully armed TNLA troops entered the village on 1 November declaring that they would like to construct a new road. Villagers heard recruitment news from other villages and decided to flee. TNLA denied the recruitment news.

Looting: On 14 November 2017, in Buthidaung township (Maungdaw district, Rakhine state), the military forcibly took away money, mobile phones, and valuables such as gold from about 600 Rohingya villagers who were fleeing to Bangladesh using a path along May Yu mountain. The villagers were from Hpa Yon Chaung, Hpoe Khaung Chaung, Sein Hnyin Pyar, Say Oe Kya and Hpone Nyo Leik villages.

ACTOR2: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
NOTES: Defusal: On 17 November 2017, around Namhsan-Panglong road (coded as Namhsan), Namhsan township, Kyaukme district (Shan State), Myanmar army defused a handmade remote bomb allegedly planted by the TNLA. Myanmar army released a statement stating that Myanmar army arrested a TNLA soldier who planted the bomb.
Displacement: Around 18 Nov 2017, Paletwa Township, Chin state, around 1,300 villagers fled to India's Mizoram State due to on-going fighting between the Arakan Army and Myanmar army.
Agreement: On 23-November-2017, in Naypyidaw, Bangladesh and Myanmar signed a MOU on refugee repatriation for the Rohingya.

Defusal: On 28 November 2017, in Kyaukme town, Kyaukme township, Kyaukme district (Shan State), Myanmar army defused a handmade explosive which was found in Nanda Mala Park, opposite to the Myanmar army Artillery Operations Command compound.

ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
ACTOR2: SSPP/SSA-N: Shan State Progress Party/Shan State Army-North
NOTES: TNLA took over the Shan State Progressive Party/Shan State Army (SSPP/SSA) controlled Mong Yin village tract in Namtu Township, Shan state on Dec 1. No battle or fatalities reported.

Weapons seizure: On 4 December 2017, in Myawaddy town, Myawaddy township, Myawaddy district (Kayin State), Myanmar police found 1,000 12.7mm bullets at a house belonging to the owners of the house. Police stated that investigation is ongoing and it is clear if the ammunition were linked to the KIA. The 12.7mm bullets can be used to destroy unarmored vehicles, penetrate lightly armored vehicles and damage external ancillary equipment. The couple was arrested in Myitkyina.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Police
NOTES: Land seizure: On 5 December 2017, in Ah Lel Chaung village (Buthidaung township, Maungdaw district, Rakhine state), the Border Guard Police began building a camp on 350 acres of land which was previously farmed by the Rohingya, following a clearance operation in the area in August 2017.
Defusal: On 7 December 2017, at a bridge about 57 miles from Toke Chaung village, in Myebon township, Mrauk-U district (Rakhine State), authorities removed a couple of mines.
On 17-December-2017, HRW found that 354 Rohingya villages had been burned since August 2017 in Maungdaw, Buthidaung and Rathedaung townships.

Mass grave: On 19 December 2017, in Inn Din village, Maungdaw township, Maungdaw district (Rakhine State), local authorities found remains of 10 bodies near a graveyard. The investigation team stated that the remains were of victims of homicides that could have happened up to a year ago.

Property destruction: On 22 December 2017, in Salingyi township, Sagaing region, the protest camp of villagers protesting the Wanbao Company and the Letpadaung copper mine was set on fire by unknown men.
Property destruction: Myanmar army troops burnt down three civilian houses at Kaik Tai village in Namsan Township, northern Shan State on Jan 14.
Non-violent activity: Masen-Kawng-based Myanmar army troops fired several .5 calibre rifle rounds to provoke KIA frontline troops assumed in the Laiza area on Jan 16.
Non-violent activity: Masen-Kawng-based Myanmar army troops fired several .5 calibre rifle rounds to provoke KIA frontline troops assumed in the Laiza area on Jan 18.

In the second half of January 2018, in Tanai Township, Kachin State, over 3,500 civilians were displaced because of on-going fighting between KIA and the Myanmar military near amber mining villages in the 'Pat Maw' area. The internally displaced became trapped for 18 days without food or supplies. Aid was denied by the military. The civilians were released in groups over several days until 9 Feb 2018.
Property destruction: Myanmar army troops set fire to several civilian buildings at Nam Gawn Zup in Awng Ja village in Tanai Township on Jan 28.
Property destruction: Myanmar army troops based at Lawt Mai Yang set fire to gold mining equipment and backhoes in Sumprabum township (Kachin state) on Jan 29.

Weapons seizure: On 4 February 2018, in Dagon, Dagon township, Yangon (West) district (Yangon Region), Yangon Regional Security and Border Affairs minister confirmed that 116 bullets in a plastic bag were found in Minedar field. The field was used on the same day as a protest ground for support of the Myanmar army, organized by supporters of Myanmar army.
Property destruction: Myanmar army troops burnt down a civilian house in Pung Ling Dingsa village in Mansi township on Feb 11.
Non-violent activity: Myanmar army troops based at Bum Re Bum fired multiple rounds of .5 caliber machine gun into a forest area on February 12.
Property destruction: Myanmar army troops burnt down two IDPs' houses in Pung Ling Dingsa village, Mansi township on February 13.

ACTOR2: UWSP/UWSA: United Wa State Party/United Wa State Army
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 05-March-2018, in Mong Toom village [near Tachileik], Shan state, the UWSA stopped the Myanmar army from working on a new road in contested territory. No fighting took place.
Non-violent activity: On 14-March-2018, near Sama [near Gara-Yang], Kachin state, the Myanmar army positioned in the KIAs 253rd mobile battalion area, fired machine gun rounds.
Property destruction: On 21-March-2018, near Hka Ya Bum and Hpun Dabang hills, Waingmaw township, Myitkyina district, Kachin state, Myanmar army soldiers set fire to abandoned farms.
Non-violent activity: On 25-March-2018, near Jan Pru Hkran village [geocode for Tanai, Myitkyina, Kachin], Kachin state, the Myanmar army fired off 10 rounds of small arms fire.
Non-violent activity: On 26-March-2018, at Hka Da Zup, Tanai township, Myitkyina district, Kachin state, the Myanmar army opened fire on the surrounding area.

NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 29-March-2018, at Nam Ya Hill, Hpakant township, Mohnyin district, Kachin state, local PMF fired small arms towards Nam Ya farms.

In April 2018, in Tanai Township, Kachin State, 2,000 individuals from Sut Yang, Sut Ya and Awng Lat villages were displaced and trapped in the forest for four weeks due to fighting between the Myanmar military and KIO/KIA. They had no access to assistance and clean water. Two children died.

On 16 April 2018, Hpakant Township, Kachin State, Myanmar army soldiers looted livestock and belongings in either Man We or Hlaing Naung Hku village, after they had forced displaced villagers to return to their village.

Security measures: On 20-May-2018, near Maungdaw, Rakhine state, the Myanmar army ordered Rohingya Muslims living in no-mans land between Myanmar and Bangladesh to leave. Around 6,000 people are living on the strip of land.
Movement of forces: Since early July, the Myanmar military's 33rd LID has been reinforced as they carry out searches for RCSS/SSA-S troops in Mong Kung (Mongkaing) township.
Movement of forces: Since early July, the Myanmar military's 33rd LID has been reinforced as they carry out searches for RCSS/SSA-S troops in Kyethi township.

Movement of forces: On 04-July-2018, 10 Myanmar military trucks were seen heading towards Waignmaw township, Kachin state (where KIA headquarters is located) prior to the start of the third 21st Century Panglong Union Peace Conference.
Looting: Around 06-July-2018, in Ye township, Mon state, an unidentified armed group has been extorting money from local plantation owners.

Property destruction: On 09 July 2018, near Thin Baw Gwe (Thin Baw Kwe) village, Maungdaw township, Rakhine state, police began to tear down around 48 Rakhine dwellings that had been built on the site of a razed Rohingya village.
Movement of forces: Around 09-July-2018, near Chipwi township, Kachin state, the Myanmar military sent reinforcements to KIA 10th battalion areas.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Police
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: PDP: Peace and Diversity Party; Rakhine Ethnic Group (Myanmar); Burman Ethnic Group (Myanmar)
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 9 July 2018, in Thin Baw Kwe village, Maungdaw township, Maungdaw district (Rakhine State), border guard police found a grenade and several swords in the home of an ethnic Arakanese-Bamar (Rakhine-Burman) man with apparent ultranationalist sympathies. It was reported that the man served as a central executive committee member an the anti-Muslim political party Peace and Diversity Party. The couple was charged by the local court.

On 11-July-2018, in Nay Pyi Taw, the third round of the 21s Century Panglong Union Peace Conference began.

Around 12 July 2018, in Hsipaw and Mong Kung (Mongkaing) townships, Shan state, the Myanmar military and the SSA-S and SSA-N were reinforcing their troops. The Myanmar military has deployed battalions from the North Eastern and Eastern Central Command as well as battalions from the 33rd LID to the two townships.

Around 12 July 2018, in Hsipaw and Mong Kung townships, Shan state, the Myanmar military and the SSA-S and SSA-N were reinforcing their troops. ACTOR1: UWSP/UWSA: United Wa State Party/United Wa State Army
SOURCE: Irrawaddy; Shan Herald Agency for News
NOTES: Recruitment: Around 15 July 2018 (month of), since this month, in several townships of Shan State (Hopang, Mongmao, Panwai, Namphan, Metman, Pangsang, Mongton, Monghpyak, Longtan and Hothauk), the United Wa State Army (UWSA) has summoned youth, both male and female, to participate in a military parade next year marking the 30th anniversary of the signing of a truce with the Myanmar military. Some youth have fled fearing they will be made to serve in the UWSA. Event geocoded for Pangsang (Wa SAD).
Property destruction: On 21 July 2018, in Tanai township, Kachin state, the Myanmar army destroyed cell phone stations used by gold miners at the Tum Mari and One Pala gold mines.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Shan Herald Agency for News
NOTES: Displacement: As of 05-August-2018, in Namtu township, Shan state, close to 1,000 villagers had fled recent fighting between armed groups in the area.
Land seizure: On 12 August 2018, in Tha Yet Oke village in Maungdaw township (Maungdaw district, Rakhine state), the local government authorities confiscated Rohingya land.

Displacement: As reported on August 15, 2018, since July 2018, more than 1,000 ethnic Shan and Palaung have fled their villages since the fighting between the SSA-South and the allied forces of SSA-North and TNLA began in Namtu Township, Shan State.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Police
NOTES: Security measures: As reported on August 17, 2018, the Myanmar army and the border police have been conducting joint patrols in Maungdaw district, Rakhine state as the one year anniversary of the ARSA attacks and subsequent military crackdown on the Rohingya population nears.

Security Measures: Before 23 Aug 2018, in anticipation of the first anniversary of the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army (ARSA)'s attacks on 30 police outposts on August 25, 2018 (and the subsequent crackdown on the Rohingya population), the police have set up 160 police outposts along the Maungdaw border and deployed nearly 1,000 policemen.

Looting: On 26 Aug 2016, in Lung Tung Loi Mun village, Hpakant Township, Kachin State, a local militia unit backed by the Myanmar army seized cows and buffaloes and asked the villagers to pay a ransom money for each animal.
Security measures: Throughout late August, the Myanmar army carried out surveillance and inspections in Mongton Township, Shan State in order to monitor the movements of the SSA-S.

Security measures: Throughout late August, the Myanmar army conducted inspections of vehicles, buses and travellers on the Mongton-Pongpakyin Road, Monghsat Township, Shan State in order to monitor movements of the SSA-S.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army

This movement of forces follows the build up of Myanmar army troops in Kamamaung town, Hpapun township in late August and early September.

ACTOR1: UWSP/UWSA: United Wa State Party/United Wa State Army
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 13 Sept 2018, near Pangsang, Wa SAD, Shan State, the United Wa State Army (UWSA) began demolishing unauthorized Christian churches.

ACTOR1: ABSDF: All Burma Students' Democratic Front
ACTOR2: ABSDF: All Burma Students' Democratic Front

ACTOR1: UWSP/UWSA: United Wa State Party/United Wa State Army
NOTES: Around 20 Sept 2018, near Pangsang, Wa SAD, Shan State, the UWSA forcibly recruited 41 bible class students from various churches for military service.

ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
NOTES: Looting: On 29 Sept 2018, at Shu Hkin Ta, Man Ping and Loi Sam Sip villages, Shan State, the TNLA collected taxes on vehicles travelling between Lashio and Muse.

Security measures: On 30 Sept, in Tanai Township, Kachin State, soldiers of the Myanmar army's 86th LIB and 238th LIB stopped locals who were travelling from Tanai to Awng Lawt village and asked them to return to Tanai.
Weapons seizure: On 1 Oct 2018, in Hlegu Township, Yangon, the Myanmar police seized 9,500 bullets which were being shipped by bus to Muse Township, Shan State.

Security measures: On 2 Oct 2018, in Nam Aum (Nam Oum), Muse Township, Shan State, the Myanmar military carried out unexpected checks of villagers by comparing resident and family lists. The previous week there had been clashes between the TNLA and Myanmar army in that village. Villagers believe the Myanmar military carried out the checks to see if any members of ethnic armed organizations were still in the village.

Security measures: Around 16 Oct 2018, Myitkyina Township, Kachin State, the Myitkyina District Election Commission restricted campaigns for the by-election in Sinbo, Ho Kat, and Ti Yang Zup villages due to security concerns.
Movement of forces: Around 19-October-2018, near Sin Phyu, Muse township, Shan state, Chinese soldiers blocked the construction of a market office near the border.

Displacement: On 25 Oct 2018, Namtu Township, Shan State, about 750 villagers from Mong Yin fled their homes and sought shelter in Namtu Town, due to fighting between the SSA-S and a combined force of SSA-N and TNLA.

Displacement: On 27 Oct 2018, Lashio Township, Shan state, clashes between the SSA-S and a joint force of the TNLA and SSA-N displaced around 650 villagers from Pan Pone, Kalar, Nang Har and Ei-Naing villages.

Displacement: On 2-3 Nov 2018, Hsipaw Township, Shan State, battles between the SSA-S and the Northern Alliance members displaced around 1,052 villagers from Wan Ho Ner, Wan Nai Lon, Wan Tong Keng, Tar Lon, Khai Heio village in Ner Makhaw village-tract and Wan Hung village.
Displacement: Around 15-November-2018, in Paletwa township, Chin state, around 1,300 people were displaced due to fighting between the Myanmar military and AA.

Defusal: On 16 November 2018, at least three bombs were found and defused by police in front of the Central Market in Taunggyi city (Taunggyi, Shan) where the annual fire balloon festival was being held. It is unclear who was responsible for placing the bombs.

Arrests: On 16 November 2018, 106 Rohingya Muslims from a camp in Sittwe on an overcrowded boat heading for Malaysia were detained near Thante village in Kyauktan township in Yangon region by local authorities. They had been at sea for 20 days during which one woman died.

Defusal: On 23 November 2018, in Insein market, Insein township, Yangon (North) district (Yangon Region), a handmade bomb was found. The authorities disposed the bomb. The same type of bomb was found again on 28 November.
On 25 Nov 2018, Launglon township, Dawei District, Tanintharyi Region, the Myanmar Navy detained 93 Rohingya refugees, among them 32 children, on a boat off the coast of Dawei heading to Malaysia.

Defusal: On 26 November 2018, in Chipwi IDP camp, Chipwi township, Myitkyina district (Kachin State), an artillery shell landed near in the IDP camp No.1. The artillery did not explode yet. The authorities came to check and fixed it so that it would not explode but it was not removed.

Defusal: On 28 November 2018, in Insein, Insein township, Yangon (North) district (Yangon Region), a handmade bomb was found in the market. Locals disposed the bomb themselves. The same type of bomb was found on 23 November in the market again.

On 21 December 2018, in Nay Pyi Taw, the office of the Commander-in-Chief Office announced a unilateral four months ceasefire from 21 Dec 2018 to 30 Apr 2019. The military promised to stop its military operations in five command regions (North, Northeast, East, Mideast and Triangle region) . The ceasefire announcement leaves out the military operations in Rakhine and Chin states where fighting between the AA and Myanmar military has been ongoing in the past couple of months.

Security measures: Around 5 January 2019, despite the ceasefire announcement by the Myanmar military covering Kachin and northern Shan state, the military has been accused of recently expanding and establishing new army camps in six areas (Namhsan, Manton, Namtu, Kyaukme, Kutkai and Namhkan) where the Ta'ang National Liberation Army is active. The military has denied this accusation.

On 07-January-2019, in Daw Pu village, Demoso township, Kayah state, the Myanmar army's Light Infantry Battalion No. 54 completed the building of a new base.
On 07-January-2019, between Daw Wiraw and Thiri Dah villages, Shadaw township, the Myanmar army's Battalion No. 429 completed the construction of a new base.
On 07-January-2019, in Nat Ye Thweh Pauk (Bo Than Win Gone), Hpasawng township, Kayah state, the Myanmar army's Battalion No. 428 completed the construction of a new base.

On 07-January-2019, in Nam Mahn Kee, Mese township, Kayah state, the Myanmar army's battalion No. 337 completed the construction of a new base.

Displacement: Around 09-January-2019, in Mai Pan (Mongpan) township, Shan state, over 1500 Pa-Oh villagers fled several villages fearing the possibility of fighting between the SSA-S and PNLA. Many have sought shelter in Wa controlled areas.

Agreement: On 19 January 2019, in Myawaddy Township, in Karen State, 11 members led by a captain from KKO: Klohtoobaw Karen Organization (splinter group) [DKBA Buddhist (2016-)] surrendered to the Myanmar military.

ACTOR2: NSCN-K: National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang
NOTES: On 29 January 2019, in the Naga-Self Administered Zone, in the village of Ta Ga in Nanyun Township in Sagaing Region, the Myanmar military with more than 400 troops under North-West Command took over the headquarters of the National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang (NSCN-K). NSCN-K's central executive committee member confirmed that it withdrew its troops not to disrupt the peace process with the government. Thus, no battle was involved during the occupation of its HQ by the military.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Police
NOTES: On 29 January 2019, in Ohn Chaung Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, about 100 military soldiers and Border Guard Police set up camp in the village and forced villagers to house them.

On 3 February 2019, in Ywa Ma Ward, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, the police arrested 24 people who fled to Kyauktaw township and two locals who sheltered them in their houses and charged them under the Unlawful Association Act.

Movement of forces: On 3 February 2019, in Matupi Township, in Chin State, the Myanmar military deployed over 100 military convoys and 2 helicopters to the area. Chin political parties expressed their concern over this military advancement as this can escalate the armed conflicts in the area.

Security measures: On 5 February 2019, in Pan Hpe Chaung Village, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, about 40 military soldiers and the police raided a house where a woman was alone at home while her husband was away. Soldiers and police have been searching homes in the region for AA supporters.

Movement of forces: As reported 7 February 2019, in Mong Pawk Township, in Shan State, the Myanmar military has been expanding its military at the Salween river dock area since its unilateral ceasefire declaration in December last year.

Movement of forces: As reported 7 February 2019, in Loilem-Panglong area, in Shan State, the Myanmar military has been expanding its military in Sa Ning mountain range since its unilateral ceasefire declaration in December last year.

Movement of forces: As reported 7 February 2019, in in Mongping Township, in Shan State, the Myanmar military has been expanding its military since its unilateral ceasefire declaration in December last year.

Movement of forces: As reported 7 February 2019, the TNLA said that the Myanmar military Light Infantry Divisions 11, 66, 88 and 99 had established up to 12 new military camps in five northern Shan State townships (location coded at Namtu).

Movement of forces: As reported 7 February 2019, in Loi Pangpi, in Mongpan Township, in Shan State, the Myanmar military has been expanding its military since its unilateral ceasefire declaration in December last year.

ACTOR2: RCSS/SSA-S: Restoration Council of Shan State/Shan State Army-South
NOTES: On 12 February 2019, in between Mongyin and Kengtung Townships, in Shan State, the Restoration Council of Shan State (RCSS) seized Myanmar military weapons from a vehicle carrying two military commanding officers. Later, however, the seized weapons were returned to the Myanmar military by RCSS.

Arrests: On 16 February 2019, in Sittwe, in Rakhine State, about 300 monks who had sat for Buddhist Dhamma exam in Lawka Nandar Jedi compound of Thadana Baikman from 7 to 10 February were detained and questioned by officials on the suspicion of having links with anti-government forces in Rakhine.

ACTOR2: NSCN-K: National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang
NOTES: During the Myanmar's military operation from 8 to 19 February 2019, near Taga Village, Nanyun township, Sagaing region (in Naga Self-Administered Zone), the Myanmar military announced that they captured the NSCN(K) camp and seized weapons and ammunitions. They also detained four NSCN (K) members.

Defusal: On 23 February 2019, in Demawso Township, in Kayah State, two motorcyclists threw two hand grenades in front of the police checkpoint but the military engineers later safely exploded the grenades.

On 25 February 2019, in Puta-O Township, in Kachin State, a convoy of military trucks headed for Puta-O town from Myitkyina. The move of the convoy was immediately after peace talks with the Northern Alliance. It was reported by witnesses that there were nearly 100 trucks carrying weapons and food.

On 3 March 2019, in Mrauk-U Township, in Rakhine State, the movement of Myanmar military troops caused fear and concern among villagers. About 500 locals of upper Lay Nyin Taung village fled to nearby villages and took refuge.

On 15-March-2019, in Ponnangyun township, Rakhine state, the Myanmar military looted rice sacks from houses in Buddhaw village. The looting by the military continued for many days. The soldiers who looted the village were from the LID 22 and 55.
On 19 March 2019, near Myebon township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military arrested and interrogated 100 villagers of Pan Myaung village. The villagers were then released.

From 22 to 24 March, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military columns conducted security operations near Kan Sauk village at DT-877 841 where the Arakan Army was positioned to block and destroy the Kyauktaw-Sittwe communication route of the military. AA troops withdrew from its position due to these clearance operations by the military.

ACTOR2: NSCN-K: National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang
NOTES: On 26 March 2019, in Hkamti Township, in Chin State, the township police arrested 5 members of NSCN-K including chairman and vice-chairman of peace implementation committee under the Unlawful Association Act 17(1). The military spokesperson told that they were charged due to their military cooperation with Assam, a resistance group to the Indian government.

On 11 April 2019, in Mrauk-U Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military arrested 27 people, according to the village administrator in Lekka village. The arrests occurred after a battle between the military and the AA. The military's announcement said it detained 23 suspected people in connection with AA.

On 21 April 2019, in Matupi Township, in Chin State, about 1,000 soldiers of Myanmar military brigade no.77 arrived at the township. Then 40 military vehicles headed to Paletwa township the next day. Some vehicles left for Yay Zwa and Linelanpi.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 26 April 2019, in Kyaukpyu Township, in Rakhine State, a handmade landmine was detected by Myanmar military security members inside the ward administrator's office in Kyaukpyu.

SOURCE: Eleven Media Group; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Land seizure: On 30 April 2019, near War Net village (Pyin Oo Lwin Township, Pyin Oo Lwin District, Mandalay Region), farmers accused Myanmar military No. 121 Supply and Transport Force of seizing land. Farmers from Shwe Sar Yan village Patheingyi Township and Kywe Na Hpa village from Pyin Oo Lwin Township reportedly harassed the Myanmar military when they were fencing seized lands. 12 farmers were charged under penal code 331, 114, 295, 186 and 427.

On 30 April 2019, in Muse Township, in Northern Shan State, the Myanmar military extended its ceasefire for two months until June 30. The extended ceasefire covers five regional commands in Kachin and Shan states whereas the Rakhine State remain excluded from the coverage. The decision on the extension was made after the request from three forces: KIA, TNLA and MNDAA.

On 30 April 2019, in Kyauk Tan Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military rounded up hundreds of villagers for interrogation. They held 275 to interrogate after they release women, children and elderly. This happened after the military captured the temporary training camp of AA in Buthidaung township.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 1 May 2019, in Tha Dein Village, near the area of Three-Pagoda Pass(Payathonzu), in Kyarinseikgyi Township, in Karen State, the roads that lead to the Tha Dein village where the troops of Mon National Liberation Army (MNLA) are based were blocked by the Karen National Liberation Army (KNLA). KNLA also deployed more troops into the area readying itself to attack on the MNLA's base. This heightened the tension between the two armed groups.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
ACTOR2: NMSP/MNLA: New Mon State Party/Mon National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 3 May 2019, near Chaungzone village, in Payathonzu Town, in Karen State, the Karen National Union and the New Mon State Party reached the agreement during the meeting held at the Democratic Karen Benevolent Army (DKBA) Magatar Chaungzone Yetakon base that road construction and timber production will be stopped in the area of dispute, troops withdrawn from the area and liaison offices informed before patrolling the area.

ACTOR1: RCSS/SSA-S: Restoration Council of Shan State/Shan State Army-South
ACTOR2: SSPP/SSA-N: Shan State Progress Party/Shan State Army-North
NOTES: On 11 May 2019, in Shan State, the Shan State Progressive Party and Restortion Council of Shan State issued the joint statement that they decided to stop fighting at the request of different civil society groups in Shan State. Though the period of the ceasefire is not determined, the two sides will engage in negotiations regarding troop deployment. No location noted; location coded at Hsipaw, site of the majority of the recent fighting between the groups.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) People's Militia Force
NOTES: Around 15 May 2019, in Tanai Township, in Kachin State, a new local militia camp was built nearby San Pya village and Lawt Ja IDP camp. The militia camp belongs to the Shanni People's Militia Force (PMF) backed my the military. Forces that belong to Kachin Independence Army were also deployed nearby the village.
On 16 May 2019, in Ponnagyun Township, in Rakhine State, a Myanmar military troop took up positions at the school in Pauk Taw Pyin village.

On 16 May 2019, near Hoyat and Laonyu Villages, along India-Myanmar border, Myanmar military conducted a clearance operation against the National Socialist Council of Nagaland-Khaplang (NSCN-K). Location coded at Nanyun township, Sagaing region.

On 22 May 2019, in Maungdaw Township, in Rakhine State, the township authorities prohibited the displaced Rohingya from settling back in their original village of Bakaguana in Bakargonenah village tract.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 3 June 2019, in Paletwa Township, in Chin State, the Arakan Army detained two vessels operating along Kaladan River and looted 150 rice bags from the vessels. It also blocked the use of the river route near Kyi Lay village located 10 miles away from Paletwa until the morning of June 4.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Police
NOTES: Around 5 June 2019, in Maungdaw Township, in Rakhine State, a bomb accidentally exploded and killed a policeman while injuring three others near the Taung Pyo Let Ya bridge. The Border Guard Force No (1) was travelling to Maungdaw accompanied by a police constable carrying three bombs. One of the bomb was accidentally detonated.

SOURCE: VOA; Narinjara News; Eleven Media Group
NOTES: On 13 June 2019, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military arrested 25 Mro ethnic village youths on suspicion of having links with the Arakan Army after clashes broke out between the Myanmar military and the Arakan Army near Kyauk Shi Pyin village. The military has been interrogating those arrested in Kyauktaw township.
On 18 June 2019, in Minbya Township, in Rakhine State, about 200 soldiers of Myanmar military took position outside of Shwegyin village.

SOURCE: AFP; Radio Free Asia; Development Media Group; Narinjara News
NOTES: The Myanmar government has banned internet access in eight townships of Rakhine and one township in Chin since 21 June. Service was restored in 5 townships on August 31. The ban on four townships (Kyauktaw, Mrauk-U, Minbya and Ponnagyun) was still in effect as of 21st December. 20 CSOs released a statement on December 21 to condemn the internet ban. The ban was reimposed in Buthidaung, Maungdaw, Rathedaung and Myebon townships in Rakhine State and Paletwa Township in Chin State by the order from Ministry of Transport and Communication on February 3, 2020.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Force
NOTES: On 23 June 2019, in Hlaingbwe Township, in Kayin State, the DKBA (splinter) group reached an agreement with the Myanmar military leading 45 soldiers of the DKBA to surrender their arms at BGF brigade no.1011 which is based in Pantaw Myi village. A spokesperson of BGF announced that the splinter group will combine with the Kayin State's BGF.

On 29 June 2019, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops entered the Laing Gwun village and consequently about 3,000 villagers of Laing Gwun and Lamone Taing villages fled to nearby villages. After the military soldiers left the village of Lai Gwun, villagers claimed that they heard the gunfire of small and heavy weapons, but it was not clear whether there was any fighting.

On 30 June 2019, in Minbya Township, in Rakhine State, 100 Myanmar military soldiers entered Minbuu village and took position at the entrance of the village. They were also patrolling in the village streets. Fighting between the Myanmar military and the Arakan Army (AA) had been taking place in a location between Shwe Kyin and Tharsi villages.

On 30 June 2019, in Nay Pyi Taw, Myanmar military has unilaterally extended the ceasefire in its five military command regions: Northern Command, North Eastern Command, Eastern Central Command, and Triangle Region Command. The ceasefire was extended until 31st August 2019. The military announced that the reason for the extension has an aim to engage in constructive peace talks with non-signatory ethnic armed organizations (EAOs).
On 2 July 2019, in Buthidaung Township, in Rakhine State, about 40 villagers from Kan Pyin village were detained by the Myanmar military and interrogated.

ACTOR2: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: Around 3 July 2019, in Sittwe Town, in Rakhine State, the top five leaders of the Arakan Army (AA) including the Commander-in-Chief Major General were charged under the Counter-Terrorism Law by the District court (all five are considered fugitives). Seven other villagers arrested by the military on March 12 have also been charged under the Counter-Terrorism Law.

SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Narinjara News; Development Media Group
NOTES: On 5 July 2019, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, after a battle between the Myanmar military and the Arakan Army (AA) took place in a mountain range near A Myet Taung village, 200 military soldiers under Brigade no.22 entered into the village and set the houses on fire. About 10 houses were incinerated. The military troops then marched towards Yay So Chaung village.

On 5 July 2019, in Buthidaung Township, in Rakhine State, after a battle between the Myanmar military and the Arakan Army (AA) took place near Myaw stream in back of the Thayet Pyin village, 50 military soldiers crossed the stream and entered into Alei Chaung village. Then, about 25 soldiers set the village on fire, and about 40 houses were incinerated. The village is inhabited by people from the Khami ethnic group.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Police
NOTES: On 7 July 2019, in Maungdaw Township, in Rakhine State, the Border Guard Police detained 60 Muslims in a boat near Myin Hlut Jetty in the township. Those detained had paid 1,700,000 MMK to the boatmen who promised to send them to Malaysian waters.

On 11 July 2019, in Mingaladon Township, in Yangon Region, two leaders of the Arakanese Association of Singapore (AAS) were arrested at the Yangon International Airport after they were deported by the Singapore government. They were then transferred to the special intelligence police force in Nay Pyi Daw on 13 July. They were deported by the Singapore government for allegedly organizing and gathering support for the Arakan Army's armed conflict with the Myanmar military. One of the those arrested is the brother of the Major General of AA and another is the chairperson of AAS.
On 20 July 2019, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, about 70 Myanmar military soldiers arrived at the villages of Pauktu Taung and Yay Gaung Chain for clearance operations.
On 21 July 2019, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military soldiers test-fired artillery shells at night in Pauktu Taung village which led 1,500 villagers to flee to Kantaunggyi town.

On 23 July 2019, in Kyaukme Township, in northern Shan State, 22 village tract leaders submitted their resignation letters after their village leader was arrested and detained by the Myanmar military. The village leader was charged under the unlawful association act accusing him of collecting taxes for the Restoration Council of Shan State (RCSS) and Shan State Progress Party (SSPP).

On 24 July 2019, in Thingangyun Township, in Yangon Region, an unexploded grenade was found by a municipal cleaner in front of the National League for Democracy (NLD) office near Malikha housing in Bawamyint ward.

ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: MNTJP/MNDAA: Myanmar National Truth and Justice Party/Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army
NOTES: On 2 August 2019, in Kutkai Township, in Shan State, troops from the joint forces of the Ta'ang National Liberation Army and Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army arrived at Tarmoenye town.

ACTOR2: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 3 August 2019, near Chay Yar Taw village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military captured the training camp of the Arakan Army. Camp assumed to have been abandoned.

On 9 August 2019, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine Region, 100 Myanmar military soldiers from LIB No.274 arrived at the village of Oak Pho and looted the shops and houses of the villagers. They then destroyed the shops.

On 12 August 2019, in Maha Bandula Park, Kyauktada township, Yangon city (Yangon-West), the security forces (assumed to be police) arrested three Karen ethnic people, including the chairman of the Karen Women Organization for using the term 'Karen's Martyrs Day.'

On 21 August 2019, in Namtu Township, in northern Shan State, handmade landmines which were set to detonate were removed by the Myanmar military. The landmines were set under the Nantsiwaw Bali bridge on Lashio-Namtu road.

ACTOR1: MNTJP/MNDAA: Myanmar National Truth and Justice Party/Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army
NOTES: Around 22 August 2019, near Muse Township, in Shan State, the Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army is stationed. Residents claimed that the troops fired warning shots if people trespassed the area.

On 29 August 2019, in Ponnagyun Township, in Rakhine State, three trucks were burned and destroyed near Yoe Ta Yoke village on Yangon-Sittwe road. AA claimed that the military set the trucks on fire when AA found out that military was transporting weapons in civilian's trucks. The military, however, claimed that AA set the trucks on fire to threaten the public.

On 29 August 2019, in Lashio Township, in northern Shan State, the Brotherhood Alliance (TNLA, AA, MNDAA) burned a vehicle near Byone Mountain between Nantphetka and Muse along the Lashio-Muse Union highway. A 12-wheeled vehicle among five trucks being stopped was burned down and other trucks were also destroyed.
On 30 August 2019, in between Lashio and Hseni Townships, in northern Shan State, three civilian cars and one motorbike was burned and destroyed by the Brotherhood Alliance (TNLA, MNDAA, AA).

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Development Media Group
NOTES: Around 31 August 2019, in Nay Pyi Taw, Myanmar military extended its unilateral ceasefire in Northern Command, North-eastern Command, Eastern Command, Eastern Central Command and the Triangle Region Command from 31 August to 21 September.

On 3 September 2019, in Kutkai Township, in northern Shan State, about 20 men from an armed group stopped seven vehicles in front of a local clinic near Nant Kut village on the Kutkai-Muse highway and set the vehicles on fire. The armed men also looted phones and cash from the passengers.

On 9 September 2019, the Brotherhood Alliance (TNLA, AA, MNDAA) announced a unilateral one-month ceasefire from 9 September to 8 October. However, the alliance declared that they will defend themselves from the offensives by the Myanmar military. Event coded at Lashio, Shan state.

On 9 September 2019, the curfew in Laukkaing and Konkyan townships in the Kokang SAZ which has been in effect since 2015 was extended again on 9 September. The curfew by the government states that no one is allowed to go outside of their homes from 9 pm to 5 am. Event coded at Laukkaing, Shan state.

SOURCE: Irrawaddy; Myanmar Now; Eleven Media Group
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 10 September 2019, in Chanmyathazi Township, in Mandalay Region, the police arrested six men with explosives, detonators, and gunpowder. The arrested men were suspected of being AA members. They were given prison sentence from 8 to 13 years on July 16 2021.

On 16 September 2019, [Location coded at Nay Pyi Taw], the president's office director-general issued a classified security warning that some ethnic armed organizations could attack Nay Pyi Taw, Yangon and Mandalay. The ministry of Home Affairs also reported that KNU, CNF, AA and KIA have plans to attack in Nay Pyi Taw on September 16 or on October 16 or 26. These groups denied such plans. However, several foreign embassies subsequently released travel warnings based on this information.
On 19 September 2019, in Minbya Township in Rakhine State, a column of Myanmar military soldiers arrived at Myin Ka (Kan) Seik village and were stationed in the village for two days.

On 20 September 2019, [Location coded at Lashio Township], in northern Shan State, the Brotherhood Alliance (TNLA, AA, MNDAA) extended its unilateral ceasefire period to the end of the year. They announced they are ready for a joint ceasefire with the military. However, they also declared that they will defend themselves from the military's offensive operations, shelling, and airstrikes. They announced again on January 1 that it had extended its unilateral ceasefire from 1 January until 29 February 2020. However, they noted they will defend themselves against military offensives.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of Myanmar (2016-); Police Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021)
NOTES: On 26 September 2019, in Myitkyina Township, in Kachin State, more than 20 personnel from Military Affairs security, the police and township general administration department raided a Kachin Christian Bible school in Lawu Maw Hpawng village.

On 27 September 2019, in Ngapudaw Township, in Ayeyarwady Region, the Myanmar police arrested 30 Rohingya Muslims from Rakhine state, who did not have verification documents, on a vehicle at the entrance of the Nga Yoke Kaung sub-township.
On 4 October 2019, in Buthidaung Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military troops from battalion No.22 set some houses in Kun Taung village on fire. About 10 houses were destroyed by the fire.

On 6 October 2019, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar police website reported that 7 members of an unknown armed group who speak Rakhine language opened fired into the air and entered Sin Khone Tai, a Muslim populated village. They then destroyed the houses and looted the properties.

On 7 October 2019, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, some houses and grocery stores owned by civilians in Htee Swe village were robbed by Myanmar military soldiers. These houses were abandoned by the Htee Swe villagers clashes broke out between the military and the Arakan Army.
Around 7 October 2019, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, a column of Myanmar military soldiers arrived at Htee Swe village located near Kyauktan village causing villagers to flee.

Around 9 October 2019 (from 9 October - 18 October), in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, more than 100 soldiers from Myanmar military battalion 22 were temporarily stationed at Basic Education Middle School of Pyain Taw Kon Tan (Pyein Taw) village. Materials inside the school and the fences were damaged after the military left. The utensils at the teachers' housing were also looted.

On 15 October 2019, in Mrauk-U Township, in Rakhine State, a Myanmar military unit of about 100 soldiers arrived in Pauk Taw Pyin village. The military soldiers ordered a motorbike taxi driver to buy food supplies for them whilst they gathered all women in the village and threatened to burn them. The soldiers also broke into the shops in the village to get food.

ACTOR1: NMSP/MNLA: New Mon State Party/Mon National Liberation Army
ACTOR2: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 18 October 2019, in Payathonzu, Kyainseikgyi Township, in Kayin State, a meeting was held between the Mon National Liberation Army (MNLA) and Karen National Liberation Army (KNLA) during which both sides verbally agreed to stop fighting.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: Around 19 October 2019, in Yangon, the Myanmar police force detained the family of the sister of the Commander-in-Chief of the Arakan Army at Yangon International Airport. The police detained the sister, her husband and her 3-year-old daughter.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
ACTOR2: NMSP/MNLA: New Mon State Party/Mon National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 22 October 2019, in Payathonzu Township, in Kayin State, the Karen National Union and the New Mon State Party reached an agreement regarding territorial boundaries between Ba Leh Doon Pite and Tee Wadoh villages.

On 23 October 2019, along the Mong Khark-Mong Noong-Mong Ngaen road, in Kongkhet Township, Kengtung District, Shan State (East), Myanmar military established a military checkpoint which reportedly limited the movement of USWA troops.

ACTOR2: KIO/KIA: Kachin Independence Organization/Kachin Independence Army
NOTES: On 24 October 2019, in Namtu Township, in Shan State, Myanmar military columns marched into area controlled by KIA's battalion 8 in Bang Gaw village where the KIO's 59th anniversary is to be held, leading to increased tension in the area.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: USDP: Union Solidarity and Development Party
NOTES: On 24 October 2019, in Kyaukme Township, in Shan State, an unknown armed group fired the gunshots in front of the Union Solidarity and Development Party office and the bus station gate. Nobody was injured.

ACTOR1: UWSP/UWSA: United Wa State Party/United Wa State Army
NOTES: On 25 October 2019, near Mong Hnyin Village, near Mongkhet Township, in eastern Shan State, the United Wa State Army brigade 468 surrounded the bamboo gate and security stations in the village set up by the Myanmar military division under Mongkhet brigade and destroyed them. UWSA withdrew its troops on October 27.
On 26 October 2019, in Kyauk Tan Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military arrived and stationed in the village, causing many villagers to flee.

Around 27 October 2019 (from 27 October - 2 November), in Htee Swea Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops stationed themselves in the village. During that time, some houses in the village were burglarized and property of the village school were destroyed. [Coded location at Htee Swea Ywar Haung]

ACTOR1: UWSP/UWSA: United Wa State Party/United Wa State Army
ACTOR2: PSC/NDAA-ESS: Peace and Solidarity Committee/National Democratic Alliance Army-Eastern Shan State
NOTES: On 28 October 2019, in between Mongla Army (NDAA) controlled area and UWSA controlled area in eastern Shan State (code for Monghket township), the United Wa State Army invaded Hko Hson gate station and entered into Naung Hote, Wun Nant, Par Hsan and Wun Chain villages. The NDAA refused to retreat. Tension is high in the area.

ACTOR1: UWSP/UWSA: United Wa State Party/United Wa State Army
NOTES: On 28 October 2019, in Mongla Township, Kengtung District, Shan State (East), USWA sent troops to set up a new outpost near an NDAA outpost.

On 10 November 2019, in Ywar Thar Yar Village, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, about 100 Myanmar military soldiers entered into the village and blocked the entrance and exit of the village. They also checked village houses and detained five villagers. They stayed in the village until November 12.
On 12 November 2019, in Mong Khark and Mongyang townships, the Myanmar military sent in troops a few weeks after the destruction of a Myanmar military checkpoint by USWA.
On 14 November 2019, in Ywar Thar Yar and Yoe Sa Nwin Villages, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military columns entered into the villages. Villagers fled to Myebon town out of fear.
On 14 November 2019, in Tha Yet Ta Pin Village, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, the police and Myanmar military moved into the village. They then detained four residents.

On 25 November 2019, two miles away from Kyauk Pan Tu (Ywar Thar Yar) Village and Chon Chaung village, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military took position at Yaw Chaung bridge and monitored the movement of the villagers. They blockaded the transport of food supplies into the village. The villagers are currently facing food shortages.
On 26 November 2019, in Oe Htein Village, in Mrauk-U Township, in Rakhine State, a column of 60 Myanmar military soldiers entered Oe Htein village and inspected houses in the village.
On 26 November 2019, in Namtu Town, in Namtu Township, in northern Shan State, Myanmar military began reinforcing their troops in the area.

Around 28 November 2019 (between 27 November - 30 November), in Zay Di Taung village, Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, the residents claimed that their property and belongings in their houses were looted and destroyed when a military column stayed in the village for four days.
On 29 November 2019, near U To Village, in Pathein Township, in Ayeyarwady Region, the security police forces detained 96 Rohingya Muslims who did not have any documents on them.

Around 2 December 2019 (from 28 November - 2 December), in Kyauktaw Town, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, a column of Myanmar military was stationed inside the Maha Kangyi Shin Pagoda compound. Another Myanmar military column arrived at the Pagoda compound after the first one left on December 2.

On 3 December 2019, in Ah Ngu Maw (Kone Tan) Village, in Ah Ngu Maw Kone Tan Village Tract, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, a column of Myanmar military entered the village while firing gunshots. They ordered all villagers to come to a monastery in the village where they were interrogated. The military then arrested two education staff on the suspicion of having connections with the Arakan Army.
On 3 December 2019, in Kone Tan Village, in Pyein Taw Village Tract, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops and the police entered the village and arrested two people.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Force
NOTES: On 3 December 2019, near Payathonzu Town, in Kyainseikgyi Township, in Kayin State, the combined force of the Myanmar military and the Karen Border Guard Force which overran an outpost of New Mon State Party based in Japan Yae Twin village last week decamped from the NMSP's outpost. They set up a presence at Hinthar Dine checkpoint which is located at a distance of 900 feet away from the outpost of NMSP.

On 4 December 2019, in Kyauktaw Town, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, soldiers of Myanmar military arrived at Shwe Kyaung monastery in Pai Thei Ward in Kyauktaw and been investigating passersby on Kan Nar road on December 5.
Around 8 December 2019 (from 4 December - 8 December) in Kyauktaw Town, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military soldiers set up camp at a primary school in Myo Ma ward.
Around 11 December 2019, in Monekoe Town, in Muse Township, in Shan State, Myanmar military troops entered the area under the control of the Kachin Independence Army brigade 6.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 12 December 2019, in Kyaung Chaung Village, in Nga Shar Village Tract, in Paletwa Township, in Chin State, Arakan Army soldiers arrived at the village. The villagers fled to Paletwa town on Dec. 17.

Around 14 December 2019, in Thaung Da Rar Village, in Thaung Da Rar Village Tract, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, houses were destroyed, and properties were looted after a column of Myanmar military entered the village. The villagers fled the village.

On 15 December 2019, near Kawthaung Township, in Tanintharyi Region, Myanmar military navy apprehended a boat in Myanmar's waters around 220 kilometers from the township. The boat carried 173 undocumented Rohingya people (82 men, 69 women, 14 boys, 9 girls) and 7 Myanmar crew members. Among them, 17 people were resettled in Sittwe and the rest were resettled in Buthidaung township after scrutinization.
Since 15 December 2019, in Ann Town, in Ann Township, in Rakhine State, security was tightened at the entrance and exit of the town. Myanmar military helicopters were also flying over the town daily.

On 16 December 2019, in Maungdaw Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops arrived at Shwe Zar (West) Village, Maung Ni village, Hlatha Village, Myo Ma Khayoungdan village, and Maungdaw town (block 5) which caused panic among the local Rohingya community.
On 16 December 2019, near Loi Tauk Village, in Loi Tauk Village Tract, in Lashio Township, in Shan State, Myanmar military troops and Ta'ang National Liberation Army troops arrived near the village.

On 23 December 2019, in Yoe Ta Yoke Village, in Yoe Ta Yoke Village Tract, in Ponnagyun Township, in Rakhine State, a column of over 100 Myanmar military soldiers entered into the village. They stationed themselves at the police station and took shelter in nearby houses.
On 27 December 2019, in Kyauktaw Town, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military was stationed inside the compound of Maha Kankyishin Pagoda.
On either 28 or 29 December 2019, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, residents claimed that there was unilateral gunfire shot by the Myanmar military towards Kyauktaw Town.

ACTOR2: KIO/KIA: Kachin Independence Organization/Kachin Independence Army
NOTES: On 7 January 2020, in Laiza, in Waingmaw Township, in Kachin State, a white fighter jet which is believed to belong to the Myanmar military flew more than five rounds over the Kachin Independence Army's camps in Laiza, Hka Ya Bum, Hpun Pyen Bum, Laisin Bum and Mai Ja Yang areas.

On 9 January 2020, in Nyaung Pin Hla Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military LID 22 arrived at the village. When the villagers returned to the village on February 5, they found that most houses had been vandalised and their property destroyed.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Force
NOTES: On 13 January 2020, near the villages of Palaing Japan and Guu Bar, in Payathonzu, in Kyainseikgyi Township, in Kayin State, about 30 members of Myanmar military and the Karen Border Guard Force (BGF) withdrew its troops from the Hinthar Dine checkpoint by demolishing their makeshift camp at the checkpoint.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 20 January 2020, near Me Let Maung Village, in Me Let Maung Village Tract, in Ann Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military claimed that the Arakan Army set fire to a cargo vehicle of Myanmar military and destroyed it near Me Lat Maung village on Ann-Sittwe road. The AA also detained the deputy military captain who drove that vehicle. The AA, however, denied the military's claim.

ACTOR2: KNPP/KA: Karenni National Progressive Party/Karenni Army
NOTES: On 20 January 2020, in Shadaw Township, in Kayah State, about 20 members of the Myanmar military set out to find the location of a battalion of Karenni National Progressive Party using a civilian as a route guide. The military column claimed it was searching for the battalion due to its involvement in the timber trade.

ACTOR2: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 21 January 2020, [Location coded at Hpapun Township], in Karen State, the Karen National Union issued a statement about the Myanmar military use of drones to gather intelligence information. The KNU claimed that drones supposedly controlled by the military have flown over the Hpapun district based KNU brigade 5 once or twice a week since September 2018. The drones also have flown five times over battalion 102 and 1 under KNU brigade 5 based in Hpapun during November and December 2019. The drones flew two times over the headquarters of KNU brigade 5 during December 2019. The Myanmar military, however, claimed that the drones were sent not for gathering intelligence, but rather for area security and regional development.

Around 22 January 2020, in Paletwa Township, in Chin State, more than 200 teachers applied for permission to transfer to other areas according to the director of the township education department. This bulk application is likely to be driven by the intensified fighting between the Myanmar military and the Arakan Army.

On 24 January 2020, in Kyauk Yan Thar Si Village, in Kyauk Yan Thar Si Village Tract, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, a column of about 150 Myanmar military soldiers arrived at the village. About 1000 villagers fled from the village and three surrounding villages.

On 24 January 2020, in Nga San Baw village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, a column of about 150 Myanmar military soldiers arrived in the village. About 1000 villagers fled from the village and three surrounding villages.

On 24 January 2020, in Maung Hpyu (Da Pyu Chaung) Village, in Kyauk Yan Thar Si Village Tract, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, a column of about 150 Myanmar military soldiers arrived at the village. About 1000 villagers fled from the village and three surrounding villages.

On 25 January 2020, in Sa Hnyin Village, in Sa Hnyin Village Tract, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, a column of 200 Myanmar military soldiers entered into the refugee camp and fired gunshots in the air. The soldiers also destroyed tarpaulin sheets and some temporary shelters. They also ordered the camp to close down.

On 25 January 2020, in Yae Poke Village, in Kyauk Yan Thar Si Village Tract, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, a column of about 150 Myanmar military soldiers arrived at Yae Poke village. About 1000 villagers fled from the village and three surrounding villages.

On 26 January 2020, in Sa Hnyin Village, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops arrived at the village and fired gunshots in the air and pressured village authorities to close down the refugee camp located in a community soccer field. The soldiers also destroyed the camp. The military claimed that they had to close an illegal camp for IDPs in order to clear landmines in the area since they heard a landmine explosion near the village and found a landmine near the camp.

On 27 January 2020, in Sa Hnyin Village, in Sa Hnyin Village Tract, in Myebon Township, in Rakhine State, five soldiers from Myanmar military LID 66 arrived at the IDPs camp where 300 refugees are taking shelter and proposed an alternative site to relocate the refugees. The relocation order came from the senior commander of the military after two days in which the military destroyed camp property.

Property destruction: On 28 January 2020, in Myaw Taung (Maungdaw township, Maungdaw district, Rakhine state), Myanmar military troops from Kyauk Pyin Seik arrived at Myaw Taung village and set two Rohingya-owned houses on fire. At the time of the incident, the house owners were already in a refugee camp across the border in Bangladesh, having fled in 2017.

ACTOR2: KIO/KIA: Kachin Independence Organization/Kachin Independence Army
NOTES: On 30 January 2020, in Mong Koe Sub-township, in Muse Township, in northern Shan State, Myanmar military issued an announcement that 21 KIA soldiers including high-rank personnel gave up their arms and weapons at Mong Koe Myanmar military station. However, the Kachin Independence Army denied that those involved were their soldiers.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Karen Information Center News

ACTOR1: NMSP/MNLA: New Mon State Party/Mon National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 1 February 2020, in Dawei District, in Tanintharyi Region, an unexploded landmine was found near a water pipe in a garden and safety removed by the NMSP.

About 800 villagers of Ku Lar Chaung and Pyein Taw fled the villages. About 57 villagers were trapped, but were successfully rescued on February 5.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 5 February 2020, near Maung Hnit Ma Village, in Nga Det Village Tract, in Paletwa Township, in Chin State, residents claimed that the Arakan Army stopped a machine boat and looted the salaries of government staff near the village. The looted salaries were returned on February 6.

Land seizure: On 5 February 2020, in Gaung Ni village (Buthidaung township, Maungdaw district, Rakhine state), the Buthidaung township vice administrator and Gaung Ni village administrators hired labourers to cut trees belonging to a Rohingya man who had fled to Bangladesh during the clearance operation. The trees were sold with proceeds shared between the two administrators.

On 9 February 2020, in Yet Khone Taing Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, ten out of 80 deserted houses in the village were burnt down. The military claimed that it seized weapons and AA flags when the arrived at the village and accused AA of burning down the houses. However, the AA denied the accusation.

On 11 February 2020, near the beach of Pauk Hla Gyai Village, in Pathein Township, in Ayeyarwaddy Region, the Myanmar navy detained 48 Rohingya men, women and children and five traffickers. It was not clear whether the group were headed for Malaysia or Indonesia.

On 15 February 2020, in Thin Ga Net Village, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, a column of Myanmar military arrived at the village and searched the houses of the villagers and also investigated the villagers. The military column left the village the same day.

Around 15 February 2020, in Hpar Hpyo Village, in Minbya Township, in Rakhine State, the Myanmar military took up positions at one part of the village. They forced the villagers to move to the other part. Villagers are currently staying at a monastery.

From 17 February 2020 to 3 March 2020, in Kyauk Khet village, near Hpa Lu Gyi Village, in Hpa Lu Village Tract, in Myawaddy Township, in Kayin State, about 60 members of Myanmar military have been stationed near the village which is under the control of DKBA. On 19 February 2020, near Tin Ma Village, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, a column of about 150 Myanmar military soldiers arrived at a monastic compound on a hill in the village. This caused the villagers to flee in fear.

On 19 February 2020, in Hlegu Township, in Yangon Region, Myanmar authorities arrested 49 Rohingya including 28 women, 18 men and 3 children in a wooded area in the township during their attempt to flee the country for Malaysia.
On 21 February 2020, in between Doe Tan and Laung Don Villages, in Maungdaw Township, in Rakhine State, an unexploded mine was detonated safely by the military.

On 22 February 2020, near Pwee Wone Village, in Paletwa Township, in Chin State, Myanmar military soldiers fired warning shots and stopped boats carrying more than 50 civilians, including students who were trapped for 2 weeks in Kyauktaw Town.

On 22 February 2020, near Tin Ma Village, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military soldiers fired warning shots and stopped boats carrying more than 50 civilians including students who were trapped for 2 weeks in Kyauktaw Town. This was the second time the group was stopped that day.

On 22 February 2020, in Nga Tauk Tu Chay Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, a column of 80 Myanmar military soldiers from LIB 536 and 538 arrived at the village which led the villagers to flee. The soldiers fired gunshots in the air when they entered into the village. Property and money were looted from the houses and shops in the village. The soldiers left the village the same day.

After clashes on February 22, 2020, in Hpapun Township, in Kayin State, tensions remain high between the Myanmar military and the Karen National Union due to the deployment of Myanmar military troops in areas controlled by KNU brigade 5. The military has deployed three brigades in the area.
On 24 February 2020, near Hpar Hpyo Village, in Minbya Township, in Rakhine State, a column of the Myanmar military took positions at the Yar Maung mountain range.
On 24 February 2020, in Tin Ma Village, in Kyauktaw Township, in Rakhine State, Myanmar military and police forces were heavily deployed in the area and conducted security operations.

NOTES: On 7 March 2020, in Ah Ngu Maw (Kone Tan) Village, in Rathedaung Township, in Rakhine State, about 100 members of Myanmar military soldiers, police and immigration officials surrounded the village and searched the houses.

ACTOR2: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army

NOTES: On 24 March 2020, in Lwei Htan village, in Kutkai township, in Muse district of Shan State, the Myanmar military seized more than 1000 weapons from Kaungkha PMF. NOTES: On 29 March 2020, in Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State, AA reportedly seized 20 rice bags meant for IDP people in Paletwa. The AA insisted that they bought from Paletwa Food Ration Transportation Committee.

On 04 April 2020, in Kyaukme town, Kyaukme township, Kyaukme district in Shan State, an unexploded grenade was found within the compound of Wailuwun monastery. On 08 April 2020, near Kha Maung Seik (coded as Ah Shey Kha Maung Seik) village, Maungdaw Township, Maungdaw District, Rakhine State, the Myanmar military seized two tents, ammunition, food and uniforms at a suspected encampment of ARSA, according to a statement released by Myanmar military on 09 April 2020.

On 09 April 2020, in Paletwa Town, Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State, more than 500 war-affected villagers from Hnan Chaung Wa village, Hna Ma Dar Village and Seint Sin Wa fled their villages to Paletwa Town.

Around 9 April 2020 (from 26 January - 9 April), in Luthaw Township, Muthraw (Hpapun) District, Karen State, the Myanmar military constant firing of artillery shells into the area forced over 360 villagers to flee their villages.

NOTES: On 14 April 2020, in Paletwa town, Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State, AA allegedly destroyed phone towers and the phone signal stopped working.

NOTES: On 16 April 2020, in Ann Town, Ann Township, Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine State, about 336 villagers from Kyeik Chaung village fled to Ann Town.

Displacement: Around 25 April 2020 (as reported), continued fighting between the Myanmar military and AA forced approximately 600 villagers to flee to Ponnagyun Town. At least 20 villages have been emptied as villagers flee the fighting.

On 26 April 2020, in Mrauk-U town, Mrauk-U Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State, police and military personnel carried out security measures in the town. NOTES: Around 1 May 2020 (between 1 April - 1 May), in Kayin State (coded as Hpapun), KNU battalion 5 and 7 accused Myanmar military of deploying about 190 military personnel and 20 border guard officers in KNU controlled area.

NOTES: On 5 May 2020, near Yar Maung Bridge, at Min, Myit Nar and Htauk Chay villages, Minbya Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops were deployed in schools, a monastery, and a community hall in the villages. NOTES: On 5 May 2020, near Myit Nar and Htauk Chay villages, Minbya Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops were deployed in schools, a monastery, and a community hall in the villages. The Myanmar military fired small guns at a football ground the village.

SOURCE: Development Media Group; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 5 May 2020, near Min village, Minbya Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State, the Myanmar military open fired as they moved into the village.

NOTES: On 6 May 2020, near War Tho Kho village, Luthaw Township, Mutraw (Hpapun) District, Karen State, Myanmar military troops burned down a temporary hut being used by the KNU to conduct temperature screenings as part of coronavirus prevention efforts.

On 6 May 2020, near War Tho Kho village, Luthaw Township, Muthraw (Hpapun) District, Karen State, fighting between Myanmar military and KNU battalion 9 forced over 480 villagers to flee their village.

On 6 May 2020, in Paletwa Town, Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State, more than 108 war-affected villagers from Pa Kar Chaung Wa village fled their village to Paletwa Town. On 9 May 2020, in Yae Shin village, Myebon Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State, the Myanmar military entered the village and detained about 70 villagers. On 12 May 2020, in Myebon Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State, Myanmar military troops carried out security measures at Sa Hnyin IDP camp after a landmine was discovered near the camp.

Around 13 May 2020 (as reported), over the past few days, in Luthaw Township, Muthraw (Hpapun) District, Karen State, the Myanmar military deployed troops around area controlled by 2nd, 5th and 7th Brigades of KNLA, according to the KNU. The Myanmar military denied KNU claimed.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 17 May 2020, in Hpapun Township, Hpapun District, Kayin State, the Myanmar military accused KNU battalion 5 of recruiting more than 100 young people. Some people fled the recruitment. The military claims any new recruitment is a violation of the NCA to which the KNU is a signatory.

Weapons seizure: Around 20 May 2020 (between 16 - 24 May), around Muse town, Muse township, Muse district (Shan State), joint security forces (assumed to be the Myanmar military) seized weapons from 6 different places during a 9-day period, according to a statement from the Myanmar military. The weapon seizure followed the recent explosions in Muse township.

On 26 May 2020, in Mee Let Wa village, in Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State, unknown people burned about 100 houses down in the abandoned village. The military and AA have previously fought in the area.

NOTES: On 22 June 2020, near Lwegel Town, Momauk Township, Bhamo District, Kachin State, Myanmar military destroyed a COVID-19 screening gate used by KIO to conduct coronavirus temperature screenings.

Around 25 June 2020 (from 24 - 26 June), in Kyaukme Township, Kyaukme District, Shan State, Myanmar military sent troops from IB 22, 23, 101 and 147 to different locations in Kyaukme Township after RCSS informed Myanmar military of the planned to hold World Anti-Drug Day.

On 26 June 2020, in Kyein Thar village, Rathedaung Township, Sittwe District, Rakhine State, a Myanmar military column burned two houses. The houses were burned down as the village administrator didn't appear for military interrogation.
Around 27 June 2020 (as reported), in Nat Maw village, Ann Township, Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine State, about 200 Myanmar military troops set up camp at a graveyard near the village.

Around 27 June 2020 (from 24 - 27 June), in Kyauk Tan area, Rathedaung Township, Sittwe District, Rakhine State, hundreds of villagers from more than 40 villages fled to Sittwe Town, Rathedaung Town and other villages after the Ministry of Security and Border Affairs issued an order regarding military clearance operations in the Kyauk Tan area.

Around 1 August 2020 (early in the month), in Tangyan Township (Lashio District, Shan State), Myanmar military LID-22 from Hpa-an and MOC-12 from Kawkareik, Karen State were deployed in the areas. An unreported number of villagers from Seng Hkawng, Nawng Lon, Ner Hel and Ner San fled to Mong Kao and Tang Yang (Tangyan) owns out of fear.

On 31 August 2020, in Thar Si village (coded as Thar Si Ywar Thit) (Kyauktaw Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State), the Myanmar military entered into the village after AA allegedly detained two members of Myanmar military. ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Shan Herald Agency for News

The villagers returned to Man Kawng after 5 days on 16 September.

Around 11 September 2020 (from 10-11 September), in northern Maungdaw (Maungdaw Township, Maungdaw District, Rakhine State), about 1,000 Myanmar military soldiers were deployed across Maungdaw Township.

Movement of forces: On 13 September 2020, near the border with Bangaldesh (coded as Maungdaw), Maungdaw township, Maungdaw district (Rakhine State), Myanmar troops on trawlers were mobilized along the border.

On 13 September 2020, at Zay Di Taung and Nyaung Kan village (Myebon Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State), more than 2400 villagers from the two villages fled to neighbouring villages after about 150 Myanmar military troops arrived at the villages. The Myanmar military searched two houses and detained 4 villagers in Nyaung Kan. However, the villagers were soon released.

ACTOR1: RCSS/SSA-S: Restoration Council of Shan State/Shan State Army-South
NOTES: Around 14 September 2020 (more than a week ago), RCSS blocked roads throughout three village tracks such Nawng Sam Hpu, Hkay Ong Awayt and Hpar Hkawng village tracks (Mongkaing Township, Loilen District, Shan State). Villagers accused RCSS of using the coronavirus as an excuse to block roads.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 14 September 2020, in five villages in Nga Shar village tract and Ye Chan Thar village, Kone Taw village tract (Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State), AA forcibly demanded two baskets of rice (about 10 kg) per or Ks. 10,000 in lieu of rice per household. Villagers were paid about Ks.40,000 per one rice bag (about 50 kg). The price offered by the AA was Ks.35,000 lower than the current market rate. Villagers were also asked to transport the rice to the forest and AA camp.

Around 15 September 2020 (month of), in Hpapun Township (Hpapun District, Kayin State), the Myanmar military expanded its troop presence in KIA's Brigade 7 controlled areas. KNU accused Myanmar military using election security concerns as cover to send in two Myanmar military battalions.

On 17 September 2020, more than 1,000 villagers from Shwe Laung Tin, Myin Kan Chaung and Kan Pyin villages (Rathedaung Township, Sittwe District, Rakhine State) fled after Myanmar military fired heavy weapons along the Mayu River.

On 19 September 2020, in Det Khi Na Thiri town (Det Khi Na Thiri Township, Det Khi Na District, Nay Pyi Taw), an unknown assailant threw a grenade at the house of Myanmar Sub-election Commission's Chairman. The grenade didn't explode and was cleared by police and Myanmar military.

On 20 September 2020, in Det Khi Na Thiri town (Det Khi Na Thiri Township, Det Khi Na District, Nay Pyi Taw), Myanmar police discovered an unexploded grenade at the house of Myanmar Sub-election Commission's Chairman. It is unclear who placed the grenade there. A similar incident happened the day before.

On 23 September 2020, in Ku Taung village (Rathedaung Township, Sittwe District, Rakhine State), nearly 2,000 villagers fled as Myanmar military column arrived at Ngalabya port on Mayu river located at two miles north of the village. The military arrived with two navy vessels.

On 26 September 2020, in Nat Seik village (Ponnagyun Township, Sittwe District, Rakhine State), Myanmar military troops were reportedly moving around Oo Raz Taung Pagoda near the village. Villagers fled out of fear.

Around 4 October 2020 (as reported), in Khang Khai and Nam Mark Hin villages (Kyaukme Township, Kyaukme District, Shan State), Myanmar military searched houses and looted food and possessions from villagers. Myanmar military also damaged houses, destroyed food supplies, and shot one buffalo and two pigs. All villagers fled from the village. Two villagers were also arrested but managed to escape. Myanmar military still blocked the village as of 12 October. Location coded as Kyaukme.

Around 8 October 2020 (as reported), the number of IDPs reached about 3,000 due to renewed clashes between Myanmar military and RCSS. IDPs sheltered at villages such as Pong Woe, Taung Hteik, Nar Hsawng, Nawng Kun, Nam Han Hkein, Kum Hin and Kawng Lan villages (Kyaukme Township, Kyaukme District, Shan State).

Looting: On 9 October 2020, in Hpa Yar Paung village, Kyauktaw township, Mrauk-U district (Rakhine State), locals accused the Myanmar army of taking relief items and food supplies from the locals whose house were burned down the previous month. A local also reported that Myanmar army took money from his mother.
On 10 October 2020, near Pone Woe village IDP camp (Kyaukme Township, Kyaukme District, Shan State), the Myanmar military twice transported materials and troops using four helicopters.

On 12 October 2020, more than 2,000 new IDPs from five villages in Rathedaung township (Sittwe District, Rakhine State) arrived at the IDP camp in Zay Di Pyin village, Rathedaung Township. The villagers were from Auk Kyawng Taung, Sa Hpo Kyun, Aung Zay Done, Pyin Wan and Kan Pyin villages.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 14 October 2020, in five villages in Nga Shar village tract (Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State), AA forcibly demanded two baskets of rice per household from five villages including Nga Shar village.
