Villagers were paid about Ks.10,000 per basket or Ks.50,000 per one rice bag. The price demand by AA was Ks.35,000 lower than the current market rate. Villagers were also asked to transport the rice to the forest and AA camp.

Arrests: On 2 November 2020, in a fisher's village or fishing port located at 5 miles from Sa Ne town (Kyaukpyu Township, Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine state), Myanmar military detained 45 fishermen and their family members including three children and more than 10 women. 42 of them were released after 6 days on 7 November and three were still detained. Military and navy personnel have been carrying out security operations in the area since the AA reportedly detained two military officers. Location coded as Kyaukpyu.

Arrests: On 2 November 2020, in Zaing Chaung village (Kyaukpyu Township, Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine State), Myanmar military detained about 150 villagers at a school for 12 days. They were released on 14 November. Myanmar military also left the village on the same day.

Displacement: On 2 November 2020, in Kyaukpyu Township, (Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine State), more than 700 villagers from Zaing Chaung, Thaing Chaung, Pyar Kywain, Tha Pyu Taung, Chaung Hpyar, Sin Poke and Kyet Tein villages have fled. Villagers fled out of fear of arrest as the Myanmar military columns were entering into villages and interrogating villagers. Location coded as Kyaukpyu.

ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Myanmar Times
NOTES: Recruitment: Around 8 November 2020 (from 7-8 November), in Mogoke Township (Pyin Oo Lwin District, Mandalay Region), more than 200 villagers have fled as TNLA allegedly recruited new members in villages like Pein Pyit (Upper), Pein Pyit (Lower), Chaung Gyi Kone San, Chaung Gyi Kyauk War and Chaung Gyi Mar Nar.

ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Myanmar Times
NOTES: Recruitment: Around 8 November 2020 (from 7-8 November), in Mongmit Township in Shan State, TNLA allegedly recruited new members.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: Looting: On 8 November 2020, in Pein Hne Ta Pin village (Paletwa Township, Mindat District, Chin State), AA soldiers entered into the village and demanded 20 rice bags from across Pein Hne Ta Pin village tract. AA demanded villagers to store the 20 rice bags in Pein Hne Ta Pin village by 14-15 November. The villagers do not know if the AA were going to give them money for the rice.

Looting: On 10 November 2020, in Tein Nyo village, Mrauk-U Town (Mrauk-U Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State), Myanmar military took 600 rice bags stored in a monastery for IDPs living in Tein Nyo village. The rice bags had been donated by ICRC and the Ministry of Social Welfare, Relief and Resettlement.

Security measures: On 11 November 2020, in Aung Lan Chein (also known as Ah Lan Chein) village (Kyaukpyu Township, Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine State), about 50 Myanmar military troops entered and inspected houses in the villages. Several villagers fled and some remained in the village. Myanmar military has inspected the village several times.

Displacement: Around 11 November 2020 (as reported), in Ramree Township (Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine State), about 500 villagers from Ku Lar Pone, Myo Chwein, Maw Yon and Nga Nyo Kaing villages have fled to Ramree and Sane Town. Villagers fled out of fear of arrest as the Myanmar military columns were entering into villages and interrogating villagers. Location coded as Ramree.

Movement of forces: Around 12 November 2020 (as reported), Myanmar military increased its military presence in southern Shan State in areas such as Pin Long, Nansang, Lin Hkay and Keng Tawng area. Location coded as Nansang (Nansang Township, Loilen District, Shan State).

Looting: On 15 November 2020, in Ah Pauk Wa village (Kyauktaw Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State), the Myanmar military allegedly looted several valuable items from six houses in the village. However, the Myanmar military denied the allegation. A military column had entered the village on 11 November and left on 15 November.

Displacement: Around 24 November 2020 (as reported), in Mogoke Township (Pyin Oo Lwin District, Mandalay Region), more than 1,000 villagers fled to Mogoke town following a clash between Myanmar military and TNLA on 24 November. Villagers fled for fear of a possible recurrence of clashes in the area.

Security measures: On 29 November 2020, in Ponnagyun Township (Sittwe District, Rakhine State), the Myanmar military one-sidedly fired guns from their outposts, reportedly for security reasons. No casualties reported.

Displacement: Around 4 December 2020 (as reported), near Yae Soe Chaung village and near Ah Myet Taung village (Rathedaung Township, Sittwe District, Rakhine State), local residents reported shooting incidents, forcing some recently-returned villagers to return to IDPs camps for fear of possible new clashes.

Displacement: Around 4 December 2020 (as reported), in Rathedaung Township (Sittwe District, Rakhine State), several villagers from Yae Boke and Maung Hpyu (Da Pyu Chaung) fled for fearing possible new clashes in the areas. Myanmar military soldiers were still active in the areas and loading materials with naval vessels. Location coded as Maung Hpyu (Da Pyu Chaung).

Movement of forces: Around 9 December 2020 (as reported), the Myanmar military increased its presence in Rakhine State. Villagers witnessed an increase in the number of soldiers with navy vessels, trucks and helicopters along the Mayu River. Location coded as Sittwe.

ACTOR1: SSPP/SSA-N: Shan State Progress Party/Shan State Army-North
NOTES: Recruitment: On 9 December 2020, in Tangyan township (Lashio District, Shan State), SSPP demanded 120 people to join SSPP from three village tracts (Mong Pat, Ho Mat and Kone Mun). Location coded as Tangyan.

Property destruction: On 9 December 2020, between Mingalar Nyunt and Wai Lar Taung village (Maungdaw Township, Maungdaw District, Rakhine State), a meat vendor saw about 20 ARSA members after hearing a gunshot near Mingalar Nyunt (NaTaLa). He ran away but his motorbike was torched. Location coded as Mingalar Nyunt.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Force
NOTES: Security measures: On 11 December 2020, in Myawaddy town (Myawaddy Township, Myawaddy District, Kayin State), a combined force of Myanmar military and local police seized more than 100 cars having some connection to BGF in two separate days on 11 and 12 December. The move had raised fears among civilians for potential military unrest.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021) Border Guard Force
NOTES: Security measures: On 12 December 2020, in Myawaddy town (Myawaddy Township, Myawaddy District, Kayin State), a combined force of Myanmar military and local police seized more than 100 cars having some connection to BGF in two separate days on 11 and 12 December. The move has raised fears among civilians for potential military unrest.

Movement of forces: Around 14 December 2020 (as reported), in Dar Let Chaung village tract (Ann Township, Kyaukpyu District, Rakhine State), Myanmar military fully blocked both land road and waterway towards Kazu Kaing village. Myanmar military previously blocked the roads partially and villagers were able to access Kuzu Kaing through Me Let Maung. However, the new full lockdown has now affected more than 4,000 villagers, cutting off delivery of food and other necessities.

ACTOR1: RCSS/SSA-S: Restoration Council of Shan State/Shan State Army-South
NOTES: Land seizure: Around 16 December 2020 (as reported), in Loi Tawng village, Yang Nang village tract (Mongkaing Township, Loilen District, Shan State) (coded as Mongkaing), RCSS allegedly forced villagers to move from the current location of Loi Tawng village to its previous location, about 2 miles from the current location. However, RCSS denied the allegation. The village administrator took the villagers to the former location for administrative reasons, according to RCSS. The village is primarily inhabited by ethnic Ta'ang villagers.
Displacement: On 27 December 2020, in Kyuakme township (Kyaukme District, Shan State), the fighting between the Myanmar military and KNU has displaced more than 1,500 villagers.

Displacement: Around 28 December 2020 (as reported), in Me Waing area (Hpapun Township, Hpapun District, Kayin State), the fighting between Myanmar military and KNU has displaced more than 3,000 villagers. The tension between the Myanmar military and KNU in the area reportedly remained high with Myanmar military deploying more troops in KNU brigade 5 base area.

Movement of forces: On 28 December 2020, in Hpapun township (Hpapun District, Kayin State), the Myanmar military deployed about 300 troops in KNU brigade 5 base area. Afterwards, more Myanmar military presence in the areas has fueled the military tension between the Myanmar military and KNU.

ACTOR1: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: Recruitment: On 3 January 2021, three AA soldiers entered into a village and held a meeting with villagers. The AA demanded 5 young people from the village to attend 'administrative training' and to pay 400,000 per person to support them during the training. AA reportedly have been carrying out recruitment among 80 Chin populated villages in Minbya, Mrauk-U and Myebon Townships in Rakhine State. Location coded to Mrauk-U town.

Movement of forces: On 4 January 2021, at Cha La Jo in Kayin State, Myanmar military shot machine gun all day to scare nearby villagers. Casualties unknown. Myanmar military has been reportedly taking offensive in Butho, Hpapun and Dwe Lo Township in Hpapun District in the first two weeks of January. Location coded as Hpapun.

Arrests: On 6 January 2021, in Shwepyithar Township (Yangon-North, Yangon Region), Myanmar police arrested 99 Rohingya who came from Maungdaw, Buthidaung, Sittwe and Kyauktaw in Rakhine State to travel to Malaysia to work. They were part of a trafficking network, according to the police. 73 of them were women and many of them brought their children along with them.

Displacement: Around 7 January 2021 (as reported), more than 3700 villagers have been displaced by the fighting between TNLA and RCSS in Namtu and Kyaukme Townships (Kyaukme District, Shan State) (coded as Kyaukme District).
Looting: On 7 January 2021, in Mar Lar village, (Kyauktaw Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State), Myanmar military forcefully took 700 baskets of paddy from the villagers.

Movement of forces: Around 7 January 2021 (from 4 - 10 January), Myanmar military were active in Kayin State, building roads, entering villages and reportedly supply foods to their bases. As the result, several villagers from Tha Kaw Hta, Yee Mu in Hpapun (Luthaw), Butho and Dwe Lo Townships (Hpapun District, Kayin State) and villagers from another three villages in Nyaunglebin Township in Kayin State fled. Location coded as Hpapun.

Movement of forces: On 7 January 2021, in Alethankyaw village on the southern Maungdaw coast (Maungdaw Township, Maungdaw District, Rakhine State), about 1,500 Myanmar military troops arrived at the village with two naval ships. They entered a BGP camp. Soon after, the Myanmar military headed towards the north of Maungdaw with 30 military trucks. Location coded as Maungdaw.

Displacement: On 11 January 2021, in Kaw Pawng village (Kyaukme Township, Kyaukme District, Shan State), villagers fled their village to Kyaukme town as nearby RCSS troops entered the village. RCSS and TNLA were based around the area. Villagers fear possible clashes. Location coded as Kyaukme.

SOURCE: Shan Herald Agency for News; Mizzima
NOTES: Looting: On 13 January 2021, in Baw Mar village (Mogoke Township, Pyinoolwin District, Mandalay Region), members of an unknown armed group in civilian clothes forcibly collected money from traditional quarry workers.

Recruitment: On 15 January 2021, in Loke Kan village track (Mongkaing Township, Loilen District, Shan State), an unknown armed group carried out recruitment, threatened villagers and asked taxes from villagers. Some young people fled to the forest and to towns.

Recruitment: On 15 January 2021, in Mong Lan village track (Hopong Township, Taunggyi District, Shan State), an unknown armed group carried out recruitment, threatened villagers and asked for taxes from villagers. Some young people fled to the forest and to towns.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Myanmar (2016-2021); Government of Myanmar (2016-)
NOTES: Arrests: On 19 January 2021, at Yazudaing River near Thit Poke Village, Kywe Chan Wa village tract (Mawlamyinegun Township, Labutta District, Ayeyarwady Region), immigration officials, Myanmar police and Myanmar military inspected a vessel, and found and arrested 34 Rohingyas.

ACTOR1: KIO/KIA: Kachin Independence Organization/Kachin Independence Army
NOTES: Looting: On 23 January 2021, in Man Ping village track (Kutkai Township, Muse District, Shan State), two KIA soldiers entered a sugarcane farm and forcefully took alcohol and motorcycle from residents. Location coded as Kutkai.

Property destruction: On 24 January 2021, at Me Waing village (Hpapun Township, Hpapun District, Kayin State), Myanmar military set a house on fire. Myanmar military troop from LIB 339 were based in the village.
Property destruction: On 26 January 2021, in Me Waing village (Hpapun Township, Hpapun District, Kayin State), the Myanmar military set fire to a house.

Coup/military takeover: On 1 February 2021, Myanmar military declared a State of Emergency and seized power from the civilian government. The Myanmar military claimed that it took power after the civilian government and UEC failed to address alleged electoral fraud which led to several demonstrations in the country. The government denied a request to suspend Parliament. Several leaders, including State Counselor, President, State and Region Chief Ministers, Members of Parliament, and others politicians were arrested from the parliament in Nay Pyi Taw. Although some of them have been released, many were still detained.

On 1 February 2021, in Yangon city (Yangon region), the security forces (assumed to be the military and police) arrested a former pro-democracy activist. The security forces filed a lawsuit under penal code 905(b) for allegedly promoting hate speech.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Myanmar (2016-); NLD: National League for Democracy
NOTES: On 1 February 2021, in Hpakant town (Hpakant Township, Mohnyin District, Kachin State), the security forces (assumed to be the military and police) arrested a member of Pyithu Parliament (NLD) representing Hpakant township.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of Myanmar (2016-); Labour Group (Myanmar); Health Workers (Myanmar)
SOURCE: Independent Mon News Agency; Karen Information Center News; Eleven Media Group; Radio Free Asia; Myanmar Times
NOTES: Strikes: On 2 February 2021, government staffers from different sectors such as Ministry of Health, Municipal Government and Village/Ward Administration from different cities across the country joined civil disobedience movement to oppose Myanmar military coup (coded as Nay Pyi Taw). The movement was reportedly launched by health workers in Mandalay on 2 February. The movement was expected to grow countrywide.

Arrests: On 3 February 2021, in Kyangin township (Hinthada District, Ayeyarwady Region), two police officers were arrested and detained after posting on Facebook to express their opposition against the Myanmar military coup, urging people to resist the junta.

Other: On 4 February 2021, in Nay Pyi Taw, about 100 NLD members of parliament held a parliamentary session and swearing of oath for civil service to express their rejection of the Myanmar military coup.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Other: On 4 February 2021, the Ministry of Defense issued a directive to abolish the retirement age of 65 years for the Commander-in-Chief and Deputy Commander-in-Chief without setting a new age limit. This implies that both leaders could remain their positions until they are toppled or voluntarily step down. Before to the coup on 1 February, the Commander-in-Chief Min Aung Hlaing was expected to retire when he turns 65 years in July 2021. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

Other: On 5 February 2021, 15 elected MPs from the NLD who were ousted following the military coup formed the Committee Representing the Pyidaungsu Hluttaw as the committee representing elected lawmakers. On the same day, the Committee advised UN representatives and foreign countries that the government led by President Win Myint is the only legitimate government of Myanmar. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

Arrests: On 6 February 2021, an Australian citizen and a professor of economics who served as an economic adviser to the NLD-led Myanmar government was detained by the Myanmar military. Although he reportedly has had a chance to speak to his wife, his whereabouts are not known. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Security measures: On 8 February 2021, township authorities invoked Section 144 of the Penal Code and announced that a total of 90 townships in 30 cities across Myanmar (coded as Nay Pyi Taw) are placed under a curfew from 8pm to 4am every night, while gatherings of more than five people are banned. On 4 May 2021, the State Administration Council announced that the curfew hours have been amended to 10pm to 4am.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Security measures: On 9 February 2021, the curfew that had been in effect since they day before between 12am to 4am in Sittwe and Pauktaw townships (coded as Sittwe) has been lifted, according to the Sittwe District Administrator. The curfew was withdrawn as there has been no new cases of the coronavirus in these areas.
Arrests: On 9 February 2021, in Muse township (Muse District, Shan State), police arrested two Muse township NLD members, including the chairperson of the Muse 105 mile Trade Zone.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Strikes: On 9 February 2021, in Myeik town (Myeik Township, Myeik District, Tanintharyi Region), 15 Ward and Village administrators resigned to show support for the nationwide civil disobedience movement to oppose the Myanmar military coup.

Arrests: On 10 February 2021, in Bhamo District, Kachin State, the chairperson of Bhamo District Election Commission was arrested by the authorities (assumed to be police). According to his family, his whereabouts remained unknown at the time of reporting as of 14 February 2021. This was part of a broader campaign of arrests of election commission officials in night-time raids by the military government to allegedly force these officials to provide evidence to support the military's claims of electoral fraud.
Arrests: On 10 February 2021, in Pathein township (Pathein District, Ayeyarwady Region), a female journalist was arrested by the police and some plainclothes men.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Myanmar (2016-); NLD: National League for Democracy
NOTES: Arrests: On 10 February 2021, in Sittwe township (Sittwe District, Rakhine State), the Chief Minister of Rakhine State from the NLD was arrested by the police and military at his place of residence. He was charged on 9 February under Section 505(b) of the Penal Code for posting a video of himself protesting against the military on Facebook.

Arrests: On 11 February 2021, in Muse township (Muse District, Shan State), a man was taken away by five plainclothes men in two cars while he was on his way to join a protest against the Myanmar military coup. He has since been detained at the Muse Police Station and charged under the Natural Disaster Management Law. He has been denied access to see his family.
Arrests: On 11 February 2021, in Yangon city (Yangon region), the Myanmar military detained 98 UEC officers from 44 Townships.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
SOURCE: Irrawaddy; Guardian (United Kingdom); Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Other: On 12 February 2021, the Commander-in-Chief announced that 23,314 prisoners were pardoned and released from various prisons across the country (coded as Nay Pyi Taw) under section 401, subsection (1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Their release coincided with the appearance of mobs creating community disturbances across Myanmar, including unverified reports of arson, smashed cars and poisoned water tanks, leading to residents organizing night-time vigilante groups. The mass pardon has sparked fears that the military was a previously-used tactic following the 1988 democracy uprising, where mobs were similarly dispatched to create chaos.

Property destruction: On 12 February 2021, in Yangon City (Yangon Region), fires reportedly broke out in South Okkalapa, Tamwe, Thaketa and North Dagon townships. While the cause of the fire was not clear, it was widely believed that these were deliberate acts of arson committed by ex-prisoners recently pardoned by the military on the same day.

Arrests: On 13 February 2021, in Magway city (Magway Region), former Magway Region Minister of Immigration and Population was taken away by a group of plainclothes men and detained by the police. He had been leading recent protests against the military coup. He has been charged under the Disaster Management Law.

Arrests: On 13 February 2021, in Gwa town, Gwa township (Thandwe District, Rakhine State), a former ward administrator of Gwa town was taken away by the military for protesting against the military coup. He had since been held incommunicado.

Other: Around 14 February 2021 (month of), in Mindat township (Mindat district, Chin state), the Mindat Public Administration consisting of a chairman, security, a CDM Judge for the judiciary and treasurer in agencies responsible for the township's judicial, defense, education, finance, business, and information matters was formed with the support of the Chin National Army.

Arrests: On 14 February 2021, in Hpa-an (Hpa-an Township, Hpa-an District, Kayin State), police arrested 20 youths who had joined anti-coup protests at night. The youths were released the next day after signing a confession to not participate in further protests.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2021-); Government of Myanmar (2016-)
NOTES: Strikes: Around 14 February 2021 (month of), in Hpruso town and Demoso town (Loikaw District, Kayah State), some police officers joined the nationwide civil disobedience movement to oppose the Myanmar military coup. At least 75 police officers from Loikaw, Demoso and Hpruso reportedly have joined the movement. 14 staff from Ward Administration Office and General Administration Department from Hpruso also joined the movement and were fired on 22 February.

Other: On 15 February 2021, in Yangon City (Yangon Region), military reportedly took money out from two branches of Myanma Economic Bank. Some reports claimed that the military was 'withdrawing large amount of cash' from the MEB, which owns banks that manage the military's pensions.
Arrests: On 15 February 2021, Myanmar police arrested more than 30 young people including students in Nay Pyi Taw. 27 of them were released later.

SOURCE: Shan Herald Agency for News; Democratic Voice of Burma
NOTES: Other: On 15 February 2021, in Taunggyi town (Taunggyi Township, Taunggyi District, Shan state), nearly 100 police officers surrounded Sao San Tun Hospital in an attempt to arrest doctors who had been participating in the civil disobedience movement. Police fired slingshots, damaging the doors of staff quarters. No arrests were made. No injuries reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Myanmar (2021-); Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Arrests: On 15 February 2021, in Myaungmya town (Myaungmya Township, Myaungmya District, Ayeyarwady Region), police, military and officials from the General Administration Department conducted a raid on the Myanma Economic Bank. Residents in the area alleged that gunshots were heard during the raid. The reason for the raid is not clear, but it was reported that some employees of the bank had been arrested at their homes by the authorities.

Other: On 15 February 2021, in Budalin town (Budalin Township, Monywa District, Sagaing Region), military conducted a raid on the Myanma Economic Bank. Local residents claimed that soldiers were seen leaving the bank carrying iron boxes. Some reports claimed that the military was 'withdrawing large amount of cash' from the MEB, which owns banks that manage the military's pensions.

Arrests: On 15 February 2021, in Laukkaing township (Laukkaing District, Shan State), a man was arrested and detained by the police under Section 505 of the Penal Code for posting a message on Facebook criticizing the military.

SOURCE: Irrawaddy; Radio Free Asia; Myanmar Now
NOTES: Other: On 16 February 2021, police filed a second charge against State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi under Section 25 of the Natural Disaster Management Law, for allegedly violating laws on public gatherings under the coronavirus restrictions, in addition to a previous charge under the Export and Import Law. On 1 March 2021, the Myanmar court filed two additional charges, under the Section 505(b) of the Penal Code for causing 'fear or alarm' or disrupting 'public tranquillity', and under a telecommunications law. On 1 April, it was reported that the military junta has charged her under Section 3 of the Official Secrets Act. On 9 June, the junta charged her under Section 55 of the Anti-Corruption Law, which carries a maximum jail term of 15 years in prison. The charges are widely considered to be a politically-motivated move by the military to justify the coup d'etat. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Eleven Media Group
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 16 February 2021, in Kawkareik town (Kawkareik Township, Kawkareik District, Kayin State), KNLA troops were reportedly deployed to surround and protect anti-military coup protesters. Tens of thousands of protesters including health workers, government staff, and teachers were demonstrating. It was reported that police forces were present and set up a roadblock, but no intervention was reported.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Myanmar (2021-) People's Militia Force
SOURCE: Assistance Association for Political Prisoners; Democratic Voice of Burma
NOTES: On 17 February 2021, in Hsihseng township (Pa-O Self-Administered Zone, Shan-South), an NLD member who was the former Hsihseng township municipal chair was arrested by the people's militia and transferred to the eastern command then to Taung Lay Lone prison. He later died of COVID-19 at Sao San Tun hospital on 27 August 2021.

Other: On 17 February 2021, eleven members of the Myanmar Press Council announced that they have resigned from the council, on the grounds that it would no longer be possible to protect press freedom under the military junta. This came after the Ministry of Information issued to the council to urge the media to report 'ethically' and 'avoid instigating public unrest.' On 16 February, more than a dozen journalists from Myanmar Times resigned due to alleged censorship by the management team. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

Arrests: On 18 February 2021, in Nay Pyi Taw City (Nay Pyi Taw), authorities arrested 11 civil servants, including nine from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. They had since been held incommunicado. This was part of a broader campaign to deter civil servants from going on strike as part of the civil disobedience movement.

Arrests: On 19 February 2021, in Pathein township (Pathein District, Ayeyarwady Region), a group of three plainclothes men (assumed to be police) arrested a university student, likely for taking part in protests against the military coup. He had since remained uncontactable.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 19 February 2021, in Kawkareik town, Kawkareik Township (Kawkareik District, Kayin State), armed KNLA Bridge 6 troops were present at an anti-military coup protest to provide security for the protest march.

On 20 February 2021, in Magway town, Magway township (Magway District, Magway Region), a member of the Pyithu Hluttaw (House of Representatives) was arrested by the police as he was carrying out pot-banging activities at his place of residence. He was released on 18 October after the amnesty announced by coup leader Min Aung Hlaing on 18 October.

SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Kachin News Group; Myitkyina Journal; Network Media Group
NOTES: Arrests: On 20 February 2021, in Puta-O township (Puta-O District, Kachin State), nine people were arrested by military personnel for their involvement in leading protests against the military coup. Five of them had been hiding in the jungle for 12 days since 9 February before they were discovered, and remained detained at the Putao City Police Station. Four of them were released on the same day. It was reported on 25 February that the remaining five people were charged under Article 505(b) for committing an offence against the state and Article 144 for unlawful assembly.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Myanmar (2016-); NLD: National League for Democracy; 88 Generation Peace and Open Society
NOTES: Arrests: On 20 February 2021, in Taunggyi town, Taunggyi township (Taunggyi District, Shan State), an NLD Secretary of Taunggyi District (also an alumnus of the 88 Generation Peace and Open Society) was arrested by four plainclothes men (assumed to be police) while sitting at a restaurant with his friends.

SOURCE: VOA; Eleven Media Group; Democratic Voice of Burma
NOTES: Arrests: On 20 February 2021, in Yangon City (Yangon State), a famous actor was arrested by the police at his place of residence for allegedly encouraging civil servants to join the civil disobedience movement. He was one of the six celebrities that the military had issued a warrant to arrest for charges under Section 505 (a) of the penal code. According to his wife, his whereabouts remain unknown.

On 21 February 2021, in Bu Ywet Ma Nyoe village (Mrauk-U Township, Mrauk-U District, Rakhine State), the Myanmar military detained 48 villagers for violating the COVID-19 curfew and released them on the following day.

Arrests: On 21 February 2021, in Mohnyin town, Mohnyin township (Mohnyin District, Kachin State), two members of a local civic group 'We Love Mohnyin' were arrested by the police for staging protests against the Myanmar military. They have been charged under Section 25 of the Natural Disaster Management Law.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 21 February 2021, in Myawaddy town (Myawaddy Township, Myawaddy District, Kayin State), KNU soldiers were seen at a protest against the Myanmar military coup, while Karen National Police Force (under the KNU) reportedly provided escort to protesters.

Arrests: On 22 February 2021, in Myeik town, Myeik township (Myeik District, Tanintharyi Region), the nephew and daughter of a protest leader were arrested by the police during a raid, after they failed to find the protest leader at home.

Arrests: On 24 February 2021, in Monywa town (Monywa township, Monywa district, Sagaing region), two female reporters were arrested by the police and charged under Penal Code 505(A). They were both released on bail on 25 February.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Myanmar (2021-) Border Guard Force
NOTES: Arrests: On 24 February 2021, in Kyaikmaraw town (Kyaikmaraw township, Mawlamyine district, Mon state), nine locals - including members of NLD - were arrested by the Border Guard Force.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Myanmar (2016-); NLD: National League for Democracy
NOTES: Arrests: On 25 February 2021, in Thaton town (Thaton township, Thaton division, Mon state), a local elected female NLD member of parliament and her husband were arrested by the police. She was later transferred to a prison and charged under section 505 (b) of the penal code.

Other: On 26 February 2021, at the UN General Assembly session, the Myanmar's Permanent Representative to the UN called for the international community to take the 'strongest possible action' to overturn the military coup. He also stated that he represented the position of the country's legitimate and democratically elected government, before concluding his statement by raising the three-finger salute popularized by protesters staging demonstrations across Myanmar against the coup. On 27 February 2021, the State Administration Council announced on state television that the Ambassador had been relieved of his position for 'betraying the country'. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

Arrests: On 26 February 2021, in Monywa town (Monywa township, Monywa district, Sagaing region), three members of the student union of Monywa University of Economics were arrested by the police in the early morning. While two of them had been released, the chairperson remains in police custody.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Myanmar (2016-); NLD: National League for Democracy
NOTES: Arrests: On 26 February 2021, in Oke Ta Ra Thi Ri town (Oke Ta Ra Thi Ri township, Oke Ta Ra district, Nay Pyi Taw), the chairperson of the NLD of Nay Pyi Taw was arrested by about 20 police officers while in hiding at Hotel Shwe Gone Daing. It was not known where he has been taken to.

Arrests: On 26 February 2021, in Mahaaungmyay town, Mahaaungmyay township (Mandalay District, Mandalay Region), an activist and his wife were taken away and detained by the police and military near 41st and 85th street.

Arrests: On 28 February 2021, in Monywa town, Monywa township (Monywa District, Sagaing Region), police and Myanmar military soldiers arrested and detained some funeral parlour workers and relief workers. They remained detained as of 1 March. The reason for their arrests was not known, but funeral parlours providing services for deaths related to the anti-coup movement have been targetted by security forces.

Arrests: On 28 February 2021, in Myitkyina town, Myitkyina township (Myitkyina district, Kachin State), a group of plainclothes men (assumed to be police) and soldiers broke into the house of an ethnic Lisu artist and arrested him. The reason for his arrest was not known. It was reported that the artist had been a supporter of the NLD-led government.

Non-violent activity: On 28 February 2021, in Myawaddy town (Myawaddy Township, Myawaddy District, Kayin State), DKBA (Benevolent) troops were present at an anti-military coup protest, presumably to provide security for the protest march. They confronted the Myanmar police when they arrested 10 protesters during the protest. No violence was reported.

On 1 March 2021, in Myeik town (Myeik Township, Myeik District, Tanintharyi Region), the Myanmar military and police arrested a journalist at his house at night. He was released on 19 October after the amnesty announced by coup leader Min Aung Hlaing on 18 October.

On 1 March 2021, the Committee Representing the Pyidaungsu Hluttaw (CRPH) representing ousted elected lawmakers following the military coup declared the military's State Administration Council a 'terrorist group' for its arbitrary arrests of democratically elected leaders and its use of violence against peaceful protesters and civilians. The CRPH added in its statement that it strongly condemns the State Administration Council's acts of violence and arbitrary arrests, stating that it was a declaration of war against the state and its citizens. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

SOURCE: Bangkok Post; Khonumthung News; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Other: Around 1 March 2021 (between 28 February - 2 March), in Sagaing Region, at least 19 police officers reportedly fled across the border into India to escape taking orders from the military junta. Four other civilians reportedly crossed into India between 28 February and 1 March.

Arrests: On 1 March 2021, in Monywa town, Monywa township (Monywa District, Sagaing Region), police and Myanmar military soldiers arrested about 14 people, including 3 doctors and 11 volunteers, while they were operating free mobile clinics. Security forces have targetted health workers viewed as providing support to anti-coup protesters.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Myanmar (2016-); NLD: National League for Democracy
NOTES: Arrests: On 1 March 2021, in Oke Ta Ra Thi Ri town, Oke Ta Ra Thi Ri township (Oke Ta Ra District, Nay Pyi Taw), an elected NLD parliamentarian was arrested by armed plainclothes security forces (assumed to be police).

Arrests: On 2 March 2021, in Hlaing township (Yangon-West District, Yangon Region), the Head of Oriental Studies of Yangon University was arrested by three plainclothes men (assumed to be police) while he and other students were gathered near MICT Park before the start of a protest against the Myanmar military coup. He was reportedly taken away at gunpoint.

ACTOR2: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: Change to armed group: Around 2 March 2021 (as reported), in Hpapun town, Hpapun township (Hpapun district, Kayin State) the KNU spokesperson reported that 12 soldiers from the Myanmar military's Light Infantry Battalions 402 and 403 (based in Dawei) defected to the KNU Brigade 5, in a show of solidarity with demonstrators opposing the Myanmar military coup.

Movement of forces: Around 3 March 2021 (as reported), in Kawkareik township (Kawkareik District, Kayin State), the Myanmar military deployed about 1,000 soldiers in KNU controlled area. There are reportedly more than 5,000 Myanmar military soldiers in KNU brigade 3 and 5 controlled areas.

Looting: On 3 March 2021, in Yangon city (Yangon region), security forces (assumed to be police and military) raided the office of a local charity organisation Free Funeral Service Society and took 500 million kyats and destroyed office equipment. The leader of the organization and his wife also faced a lawsuit. The security forces accused them of supporting civil servants who joined the civil disobedience movement.

Security measures: On 3 March 2021, in Hakha town (Hakha Township, Hakha District, Chin State), military and police forces raided the Hakha Fire Department. Eight firefighters who were at the station at the time managed to escape. The reason for the raid was not reported.

Arrests: On 4 March 2021, in Mandalay city (Mandalay Region), the vice chairman of Mandalay Region Chamber of Commerce & Industry was arrested at night. He was reportedly arrested for attempting to use the COVID-19 fund to support the civil disobedience movement.

Other: On 4 March 2021, in Mandalay City (Mandalay Region), military and police forces exhumed the body of a 19-year-old woman who was shot dead by security forces during a protest against the military coup on 3 March.

Arrests: On 4 March 2021, in Monywa town, Monywa township (Monywa District, Sagaing Region), police and Myanmar military soldiers arrested about 3 aid workers while they were doing a relief operation.

Security measures: On 4 March 2021, in North Okkalapa township (Yangon-east District, Yangon Region), the Myanmar military and police fired several gunshots on Khe Mar Thi road at night. No target specified.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 5 March 2021, in Kawkareik Township (Kawkareik District, Kayin State), KNU Brigade 7 were deployed at the scene to provide security for locals protesting against the military coup. More than 1,000 people joined the protest.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 5 March 2021, in Hpapun township (Hpapun district, Kayin state), KNU Brigade 5 were deployed at the scene to provide security for locals protesting against the military coup. More than 10,000 people joined the protest.

Looting: On 5 March 2021, in Mahaaungmyay township (Mandalay district, Mandalay Region), military troops raided a house between 35th and 36 street and fired shots, causing damage to the car and properties in the house. It was reported that they also took away gold from the house. It was not reported if live rounds or rubber bullets were fired.

Arrests: On 5 March 2021, in Myitkyina town (Myitkyina Township, Myitkyina District, Kachin State), a man (also an NLD member) was arrested by the police in front of the General Administration Department office. While the reason for his arrest was not known, it was reported that he had been actively involved in the ongoing protests against the military coup.

ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 5 March 2021, in Loi Lumt and Mae Han village (Lashio Township, Lashio District, Shan State), hundreds of TNLA soldiers entered the village at around 4:00 AM.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Health Workers (Myanmar); Government of Myanmar (2016-); NLD: National League for Democracy
NOTES: Arrests: On 6 March 2021, in Madaya town (Madaya Township, Pyin Oo Lwin District, Mandalay Region), the Myanmar police arrested an NLD Chairman for Madaya Township along with a medical doctor and deputy director of the Education Department at night.

Around 6 March 2021, in Pathein town (Pathein Township, Pathein District, Ayeyarwady Region), the Myanmar military established a base near No.9 Basic Education for High School and in Pathein University.

Other: On 6 March 2021, in Shwebo town (Shwebo Township, Shwebo District, Sagaing Region), the Myanmar police broke in and entered the Shwe University campus. Although locals attempted to block them, the police entered from the other side of the university. About 100 local people were living inside the campus. It is not known yet what happened inside the campus.

On 6 March 2021, in Mawlamyine city (Mawlamyine Township, Mawlamyine District, Mon State), about 150 Myanmar military soldiers and police officers were deployed and occupied the premises of the main campus and one of the dormitories of Mawlamyine University. It was reported that the key to the main campus and ten other township government offices had been confiscated by security forces. This was part of a coordinated deployment by military troops to occupy and establish bases in hospitals and other public buildings across Myanmar between 6-7 March.
Arrests: On 6 March 2021, in Yangon city (Yangon Region), Shan State Minister for Planning and Finance was arrested. He has been arrested once previously after the Myanmar military coup.

Arrests: On 6 March 2021, in Mandalay City (Mandalay region), police arrested a veteran activist of the 1988 uprising while he was on his way home. He was reportedly detained in a prison in Mandalay and has been denied access to see his family.

Looting: On 6 March 2021, in Yadanabon University campus in Mandalay city (Mandalay Region), the Myanmar military and police broke into the Yadanabon University rector's house. They loaded materials from the house in their car and also took some money, a phone and a laptop.
Arrests: On 7 March 2021, in Mingalar Taung Nyunt Township (Yangon-east District, Yangon Region), about 15 armed soldiers fired gunshots and arrested a civilian.
Around 7 March 2021 (as reported), in Pathein town (Pathein township, Pathein District, Ayeyarwady region), the Myanmar military established an outpost within the Ta Gaung Pagoda compound.

On 7 March 2021, in Mandalay City (Mandalay Region), military troops raided and took over the premises of universities, hospitals and other public buildings, including Mandalay Technological University (MTU), Mandalay General Hospital, Yadanarbon University, Mandalay Central railway station, and other major government facilities including government offices and the local power authority. At least MTU was used as a military outpost. Military troops were reportedly also seen at a Buddhist temple.

On 7 March 2021, in Yangon City (Yangon Region), military troops occupied Yangon General Hospital, Gandhi Hospital, Waibargi Specialist Hospital to use as bases. This was part of a coordinated deployment by military troops to occupy hospitals and other public buildings across Myanmar on the same day.

Other: Around 7 March 2021 (as reported), in Myitkyina town (Myitkyina Township, Myitkyina District, Kachin State), the Myanmar military and police approached the Myitkyina general hospital with 12 trucks including a prisoner transport truck. The military and police entered into the Hospital Administrator's office.

Around 7 March 2021 (as reported), Magway town (Magway Township, Magway District, Magway Region), the Myanmar military started using Magway University, Magway Technological University, Magway Computer University, Magway Hospital and medical training schools as military outposts.
On 7 March 2021, in Ye town (Ye Township, Mawlamyine District, Mon State), the Myanmar military and police started using the Ye Public Hospital as an outpost.
On 7 March 2021, in Kyaukse Township (Kyaukse District, Mandalay Region), the Myanmar military and police used Tawma University as their outpost.
On 7 March 2021, in Taw Ma village (Sintgaing Township, Kyaukse District, Mandalay Region), the Myanmar military occupied Kyaukse University located in Taw Ma village as their military base.
On 7 March 2021, in Meiktila town (Meiktila Township, Meiktila District, Mandalay Region), the Myanmar military occupied a university, hospital and monastery as their base camps.

On 7 March 2021, in Monywa township (Monywa District, Sagaing Region), police and military troops occupied Monywa University and Monywa University of Economics to set up a base. This was part of a coordinated deployment by military troops to occupy hospitals and other public buildings across Myanmar on the same day.
On 7 March 2021, in Puta-O town (Puta-O Township, Puta-O District, Kachin State), the Myanmar military occupied a university, hospital and monastery as their base camps.

Other: On 7 March 2021, in Gwa town, Gwa township (Thandwe District, Rakhine State), military troops attempted to occupy the main public hospital but were succesfully prevented by the superintendent of the township. This was part of a coordinated deployment by military troops to occupy hospitals and other public buildings across Myanmar on the same day.
On 7 March 2021, in Gwa town (Gwa Township, Thandwe District, Rakhine State), the Myanmar military occupied Gwa Public Hospital as their base camp.
On 7 March 2021, in South Okkalapa township (Yangon (East) District, Yangon Region), the Myanmar military occupied the Women and Children's hospital as their base camp.
On 7 March 2021, in Tedim town (Tedim Township, Falam District, Chin State), the Myanmar military occupied the Tedim Public Hospital as their base camp.
On 7 March 2021, in Falam town (Falam Township, Falam District, Chin State), the Myanmar military occupied the Falam Public Hospital as their base camp.
On 7 March 2021, in Yenangyaung town (Yenangyaung Township, Magway District, Magway Region), the Myanmar military occupied the Yenangyaung University as their base camp.

On 7 March 2021, in Hakha city (Hakha Township, Hakha District, Chin State), the Myanmar military occupied the Hakha University as their base camp. Locals locked the university entrance gate with keys in response to the military occupation of the university.

On 7 March 2021, in Lashio town, Lashio township (Lashio District, Shan State), military troops occupied the Lashio General Hospital. This was part of a coordinated deployment by military troops to set up bases in hospitals and other public buildings across Myanmar on the same day.

ACTOR1: PSLF/TNLA: Palaung State Liberation Front/Ta'ang National Liberation Army
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 7 March 2021, in Maw Han village (Kutkai Township, Muse District, Shan State), nearly 300 TNLD soldiers arrived and entered the village. They had reportedly arrived to provide security for protesters who were protesting in the township against the Myanmar military coup.

Security measures: On 7 March 2021, in South Okkalapa township (Yangon (east) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police one-sidedly fired shots around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Security measures: On 7 March 2021, in Hlaing township (Yangon (west) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police one-sidedly fired shots around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Security measures: On 7 March 2021, in Mayangone township (Yangon (west) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police one-sidedly fired shots around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Security measures: On 7 March 2021, in Thingangyun township (Yangon (east) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police one-sidedly fired shots around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Security measures: On 7 March 2021, in Yankin township (Yangon (east) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police one-sidedly fired shots around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Security measures: On 7 March 2021, in Dawbon township (Yangon (east) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police one-sidedly fired shots around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Security measures: On 7 March 2021, in Shwepyithar township (Yangon (north) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police one-sidedly fired shots around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Arrests: On 7 March 2021, near Thantlang town (Thantlang Township, Hakha District, Chin State), five striking police officers and two other individuals were arrested at a checkpoint (assumed to be by police forces). It was reported that the striking officers had been searching for safer places to go into hiding after joining the civil disobedience movement against the military coup.
On 8 March 2021, in Muse town (Muse Township, Muse District, Shan State), the Myanmar military occupied the Muse Public Hospital as their base camp.
On 8 March 2021, in Pakokku town (Pakokku township, Pakokku District, Magway region), the Myanmar military occupied the Pakokku University as their base camp.
On 8 March 2021, in Pazundaung township (Yangon (East) District, Yangon Region), the Myanmar military destroyed at least 19 private cars parked on the road.
Arrests: On 8 March 2021, in Mahaaungmyay township (Mandalay District, Mandalay Region), police raided an NLD office and smashed the glass windows and CCTV cameras and arrested one party member.

Arrests: On 8 March 2021, in Taunggyi town (Taunggyi Township, Taunggyi District, Shan State), a journalist was arrested by security forces (assumed to be police). He was later released on the same day.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 8 March 2021, in Dawei Township (Dawei District, Tanintharyi Region), armed KNU soldiers from Brigade 4 were deployed to provide security for demonstrators who held a protest march against the military coup.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Other: On 8 March 2021, the military's State Administration Council revoked the operating license of five independent domestic news outlets, including Mizzima, DVB, Myanmar Now, Khit Thit Media, and 7Day News from publishing and broadcasting, or disseminating messages through social media. Following this, security forces raided the offices of Mizzima and Myanmar Now, and confiscated computers and office equipment from the Myanmar Now office. One of the news outlets had since issued a statement to condemn the military's actions, stating that it was aimed at prohibiting the public's right to information and freedom of expression. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: NLD: National League for Democracy; Government of Myanmar (2016-)
NOTES: Arrests: Around 8 March 2021 (as reported), three members of NLD - two of whom were members of Parliament - were imprisoned and faced prosecution under article 505 (a) of the penal code in Nay Pyi Taw.

On 9 March 2021, in Nay Pyi Taw, six people with civilian clothes - believed to be the Myanmar military or police - detained two Ministerial Assistant Director of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs over a leaked document about an emergency meeting between the Myanmar military and the Chinese Government.

ACTOR1: KNU/KNLA: Karen National Union/Karen National Liberation Army
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 9 March 2021, in Kawkareik town, Kawkareik Township (Kawkareik District, Kayin State), the KNLA and Karen National Police Force (under the KNU) were deployed to provide security for demonstrators who held a protest march against the military coup.

On 9 March 2021, between 35 and 36 streets in Mahaaungmyay township (Mandalay District, Mandalay Region), the Myanmar security forces raided an NLD office and arrested an NLD General Secretary for Mandalay District along with NLD Finance Officer for Mahaaungmyay Township and an NLD Executive Member for Mahaaungmyay Township.

Looting: On 9 March 2021, in Shwepyithar (Shwepyithar Township, Yangon-north District, Yangon Region), the Myanmar military raided a vocational school and forcefully looted phones, laptops and motorcycles from the school.

On 9 March 2021, in Launglon Township (Dawei District, Tanintharyi Region), the Myanmar military occupied Launglon Township Hospital, Myanma Economic Bank, Agriculture Bank and Region Court as their base camps.

On 9 March 2021, in Dawei town (Dawei Township, Dawei District, Tanintharyi Region), the Myanmar military occupies several public spaces including a Chinese Temple, Oktagyi Abhidhamma Propagation Office, Aung Mingala Cinema, Dawei Public Hospital, Dawei Computer University, Dawei Technological University and Dawei University as their base camps. The military fired gunshots as the locals opposed their base establishments.

Arrests: On 9 March 2021, in Maubin town (Maubin Township, Maubin District, Ayeyarwady Region), the Myanmar military and police searched for leaders of six social workers' organization and arrested two leaders. The incident came after some social workers issued a statement declining to provide social services to the military, family members and their associates.

Arrests: On 9 March 2021, in Lanmadaw township (Yangon-West District, Yangon Region), at 1am, military soldiers raided homes and arrested at least 25 male residents. It was reported that residents in the township stopped a car of strangers who were attempting to enter a neighbourhood during the nightly curfew in the evening of 8 March. Residents reportedly found weapons in the car and claimed that they were military personnel before releasing them. Residents claimed that the soldiers who arrived and raided the homes in the early morning were the soldiers who had been captured in the car.

Arrests: On 9 March 2021, in Bago town, Bago township (Bago district, Bago Region), a former NLD member who was the leader of the security team of the State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi was arrested by military soldiers from his place of residence. It was reported that there were no charges against the NLD member. There were some reports on social media that he had died in military custody, but this has yet been verified by his family or other official sources.

Arrests: On 9 March 2021, in Hakha town (Hakha Township, Hakha District, Chin State), military soldiers raided the office of a local NGO called Chin Center for Peace & Reconciliation and arrested security guards who were on duty. They also raided a private clinic and arrested a doctor who was allegedly providing medical treatment to injured protesters.
Security measures: On 9 March 2021, in Kyaukkyi Township (Bago Region), the Myanmar military fired gunshots. The reason for gunshots is not reported.

Arrests: On 9 March 2021, in Kamayut township (Yangon-West District, Yangon Region), security forces including police and military raided the office of independent news outlet Kamayut Media and arrested the co-founder and editor-in chief. The arrest came after the military's State Administration Council had announced on 8 March that the publishing licenses of five other independent media outlets were revoked.

On 10 March 2021, in Mingalar Taung Nyunt township (Yangon (East) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police raided Ma Hlwa Gone Railway Office and arrested staff who joined the civil disobedience movement. Around 1,500 military troops and police surrounded and blocked all entrances and exits at residences of government railway staff. It was reported that security forces conducted raids, forcing residents - striking railway staff and their family members - to leave the area.

Arrests: On 10 March 2021, in Myitkyina town, Myitkyina township (Myitkyina district, Kachin State), police raided a carpentry workshop and arrested the owner's wife and brother and six workers. The workshop was targeted as authorities believed that they were manufacturing shields used by protesters against the military coup.

On 10 March 2021, in Minhla town (Minhla Township, Thayarwaddy District, Bago Division), the Myanmar military and police arrested the head of a government school at her house for her involement in the civil disobedience movement.

Arrests: On 10 March 2021, in Thantlang town (Thantlang Township, Hakha District, Chin State), a man was arrested by riot police and armed soldiers and taken to a military base. The exact reason for his arrest was not confirmed, but security forces claimed that they had questions to ask the detainee.

Arrests: On 10 March 2021, in Matupi town (Matupi Township, Mindat District, Chin State), at least four individuals - including a government staff and a Christian pastor - was arrested at night by police and armed soldiers. The reason for their arrests was not reported.

Property destruction: Around 11 March 2021 (as reported), in Nyaungdon town (Nyaungdon Township, Maubin District, Ayeyarwady Region), an unknown assailant set a judge's car on fire. The Myanmar military with two cars recently drove around the town for security measurement.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
ACTOR2: ULA/AA: United League of Arakan/Arakan Army
NOTES: On 11 March 2021, the military's State Administration Council announced that the designation of Arakan Army as a terrorist group has been withdrawn. The Arakan Army was first declared as a terrorist group on 23 March 2020. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Property destruction: On 11 March 2021, in Mahaaungmyay township (Mandalay District, Mandalay Region), at night, more than 100 military and police forces raided one of the wards and caused damages to more than 30 houses by firing slingshots and rubber bullets. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Displacement: On 11 March 2021, in Shi Ku Hsu village located along the road between Myitkyina and Lai Zar town (Myitkyina Township, Myitkyina District, Kachin State), a military officer told villagers that there could be an armed clash in the area and told them to flee. Villagers fled as the result. Later, the same officer asked villagers to return to their village. However, the villagers didn't return. Location coded as Myitkyina.

On 11 March 2021, in Kengtung town (Kengtung District, Shan State), the deputy director at Kengtung Township Development Department was arrested by military and police forces for writing anti-coup poem on his Facebook page. He was charged under Section 505(a) of the Penal Code and later sentenced to 3 years imprisonment on 5 November.

On 12 March 2021, in Pathein town (Pathein township, Pathein District, Ayeyarwady region), a medical medical superintendent of Pathein Hospital was arrested by the police for allegedly refusing to reopen the hospital. His family members stated that he remained uncontactable as of the evening in 12 March.
Arrests: On 12 March 2021, in Hlaing township (Yangon (North) District, Yangon Region), the Myanmar security forces arrested a female member of Parliament.

Arrests: On 12 March 2021, in Hlaingthayar township (Yangon (North) District, Yangon Region), military and police forces raided a three-storey dormitory and arrested 24 people. Security forces reportedly fired either rubber bullets or live rounds on the street. Security forces also confiscated more than 50 mobile phones from a shop. The shop owner and his wife were also arrested.

On 13 March 2021, in Hakha town (Hakha Township, Hakha District, Chin State), military soldiers occupied the staff quarters of the Hakha General Hospital. Some buildings were also used for storing weapons.

Security measures: On 13 March 2021, in Myitkyina city (Myitkyina Township, Myitkyina District, Kachin State), the Myanmar military raided a Christian College. They gathered students and staff in one place and asked them their names and took note of their names. They also searched the school buildings.

Arrests: On 13 March 2021, in Nyaungdon town (Nyaungdon Township, Maubin District, Ayeyarwady Region), the Myanmar military and police raided a civilian house and arrested one civilian for allegedly creating a protective shield for protesters. The security forces also fired sound grenade in the ward to threaten residents.

Property destruction: On 14 March 2021, in Shwepyithar township (Yangon (North) District, Yangon Region), a garment factory was reportedly set on fire but it was not confirmed who were the perpetrators. The incident took place on the same day as fire broke out at several factories around Yangon, including many that were owned by Chinese nationals. This happened amid rising anti-Chinese sentiments in Myanmar, leading to claims that Chinese-funded factories may have been targeted. The Chinese government has since issued a statement condemning the attacks against its factories and called on Myanmar to protect its properties and citizens.

Property destruction: On 14 March 2021, in Insein township (Yangon (North) District, Yangon Region), a garment factory was reportedly set on fire but it was not confirmed who were the perpetrators. The incident took place on the same day as fire broke out at several factories around Yangon, including many that were owned by Chinese nationals. This happened amid rising anti-Chinese sentiments in Myanmar, leading to claims that Chinese-funded factories may have been targeted. The Chinese government has since issued a statement condemning the attacks against its factories and called on Myanmar to protect its properties and citizens.

Displacement: Around 14 March 2021 (as reported), RCSS reported that nearly 100 people have fled into and sought refuge in territory controlled by the RCSS, including civil servants and Anti-coup protesters. Location coded as Loilen district, Shan state.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Security measures: On 14 March 2021, the military's State Administration Council declared martial law in two townships in Yangon Region, Hlaingthayar and Shwepyithar. On 15 March, this was further expanded to include four more townships in Yangon Region (Dagon Myothit (Seikkan), North Dagon, North Okkalapa, and South Dagon), as well as five townships in Mandalay Region (Aungmyethazan, Chanayethazan, Chanmyathan, Mahaaungmyay, and Pyigyidagun). Under the martial law, the military can deploy security forces in response to incidents that are deemed to undermine security and the rule of law. Location changed as Nay Pyi Taw.
On 14 March 2021, locals selling books to raise funds for the civil disobedience movement were arrested by the security forces in Mandalay city (Mandalay region).
On 14 March 2021, in Mandalay city (Mandalay region), the Myanmar security forces (assumed to be the military and police) arrested a journalist while he was reporting on a strike.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Assistance Association for Political Prisoners; Myanmar Now
NOTES: Displacement: Around 15 March 2021 (as reported), in Chin State (coded as Hakha), about 400 people have reportedly fled across the border into Mizoram State in India since end February. A total of 198 police officers and their families were amongst those who fled, as they refused to serve under the military junta in Myanmar. It was reported that 116 people fled across the border on 12 March 2021.

On 15 March 2021, in Singu Township and also reportedly in Thabeikkyin township (Pyin Oo Lwin District, Mandalay Region), the Myanmar military went to villages where they had fired at civilians earlier on the same day and established base camps.

Displacement: On 15 March 2021, more than 200 villagers from Gway Htaw, Tan Baung Yan, Sa Ni Tu Yan and Au Sham Zwut fled to Tang Hpre village in Myitkyina Township (Myitkyina District, Kachin State) due to a renewed clashes between the Myanmar military and KIA around the Gway Htaw village in Myit Son area.

SOURCE: Myanmar Labour News; Democratic Voice of Burma
NOTES: Displacement: On 16 March 2021, in Hlaingthayar township (Yangon (North) district, Yangon region), tens of thousands of internal migrant families fled Hlaingthayar following the declaration of martial law in the township.

Arrests: On 16 March 2021, in Kamayut township (Yangon-West District, Yangon Region), security forces (assumed to be police) entered a branch office of a private bank and arrested four bank customers. State media MRTV claimed that the four people, including three women, were detained for condemning the bank's resumption of operation and allegedly inciting people to join the civil disobedience movement. Videos recorded by other customers however indicated that they were complaining to bank staff for not handling their demands properly. Family members stated that they had reached out to the police station but their whereabouts were not known as of 17 March 2021.

Arrests: On 16 March 2021, in Hlaingthayar township (Yangon (North) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military entered Ba Htoo Road near Phyo Bridge and Tama Gone. 9 people were arrested in two locations.
Security measures: On 16 March 2021, in Hlaingthayar township (Yangon (North) district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military opened fire near the BOC bus stop.

Property destruction: On 16 March 2021, in Mingalar Taung Nyunt township (Yangon (East) District, Yangon Region), about 30 military soldiers and police officers raided the office of a member of the Committee Representing Pyidaungsu Hluttaw (made up of lawmakers ousted by the military coup). They smashed the windows and damaged office properties. It was not clear if any items had been taken away by security forces.

Arrests: On 16 March 2021, in Dawbon township (Yangon-East District, Yangon Region), the Myanmar military and police searched NLD members houses and arrested some of them. The number of arrests was not reported.

Property destruction: On 16 March 2021, at Maungtaing ward-2 in Taungdwingyi town, Taungdwingyi township (Taungdwingyi District, Magway Region), the Myanmar military and police raided a house and destroyed it. They also looted some materials they took from a house along with more than 500,000 Myanmar kyats.
Security measures: On 16 March 2021, in Mayangone township (Yangon-west district, Yangon region), the Myanmar military fired about 40 rounds of sound grenade at the Bayintnaung intersection.

Arrests: On 16 March 2021, in Taunggyi town (Taunggyi Township, Taunggyi District, Shan State), the Myanmar military arrested Heart Rock Cafe owner at night. It is not clear why he was arrested but it is likely connected to the Anti-coup movement.

Movement of forces: On 16 March 2021, in Mong Yaw village tract, Lashio township (coded as Lashio), Lashio District, Shan State, over 300 soldiers from Northern Alliance arrived in the village. Myanmar military also sent more soldiers into the area.

Displacement: Around 16 March 2021 (as reported), in Hpapun township (Hpapun District, Kayin State), about 800 villagers from two villages fled their villages after the Myanmar military fired artillery shells into the villages and burned rice fields.

Security measures: Around 16 March 2021 (month of), in Gangaw township (Gangaw district, Magway Region), military troops began raiding homes in the area, allegedly searching for weapons and any tools that could be used to resist the military forces. Residents reported that soldiers also stole money, mobile phones and jewellery from their homes.
Non-violent activity: On 17 March 2021, in Sagaing town (Sagaing region), locals held a people-less protest against the Myanmar military coup and in support of the civil disobedience movement.

Other: On 17 March 2021, the Committee Representing Pyidaungsu Hluttaw issued a statement declaring that all ethnic armed organizations have been removed from the list of terrorist groups or unlawful associations. Location coded as Nay Pyi Taw.

Security measures: On 17 March 2021, in Yangon city (Yangon region), Myanmar military and police raided different townships across Yangon and set barricades made by civilians on fire. Security forces also fired gunshots while destroying the barricades. It was reported that security forces had been forcing residents to remove barricades.

Arrests: On 17 March 2021, in Pathein town (Pathein township, Pathein District, Ayeyarwady region), military and police forces stormed a ward. A family was carrying sand bags used for building their house but security forces believed that the sandbags were meant for building barricades for security purposes in the neighbourhood. Security fired five rubber bullets and took away an 11-year-old boy.

Arrests: On 17 March 2021, in Mayangone township (Yangon-West District, Yangon Region), security forces (assumed to be military and police) forcibly arrested male residents in the area who were then made to work for hours to remove sandbags and barricades set up by residents on the streets.

Arrests: On 17 March 2021, in Yankin township (Yangon-East District, Yangon Region), military forcibly arrested male residents in the area who were made to work for hours to remove sandbags and barricades set up by residents on the streets.

Movement of forces: On 17 March 2021, in Moe Bye village, Pekon township, Taunggyi District, Shan State, 200 soldiers arrived and entered Falai and Lehton villages. Troops were reportedly stationed at a church in Falai village and at a school in Lehton village. It was not clear why the military was staying in their villages.

Security measures: Around 17 March 2021 (between 15 March - 19 March) in Pekon township (Taunggyi District, Shan State), about 200 Myanmar military soldiers were deployed in Lelhton village after the killing of four soldiers by an unknown armed group on 15 March.

Arrests: On 17 March 2021, in Kamayut township (Yangon-West District, Yangon Region), at least 20 men were arrested by police and made to work for hours to remove sandbags and barricades set up by residents on the streets.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Refugees/IDPs (Myanmar); Government of Myanmar (2016-); Military Forces of Myanmar (2021-); Police Forces of Myanmar (2021-); Health Workers (Myanmar)
NOTES: Displacement: Around 18 March 2021 (as reported), KNU stated that almost a thousand people were sheltering inside KNU-controlled territory, having fled towns and cities following the Myanmar military coup. KNU claimed that these included people who have led or were involved in the civil disobedience movement, government staff, police and military personnel who have defected, doctors and members of parliament. Location coded as Hpapun.

Property destruction: On 18 March 2021, in a village in Tabayin township (Township, Shwebo District, Sagaing Region), about 50 Myanmar military with 6 military truck entered the villagers following a riot between villagers and police. The military fired about 50 rounds of gunshots and destroyed some shops and cars. The military fired at houses and challenged the villagers 'if you dare, come out'. There were no civilian casualties. However, they arrested six villagers and looted rice bags.

Looting: Around 18 March 2021 (as reported), in Insein township (Yangon-North district, Yangon Region), the Myanmar military and police searched houses at night and looted civilians' properties on 'several nights'. Afterwards, several residents in the township left and went back to their birth towns.

Weapons seizure: Around 18 March 2021 (as reported), in Mawlamyine city (Mawlamyine Township, Mawlamyine District, Mon State), the Myanmar military seized two MM-107 artillery shells and claimed that an unknown armed group attempted to attack the Myanmar military Southeast Command base located at Shwe Nat mountain in the Mawlamyine city.

Looting: On 18 March 2021, in Twantay township (Yangon (South) District, Yangon Region), military and police forces raided at least six villages and looted personal belongings worth nearly 20 million kyat. They reportedly stole cash, gold and jewellery, cameras and food at gunpoint. They fired either rubber bullets or live rounds and broke open doors, reportedly targeting activists and those who were believed to be financially supporting the protests against the military coup.

Arrests: On 18 March 2021, in Mee Thway Chaung village tract (coded as Maubin), Maubin township (Maubin district, Ayeyarwady Region), security forces (coded as military and police forces) arrested nine villagers - including eight men and one woman (reportedly NLD members and supporters). It was reported that USDP members in the villages had been providing information to the military.

Property destruction: On 18 March 2021, in Thingangyun township (Yangon (east) district, Yangon region), the security forces (assumed to be the Myanmar military and police) hit and destroyed about 30 car parked along the Ngamoe Yeik road.

Security measures: On 18 March 2021, in Dawbon township (Yangon-East District, Yangon Region), the security forces (assumed to be the Myanmar military and police) one-sidedly fired around the neighbourhood at night. This was part of the intensified raids of residential areas conducted at night by security forces.

Looting: On 18 March 2021, in Zee Hpyu Kone village (Twantay Township, Yangon-south District, Yangon region), the Myanmar military and police entered to the village and searched houses. They looted some villagers' belongings.

Displacement: Around 18 March 2021 (between 17 March - 19 March), in Pekon Township (Taunggyi District, Shan State), more than 1,500 villagers fled after the Myanmar military vowed to retribute the death of four soldiers on 15 March.
Security measures: On 18 March 2021, in Ahlone township (Yangon-West district, Yangon Region), military and police forces raided the Academy Hospital and searched its patient wards.

Arrests: On 18 March 2021, in Yangon city (Yangon region), the Myanmar security forces (assumed to be the Military and police) arrested the NLD Central Information Committee leader along with an NLD youth.

Property destruction: On 18 March 2021, in Hlaingthayar township (Yangon (North) District, Yangon Region), military and police forces came to clear barricades that were set up by residents for self-defence purposes. They also searched houses near the Bayint Naung intersection. Security forces reportedly used stun grenades and fired live ammunition, breaking glasses and causing damages to apartments, including bullet holes. Arrests were reported, but the exact number was not confirmed. It was reported that this was part of an operation to demand residents in different areas of Yangon to remove barricades that had been set up within neighbourhoods for self-defence purposes.

Security measures: On 19 March 2021, in Hlaingthayar township (Yangon (North) District, Yangon Region), military forces were reportedly firing either rubber bullets or live rounds near Thama Kone. The reason was not reported.

On 19 March 2021, in Yangon city (Yangon Region), two Australians were detained by military forces after they were prevented from boarding a relief flight out of Yangon. They both ran a business consultancy firm and worked as agriculture development consultants, and were allegedly friends with another detained Australian (previously the Economic Advisor to the Myanmar's ousted civilian government). They had since been placed under house arrest.
Arrests: On 19 March 2021, in Nay Pyi Taw, the Myanmar security forces (assumed to be the Military and police) arrested a BBC journalist and Mizzima journalist.

Movement of forces: On 19 March 2021, in Tha Pyay Kone village (Tabayin township, Shwebo District, Sagaing Region), around 180 soldiers arrived and stationed themselves at a monastery and a primary school. This followed after a deadly incident between villagers and police officers the day before, which resulted in two police officers killed and one injured. Villagers from four other nearby villages in the township also fled out of fear that they could be targeted.

Property destruction: On 19 March 2021, in Tamwe township (Yangon-east district, Yangon region), unknown assailants shot a firebomb inside the M-21 Sports Collection Store. The store building and some nearby buildings were set on fire. Residents claimed that the store was set on fire after residents refused to act on security forces' demand to remove barricades in the township.

Arrests: On 19 March 2021, in Tachileik town (Tachileik Township, Tachileik District, Shan State), six protest leaders who had participated in demonstrations against the military coup were arrested by military forces in their homes.
On 19 March 2021, in Bhamo town (Bhamo Township, Bhamo District, Kachin State), a freelance journalist associated with Mizzima was arrested by police.

Displacement: Around 19 March 2021, (between 18-21 March), in Tabayin township (Shwebo District, Sagaing Region), the Myanmar military threatened villagers that they will retribute for the killing of two police officers by villagers on 23 March near Tee Taw in Tabayin township. Hundreds of military also occupied the surrounding areas after the incident. Fearing threat from the Myanmar military, thousands of villagers from Tee Taw, Ohn Si, Chaung Mee, Tha Pay Kone and Tha Yet Kan fled their villages.

Property destruction: On 20 March 2021, at Kyauk Myaung Myothit in Tamwe township (Yangon region), security forces (assumed to be the Myanmar military and police) hit and destroyed several cars parked along the road with a bulldozer. The VOA reported 'more than 40' and the Eleven Media Group reported about 80 cars were destroyed.
