On 7 December 2021, in Tamwe township (Yango-East district, Yangon region), the military arrested 10 locals for participating in pot-banging protest against the Myanmar military.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: NLD: National League for Democracy; Government of Myanmar (2016-)
NOTES: Land seizure: On 7 December 2021, in Okpho township (Thayarwady district, Bago-West), the military troops raided and cordoned off the houses of two NLD's Regional Members of Parliaments.
On 7 December 2021, in Pa Dan village of Ngape township (Magway region), the military arrested two men at the security check point.
On 7 December 2021, in Hpruso town (Hpruso township, Loikaw district, Kayah State), the military arrested local youths on suspicion of having connection with the PDF.

Looting: On 7 December 2021, in Let Wea village of Natogyi township (Myingyan district, Mandalay), the military raided the village and looted gold, a motorbike and 20 million kyat from one house, a scoopy each from two other houses, rice packs and oil boxes from some other houses.
On 7 December 2021, in Demoso town (Demoso township, Loikaw district, Kayah State), the military arrested local youths on suspicion of having connection with the PDF.

On 7 December 2021, in South Okkalapa township (Yangon-east, Yangon), the military troops raided the 'Min Clinic' between Poonami and Post Office on Thitsar Road and arrested the nurses. The reason for the arrest is still unknown.

On 7 December 2021, in Kawthoung town of Kawthoung township (Kawthoung district, Tanintharyi region), the military arrested a teacher participating in the civil disobedience movement (CDM) and her husband in Padauk Shwe Wah ward.

On 7 December 2021, in Mahaaungmyay township (Mandalay district, Mandalay region), Myanmar military and police forces arrested 11 civilians after residents held pot-banging protest in response to the mass killing of civilians in Sagaing Region earlier the same day.

Property destruction: On 7 December 2021, in Kamaryut township (Yangon-West district, Yangon region), the military destroyed the door windows and windshields of over 30 cars in Yadanar street as residents participated in pot-banding protests against the Myanmar military. They also fired shots into the air and slingshots at residents' apartments, breaking their windows.

On 7 December 2021, in Kan Kone village (Tabayin township, Shwebo district, Sagaing), the military marching along the Pathein-Monywa road arrested about five workers from the Everwin Beer Shop. The reason for the arrest is still unknown.
Displacement: Around 7 December 2021, in Tar Tee village (Hsipaw township, Kyaukme district, Shan-north), more than 200 villagers have fled their village due to fears of possible fighting.

Displacement: On 8 December 2021, in Na Gar Twin village, Tabayin township (Shwebo district, Sagaing region), the entire village fled their homes in fear of the Myanmar military forces who had arrived and stayed overnight in the village.

Property destruction: On 8 December 2021, in Chaung Tet village of Chauk township (Magway district, Magway region), unknown group of people cut the cables off of MPT, Telenor and Ooredoo telecom tower. This followed the announcement of increasing the price of mobile data by the military.

On 8 December 2021, Mahaaungmyay township (Mandalay district, Mandalay region) Myanmar military forces claimed arrest of four people who were allegedly involved in arms dealing between PDF-Myaung, PDF-Madaya, and PDF-Amarapura. Multiple firearms, ammunition, and explosive devices were also seized at 38-90 Street in Sein Pan East Ward in Mahaaungmyay.

Weapons seizure: On 8 December 2021, in Khu Lel village, Singu township (Pyinoolwin district, Mandalay region), Myanmar military forces seized weapons, including firearms, 60 magazines, 7000 rounds of ammunitions, 97 hand grenades, 54 energas, 300 electric triggers, 15kg of gunpowder, and other accessories, inside Ma Ni Zaw Ti Monastery.

Property destruction: On 8 December 2021, in Aung Tha Pyay village, Ye township (Mawlamyine district, Mon State), Myanmar military troops burned down two houses in Aung Tha Pyay village. Villagers fled homes in fear of Myanmar military forces.
On 8 December 2021, in Kyaukpadaung town of Kyaukpadaung township (Nyaung-U district, Mandalay region), the military arrested two Yway Nout San villagers at the check point outside football stadium.
On 8 December 2021, in Danubyu town of Danubyu township (Maubin district, Ayeyarwady region), the military arrested two young women, accusing them of being PDF members.

On 8 December 2021, in Ye-U township (Shwebo district, Sagaing region), about 30 military troops raided the Aryu pharmacy and arrested a doctor, who is the daughter of the owner, participating in the civil disobedience movement and her husband.

Movement of forces: On 8 December 2021, in Tabayin township (Shwebo district, Sagaing region), Myanmar military transported around 150 reinforcement troops with helicopters in west of Tabayin town in order to control more territories.

Property destruction: On 8 December 2021, in Thantlang town (Hakha district, Chin State) the Myanmar military forces burned down 18 houses in Zon Mon Ward at around 2pm and another five houses in Phayarkyaung Ward at around 6:30 pm. The military forces have burned down over 500 houses in Thantlang since September.

Security measures: On 8 December 2021, in Kin Seik village, Mrauk-U township (Mrauk-U district, Rakhine State), around 50 military forces raided and ransacked houses in Kin Seik village for 3 hours for unknown reason.

Displacement: On 8 December 2021, in Mongkaing township (Loilen district, Shan-South state), about 1,000 villagers from four villages - Hpar Lan, Wan Paik, Wan Paik Na Mon and Kone Kham as fighting (between unreported armed groups) resumed near Ham Ngaing village tract.

SOURCE: Myanmar Now; Democratic Voice of Burma
NOTES: Displacement: On 9 December 2021, in Min Thar Kya village of Myaing township (coded as Min Thar Kya (South)) (Pakokku district, Magway region), the military raided and occupied the village, forcing about 1000 locals excluding 17 elder persons to flee.

SOURCE: Democratic Voice of Burma; Ministry of Defense - NUG
NOTES: On 9 December 2021, in Ka Nyon Kyun village of Launglon township (Dawei district, Tanintharyi region), about 40 military troops opened fire and raided the village on suspicion of harboring PDFs. They arrested at least 15 villagers and forced others - old and young - out of the house and forced them to sit under the sun.
Property destruction: On 9 December 2021, in Kanpetlet township (Mindat district, Chin State), Myanmar military forces burned and destroyed locals' farms for unknown reason.

Property destruction: On 9 December 2021, in Na Gar Twin village, Tabayin township (Shwebo district, Sagaing region), Myanmar military forces burned and destroyed residential house at around 4 pm for unknown reason.

Defusal: On 9 December 2021, in Aungmyaythazan township (Mandalay district, Mandalay region), the military defused two improvised mines - one near the house of a teacher who do not join the civil disobedience movement (CDM) and one near the Mandalay region parliament building.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Property destruction: On 9 December 2021, in Sin Ta Lel village of Ayadaw township (Monywa district, Sagaing region), the military led by the village administrator searched houses and destroyed the Mu bridge and two houses.

ACTOR1: Government of Myanmar (2021-) State Administration Council
NOTES: Security measures: On 9 December 2021, in Sagaing town of Sagaing township (Sagaing district, Sagaing region), the military administration restricted not to ride a motorbike more than one man.
On 9 December 2021, in Mogoke town of Mogoke township (Pyinoolwin district, Mandalay region), the military raided a house and arrested a young man.
On 9 December 2021, in Myit Thar village, Myingyan township (Myingyan district, Mandalay region) the military forces arrested a villager from Myit Thar for unknown reason.
On 9 December 2021, in Pin Zin village of Wetlet township (Shwebo district, Sagaing region), the military arrested a man, accusing him of being a PDF member and brought to the Wetlet police station.

Displacement: Around 9 December 2021 (as reported), in Yinmarbin township (Yinmarbin district, Sagaing region), over 5,000 locals from 8 villages including Bein Nwe Chaung, Hpaung Kar, Done Taw, Gone Taw, Than Kone and Kyay Sar Kya were forced to flee after military raids and killings in Done Taw.

On 9 December 2021, in Taunggyi town of Taunggyi township (Taunggyi district, Shan-South state), about 30 forces of the military and police arrived at a shop near Sao San Tun hospital and arrested about 20 young people.

Displacement: Around 9 December 2021, in Ham Ngaing village tract, Mongkaing township (Loilen district, Shan State), around 1,000 villagers were forced to flee homes due to continued clashed between local armed ethnic armed groups.

On 10 December 2021, in Mandalay city (Mandalay district, Mandalay region) an owner of Bus in Khitaya Bus State was arrested by the military forces for posting that he would not be running the bus in support of the nationwide silent strike against the military coup.

On 10 December 2021, in Taunggyi town (Taunggyi district, Shan State), Myanmar military forces arrested the owners of two department stores after they closed their shops in support of 'Silent Strike' protest against Myanmar military coup.

Defusal: In the week of January 21, 2010, a K58 mine bomb was discovered by cleaners in Paoy Paet (Ou Chrov, Banteay Meanchey). It is reported that the bomb was placed along with bags of rubbish by an unidentified man. The bomb was taken and destroyed by the Cambodian Mine Action Authority.
On February 10, 2010, 3 boys were seriously injured in Koas Krala (Battambang) when the mine they were playing with exploded.
On February 17, 2010, 3 Thais who are thought to be illegal loggers were injured in the border area in Choam Khsant (Preah Vihear) when they stepped on separate land mines.

Non-Violent Activity: On 4/3/2010, the Military of Cambodia fired 200 rockets at an airfield in Kampong Chhnang, 110 miles from the Thai border. The Cambodian government and military denied that this rare public test of rockets is a show of force but in light of the border tensions between Thailand and Cambodia this event has potential significance.

On March 9, 2010, a man was killed and his wife and daughter injured when a bomb exploded in Phnom Kravanh (Pursat). It is reported that the civilians were using the bomb to catch fish after it was found in a field.
Property destruction: On 18 March 2010, a group of villagers torched the office of the Phnom Penh Sugar Company in Om Laing (Thpong, Kampong Speu). This event follows an unspecified land dispute.
On March 21, 2010, 3 children in Koas Krala commune (Battambang) were seriously injured when bombs they found and were playing with exploded.
In the week of April 5, 2010, a boy was killed and another injured when a bomb they were playing with exploded in Kampot province.
On 1/5/2010, 5 plantation workers were killed and 9 injured by an explosion in Sala Krau (Pailin). The explosion occurred when they drove over an anti-tank mine.
In the week of May 4, 2010, a boy was injured when a bomb he was playing with exploded in Kampong Cham.
On May 14, 2010, a soldier based in Thma Puok (Banteay Meanchey) was seriously injured when he stepped on a land mine while searching for bamboo shoots.
On May 14, 2010, a villager from Svay Chek (Banteay Meanchey) was seriously injured when a land mine exploded while he was out hunting.
On May 17, 2010, 5 persons were injured when a man used an axe to hit a bomb until it detonated in Mongkol Borey (Banteay Meanchey).
On May 17, 2010, a woman was injured when she bit a bomb she found near her home in Steung Treng province.

Property destruction: On May 25, 2010, 50 police and Environment Department workers destroyed the homes of approximately 100 families in Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey) after an on-going land dispute. The police dismantled some homes and burnt others.

On 25 May 2010, a group of military police, provincial police and soldiers burned the houses of more than 100 villagers in O'Ampil village in Anlong Veng district (AV, OM) after the villagers refused to leave following an eviction notice.
On August 25, 2010, a boy was killed in Banan (Battambang) when a cow stepped on an anti-tank mine. The explosion killed the boy and two cows.

On August 29, 2010, 4 persons were killed and 3 others injured in a bomb explosion in Phnom Kravan (Pursat). It is reported that a man was using an unexploded bomb as a microphone and it exploded when he threw it and it hit a wooden floor.

On 29/8/2010, 4 civilians were killed, and 3 others injured when a leftover B-40 rocket launcher exploded in Rovieng (Phnom Kravanh, Pursat). It is reported that a villager was using the explosive as a pretend microphone when it fell and detonated.
On September 10, 2010, a man was killed in Veal Veang (Pursat) when a mine exploded while he was cutting tees.

On September 20, 2010, a soldier was killed and another injured when a grenade launcher exploded in Thma Puok, Banteay Meanchey. The explosion occurred after the soldiers accidentally placed a wooden pole on the grenade left from the 1980s.
On September 23, 2010, a soldier was injured when he stepped on a land mine along the Thai border in Anlong Veng (Oddar Meanchey).

On 30/9/2010, an explosion occurred in the Phnom Trop hill area in (Krong Pursat, Pursat). The Cambodian troops said a grenade was thrown on them by Thai troops. While Thai troops said that it was old ammunition that exploded. No injuries were reported.

On October 26, 2010, a man and his son were killed when a bomb exploded in their home in Rolea B'ier (Kampong Chhnang). It is reported that the man planned on recycling three bomb pieces when one detonated. A woman was seriously injured in the explosion.

On November 2, 2010, a man was killed and 3 others injured in Phnum Proek (Battambang) when an anti-tank mine exploded. A soldier was driving a tractor when it ran over the mine and caused it to explode.
On November 5, 2010, 3 men were injured when an anti-tank mine exploded in Battambang province. The men were riding in a trailer pulling corn when it drove over a mine which caused it to explode.

On 17/11/2010, 14 people were killed in Battambang when their tractor ran over an anti-tank mine. It is reported that the group of farmers were returning home from harvesting chilies when the land mine exploded.
On December 15, 2010, 4 children were seriously injured when a landmine exploded while they were playing with it in Phnum Proek (Battambang).
On 15/12/2010, 4 children were seriously wounded when a land mine exploded while they were playing in the forest close to their home in Chakrei commune (Phnom Proek, Battambang)
On 19/12/2010, 2 people were killed and 6 injured in Chheu Teal (Sampov Loun, Battambang) when a land mine exploded. A man was using an excavator to dig a hole when it triggered a mine.
On December 20, 2010, 2 persons were killed and 6 others injured when an anti-tank mine exploded in Sampov Loun district (Battambang). The explosion occurred after an excavator ran over the mine.
On December 29, 2010, a soldier was injured when he stepped on a landmine in Thma Da (Veal Veaeng, Pursat). The soldier was helping his wife find trees when he stepped on the mine.

On 18 January, two men were seriously injured when a B-40 rocket exploded at their home in Chakrei commune's Damnak Ksan village (Battambang province's Phnom Proek district). The men were attempting to break the rocket to make a large blade from the metal when the rocket detonated.
On 24 February, Cambodian soldiers fired three shots in the border area assumed in Kantuot commune, Preah Vihear province into Sisaket province (Thailand).
On 24 February, a man was seriously injured and his tractor destroyed by an UXO explosion, in Banteay Meanchey. Location coded: capital of the province.

On 24 February, two Thai soldiers were seriously injured after stepping on landmines while patrolling Phu Ma Khua (near Preah Vihear Temple) along the Cambodian border in Kantuot commune (Preah Vihear province, Cambodia).
On 28 February, a 14-year-old girl was severely injured and had one leg amputated after stepping on a landmine while walking through farmland in Samlot district, Battambang.
On 28 February, an anti-tank mine explosion injured one man while he was driving in his tractor in Samrong commune, Banteay Meanchey's O'Chruv district.
On 28 February, a man was severely injured after his tractor hit an anti-tank mine, in Phnom Proek district, Battambang.
On 05 March, a 51-year-old farmer was killed when an unexploded piece of ordnance was set off while he was ploughing his farmland in Malai district, Banteay Meanchey

On 06 March, a 52-year-old farmer was killed when he stepped on an anti-personnel mine, Samlout district, Battambang. The landmine exploded when he and his wife were clearing land in their corn and cassava fields.
During the week of 6-12 March, a 55-year-old man and his two sons were injured by a piece of unexploded ordnance while tilling their vegetable garden in Samlout commune, Samlout district, Battambang.

Property destruction: On 31 March 2011, about 200 armed military police and police descended upon Tuol Sangke commune's Tuol Kork village, in Phnom Penh. They demolished the homes of forty-two families, enforcing a Supreme Court ruling in favor of a former Funcinpec minister, who allegedly owned the land.
On 05 April, a 31-year-old man was killed when an old landmine exploded as he planted chili plants in Prek Phnov commune, Sen Sok district, Phnom Penh. Two other workers were injured.

On 11 April, a 12-year-old was injured after an unexploded ordinance detonated in Sompov Loun commune in Battambang province. The girl was hit by a rock after an excavator accidentally touched the UXO, exploding the landmine.

On 26 April, three farmers were killed and other three were injured when an anti-tank mine detonated in Trapaing Prasat district, Oddar Meanchey province. The accident occurred when the anti-tractor where the victims were riding ran over an old mine.
On 09 May, a 25-year-old man was seriously injured when an anti-tank mine exploded in Rotanak Mondul district, Battambang. The farmer was clearing land with a tractor when the device exploded.

On 14 May, three Cambodian deminers died by explosions of unexploded ordinances (UXOs) in Kompong Speu. The deminers were storing the UXOs at a warehouse before they are designed to be destroyed later. Location coded: capital of the province.

Four teenagers were slightly injured when a mine exploded, in Mong Russey district, Battambang. The teenagers had discovered the Khmer-Rouge era shell in a field and tried to burn it. Date coded: date of news article.

On 22 May, a 22-year-old man was severely injured when an UXO exploded, in Damrei Slap commune, Kampong Svay district, Kampong Thom. The man, who had spotted the UXO in a rice field while tending to his water buffalo, was tinkering with the device, assuming that it had previously detonated.
On 29 May, a tractor driver was seriously injured when he ran over an anti-tank mine in Slakram commune's Boeung Snou village, Svay Chek district, Banteay Meanchey.

On 13 June, a 29-year-old man was critically injured when a landmine exploded in Banteay Meanchey province. The man was looking for bamboo shoots in Boeung Tasrey village of Thma Pouk district's Kouk Romiet commune.
On 20 June, two men were seriously injured after hitting an unexploded ordinance, known as a DK75, at a construction site in Sre Or village in Odong district, Kampong Speu province.

On 20 June, one man died and another was injured when an unexploded ordinance detonated in Chbar Mon town, Kampong Speu province. The man had found two pieces of UXO at a construction site and had thrown one against a tree, causing it to detonate.
On 28 June, a 37-year-old man was killed when his tractor detonated an anti-tank mine, in O'Kondorl village in Santepheap commune, Sampov Loun district, Battambang.
On 02 July, a 22-year-old farmer was seriously injured when his tractor struck an unexploded ordnance while he ploughed a field in Kamrieng district, Battambang.

On 06 July, a 35-year-old tractor driver was seriously injured in an anti-tank mine explosion in Thma Puok district, in Banteay Meanchey. The farmer had ran over the mine with his tractor while clearing a plantation, injuring his arm and leg.
On 09 July, a teenager died when a mine exploded in Ratanak Mondol district in Battambang. The man ran over the mine in a tractor while ploughing a field for his boss.

On 08 August, a Thai soldier (identified as Nikorn Moonha) was killed after stepping on a land mine while on patrol near Ta Khwai Temple at the Thai-Cambodian border, near Surin's Phnom Dongrak District. Location coded: Ta Krabey temple, located near Ta Khwai temple.

On 10 August, five boys were injured, four of them seriously, after a 60-millimetre shell they had been playing with exploded near the Peam Chaing rubber plantation in Preah Theat commune, Tboung Khmum province. In the news article, location mentioned is in Kampong Cham province. However, in 2013 part of the province was split, creating Tboung Khmum province.

Movement of forces: On 20 August, Cambodian troops of Brigade No. 9, stationed at the foot of Chak Chreng area, near Preah Vihear temple, Kantuot commune, were pulled back to their barracks in Choam Khsant district of Preah Vihear province.
On 23 August, seven Cambodians were injured by an explosion of an anti-tank mine in a rubber plantation, in Slor Kram Commune, Svay Chek district in Banteay Meanchey province.
On 29 September, a teenage boy was killed and a young man was seriously wounded while playing with cluster bombs they found in a field while tending cattle in Dangkor district, Phnom Penh.
On 01 December, a driver and five farmer workers were injured in Veal Veng district, Pursat province when their truck drove over an anti-tank mine, exploding the device.
Property destruction: On 30 Dec 2011, about 300 armed soldiers and military police officials dismantled the homes of more than 100 families in Kantuot commune, in Choam Ksan district, Preah Vihear.

On 06 January, a deputy police chief was killed by a landmine while patrolling in a forest at the Cambodia-Thailand border, in Choam Ksan district, Preah Vihear. The official died instantly when he triggered a small mine with his hand while on patrol with soldiers.

On 03 February, eight Cambodian farmers were killed and one was seriously injured after their truck hit two old anti-tank mines, on an unmarked road in Ou Sampoar commune, Malai district, in Banteay Meanchey province.
On 19 February, a 49-year-old broke his right ankle after stepping on a landmine while he was searching for vegetables, in Thma Puok district, Banteay Meanchey province.
On 19 February, a 58-year-old man suffered minor injuries after stepping on a mine while he was hunting rabbits, in Thma Puok district, Banteay Meanchey province.
On 27 February, three men were injured after one of them stepped on a landmine in Samlot district, Battambang. The men had been clearing a forest to cultivate corn.

On 01 March, a warhead of a 60-mm shell exploded, injuring 20 children, at a school in Preah Vihear's Kulen district. One of the children had picked up an unexploded 60-mm shell from a field nearby and brought it to play in the classroom.

On 10 March, two boys were killed when a B-40 grenade exploded, in Kandorl commune, Botum Sakor district, Koh The boys had found the device, believed to be from the civil era period, and were playing with it, when it exploded.

On 17 March, five farmers were injured, three of them seriously, when a landmine exploded as they cooked rice in a field in Trapaing Ser village, Snuol district, Kratie province. Coordinates for the village not found.

On 31 March, two young boys were killed and a woman was seriously injured after an unexploded ordinance (UXO) exploded in Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey province. The boys had found the B40 rocket in the forest near their house and played with it.
On 25 April, a man was killed after his tractor drove over a buried anti-tank mine in a rice field in Tuol Pongro commune, Malai district, Banteay Meanchey province.

On 02 May, a Thai soldier was allegedly badly injured by a landmine device placed in the Thai-Cambodian border, near the area surrounding Preah Vihear temple. Thai military accused Cambodia of placing the devices along the border, but the Cambodian government stated the area still have landmines from the Khmer Rouge regime.

On 23 May, two farmers were seriously injured when a landmine exploded, in Paoy Paet town, Banteay Meanchey. The men had found the landmine in a rice field and allegedly played with it before it exploded.

On 07 July, a 37-year-old farmer from Oddar Meanchey and his two oxen were killed in an anti-tank mine explosion, when his cart rolled over a civil war-era landmine, in Tumnup Thmey village, Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey.

On 18 July 2012 , Cambodia and Thailand pulled hundreds of soldiers out of the disputed border area of Preah Vihear temple, in Kantuot commune, replacing them with police and security guards. The movement of troops happened one year after a ruling by the UN's highest court.

Around 31 July, a mass grave thought to contain the remains of hundreds of Khmer Rouge victims was uncovered in Kralanh district, Siem Reap province. The skeletal remains of at least 17 people were found.

On 03 August, one teenager died and three other children were injured when a Khmer-Rouge era rocket exploded in Phnom Sroch district, Kampong Speu province. The children had taken their cows to graze near Kraing Lahong village when they discovered the discarded B-40 rocket and started to throw stones at it.

Mass grave: on 6 Aug, a mass grave thought to contain the remains of hundreds of Khmer Rouge victims was uncovered in Du Dantry village, Kampong Thkov commune, Kralanh district, Siem Reap province. The skeletal remains of at least 20 people were found.
On 12 August, four farmers were injured when an unexploded ordinance detonated at a cassava plantation in Pir Thnu commune, in Kratie province.

On 30 August, a small homemade bomb exploded at a bridge on National Road 4 near Pich Nil, a traditional place of Buddhist prayer in Traeng Trayueng commune, Phnom Sruoch district, Kampong Speu. No one was injured in the explosion.
On 09 September, three boys died when an old B-40 rocket exploded as they tried to break it open, in Trapeang Prasat district, Oddar Meanchey province.

On 01 October, six farmers were killed and other two were seriously injured when their tractor ran over an anti-tank mine in Rotonak Mondul district, Battambang province. The landmine is believed to be from Cambodia's 1980s civil war.

On 07 October, three Cambodian farmers from the same family died after their truck hit an old anti-tank mine in Ta Sanh commune, Samlout district, Battambang. Other two relatives were seriously injured in the blast.

On 07 October, three Cambodian farmers from the same family died after their truck hit an old anti-tank mine in Battambang. Other two relatives were seriously injured in the blast. The landmine is believed to be from the civil war in the country.
On 14 January, a man had to have his leg amputated after stepping on a landmine, while setting traps in a forest in Thma Da commune, Veal Veng district, in Pursat.

On 15 January, four American demining experts got injured when an unexploded ordnance (UXO) exploded at a mine clearance training field in the Cambodian Mine Action Center (CMAC), in Kampong Chhnang province. Two of the experts were in critical condition.
On 30 January, a man had his leg amputated after stepping on a landmine while walking through a forest to chop wood, in Trapaing Chor commune, Oral district, in Kampong Speu.

Defusal: On 08 February, a team composed of provincial police and the Cambodian Mine Action Centre (CMAC) uncovered and destroyed a cache of mortars, rockets and anti-personnel landmines Sisophon town (called Serei Saophoan), in Banteay Meanchey province. The materials were found when a local farmer in O'Ambel commune in Sisophon was inspecting an irrigation canal. Officials believe they were buried by Khmer Rouge guerrillas during fighting in the 1990s.

On 13 February, a man was injured and taken to hospital after two anti-tank mines exploded while he was farming in Sampov Loun district, Battambang. The mines were believed to be remnants of the civil war period.
On 20 February, a police officer lost his right leg after stepping on a landmine while on border patrol in the jungle around Samlot district, in Battambang.
On 23 February, a woman was killed by a 60-mm explosive UXO while clearing grass at a rubber plantation in Kravanh village, Snoul district (Kratie province).

On 02 March, a seven-year-old girl lost her eye and was severely injured from the shards of a B40 rocket that exploded when she picked it up while scavenging, in Choam Ksan district, Preah Vihear province. The area was a battle zone during the civil war.
On 04 March, four people were injured after their tractor ran over a landmine, in Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey province.

ACTOR2: Military Forces of Thailand (2011-2014) Thai Rangers
NOTES: On 05 March, a 16-member ranger patrol Thai unit was inspecting areas around Ta Kwai temple (Prasat Ta Krabey in Khmer) in Surin's Phanom Dong Rak district in Thailand (contested area in Kouk Khpos, Banteay Ampil, Oddar Meanchey, Cambodia). Three rangers stepped on landmines, and one ranger's right leg was blown off. The landmines were found to be Vietnamese-made TMN1 mines, which are commonly used by the Cambodian military.

Property destruction: On 14 March 2013, security guards tore down the shelters of 12 families at the Borei Keila eviction site in Phnom Penh, while they were at the Court of Appeal supporting imprisoned Beehive radio director Mam Sonando. The guards were acting on behalf of the development firm Phan Imex, who owns the land.

On 15 March 2013, villagers in the Thai-Cambodia disputed border region around Preah Vihear temple claimed that both Thailand and Cambodia have been moving more troops and weapons to the border zone, starting mid-March. The countries have a case in the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on the ruling of the Preah Vihear Temple, in Kantuot, and its surrounding area.
On 24 April, a 18-year-old was killed when he drove his tractor over an anti-tank landmine while plowing farmland in Pailin's Sala Krao district.
On 01 May, a man lost an eye when a fire in front of his house set off a landmine in Bour commune, Battambang province.

On 01 May, one man was killed and two others seriously injured in a mine explosion in Takeo province's Tram Kak district. The three men were clearing forest to build a home when one stepped on the mine.

Property destruction: On 30 May 2013, about 50 police, soldiers and environmental officials demolished two houses and cut down thousands of trees belonging to families, in Thma Da commune, Veal Veng district, Pursat. The villagers are locked in a land dispute with MDS Import Export Co, owned by tycoon Try Pheap.

On 12 June, a deminer was killed near the Cambodian-Thai border, in Cham Yeam villag, Koh Kong, when a piece of unexploded ordnance (UXO), believed to be an anti-tank mine, went off during a demining operation. Two other people were injured.

On 17 July, three farmers suffered mild to serious injuries when a B40 rocket they dug up exploded, when they were picking rubber tree plants on a plantation, in Tbong Khmum district's Veal Vong village, Kampong Cham. Unable to find district or village. Location coded: capital of the province.
On 31 July, two children and a man were killed when their buffalo cart hit an anti-tank mine left over from the country's civil war, in Oddar Meanchey. Capital of the province coded as location.

On 07 August, a bomb exploded at the rear gate of the Phnom Penh Municipal Court, blackening the walls and leaving a small patch of broken pavement but resulting in no injuries. No suspects were identified.

Movement of forces: on 09 August, Cambodia military forces deployed armoured personnel carriers and soldiers to Phnom Penh, to prevent any violence if mass demonstrations following disputed polls go ahead.

On 14 August, a bomb exploded at the Cambodian People's Party headquarters in Kampong Speu province's Kang Pisey district, damaging a CPP signboard, a wall and some parts of the headquarters itself, but resulting in no injuries.

On 14 August, a landmine killed six people and injured one man after the group ran over it riding in a homemade tractor in Preah Vihear's Choam Ksan district. The area is a former Khmer Rouge territory.

A landmine blast tore both legs from a 19-year-old man as he searched for bamboo shoots in wooded area in Pailin province's Sala Krao district. No date mentioned for the event, coded date of the news article.

Defusal: On 13 September, a makeshift bomb was discovered near the Parliament, in Phnom Penh, and three M79 grenades were also found close to Freedom Park. The discovery of the bombs add to tensions in the capital, ahead of planned protests over Prime Minister Hun Sen's disputed election win. The devices were exploded by bomb experts.

On 27 October, two Cambodian soldiers sustained injuries after accidentally setting off a buried anti-personnel mine in Chheu Krom village near a military camp, in Pailin. The soldiers were clearing the grass in a cassava plantation.

On 19 November, two people were seriously injured and five others slightly injured when unexploded ordnance (UXO) detonated in Trapaing Prey commune, Anlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey province. The group of seven, workers in a rice field, had been enjoying lunch together when a man stepped on the landmine.

Defusal: on 13 January, 27 pieces of unexploded ordinance, believed to be from Lon Nol-era, were found near Sla village, in Voasar commune (Kampong Speu, Samrong Tong). Demining experts and district military police dug out and detonated the war remnants on the spot.

Property destruction: End of January/beginning of February, local authorities, soldiers and Tianjin Union Development company representatives demolished 42 homes in Ta Noun commune and two houses in Koh Sdech commune, to make way for large-scale ecotourism development.
On 30 January, three children died in Kampong Leng district (Kampong Chhnang province) when an unexploded rocket they found and handled blew up. The area is the site of a former Vietnamese barracks.

On 21 February, a girl and a boy were killed by a mortar round, left from the war time, in Bavel district, Battambang province. The victims scratched the ground near their village and found the shell, then they used rock to smash it, triggering the explosion.

On 26 March, two children and a woman were seriously injured when they stepped on a landmine in Svay Chek district, near a border patrol station in Banteay Meanchey. The woman lost her leg and the children were seriously injured.

On 28 March, a man died and another was injured when a 1970s anti-tank mine exploded when two men drove a mini-tractor over the explosive, which lay just 20cm to 30cm beneath a new road in Battambang's Rattanak Mondul district.
On 29 March, a 12-year-old boy was killed and another seriously injured when a rusty 60mm artillery shell he was playing with exploded, in Salakrov district (Pailin).

On 10 May, two Cambodian deminers were killed when an old anti-tank mine from the civil war they were trying to remove from the ground exploded, in Samlot commune (Battambang). The two deminers were employees of the British demining charity Halo Trust.

Displacement: Approximately 2,000 Chinese business people and tourists have crossed the Vietnamese border into Cambodia to escape anti-China riots in Vietnam. Location not mentioned, location coded as main border crossing point, Paoy Paet city.

Property destruction: In the month of May 2014, villagers homes were burned down during an eviction drive by the Vietnamese rubber firm Bin Pheurk, in Kratie's Snuol district, to make land for the Vietnamese rubber firm Bin Pheurk. Villagers claim more than 200 homes and over 2,000 hectares of crops were destroyed.

On 23 May, a war-left mortar round exploded, killing an old woman and seriously injuring five others in Kampong Svay (Kampong Thom province). A man was hitting a mortar shell with a hammer to remove saleable scrap-metal, when the device exploded.

Displacement: Between June 1 and June 18, thousands of Cambodian laborer's returned from Thailand across the different checkpoints, mainly the border town of Paoy Paet in Banteay Meanchey. The mass return of workers has been driven largely by Thailand's military, which had instructed private companies not to accept illegal immigrants after leading a coup in 22 May.
On 12 July, an anti-tank mine from the civil war exploded, injuring an agricultural worker in Kdol Tahen commune (Bavel, Battambang).

On 15 July, an old unexploded ordnance (UXO) blew up leaving at least eight people seriously injured, in Pursat's Veal Veng district. The device, found by a child, exploded when children where playing with at home.
On 31 July, three people were severely hurt when a tractor in Svay Chek district in Banteay Meanchey ran over a buried anti-tank mine in a former battlefield.
On 19 November, a man was seriously injured and lost his left leg when he stepped on an antipersonnel mine, in Chork Rokar village (Samlot district, Battambang).

Movement of forces: In December 2014 (no specific date mentioned), China reported that around 200 Thai soldiers had been deployed to the disputed area of An Ses/Chong Arn Mar (Choam Khsant district, Preah Vihear Province).

Movement of forces: on 29 December, Cambodia started to move soldiers and weapons to the Chong Arn Ma pass (An Ses border crossing, near Choam Khsant in Preah Vihear), while evacuating civilians from a local market. The movement started after Cambodian authorities moved in equipment to begin work on a development project in an area claimed by both countries. Thailand also boosted its military presence in the area.
Property destruction: Officials allegedly burned down cottages villagers had built on disputed land in Banteay Srei district.

Non-violent activity: A land dispute between Vietnamese soldiers and Cambodian civilians resulted in Vietnamese soldiers blocking about 500 Cambodians along with four members of the CNRP from accessing an area the Cambodians claimed was Cambodian territory.
A man was badly injured when a decades-old land mine exploded after he ran it over with a tiller. The detonation left him with injuries all over his body and destroyed the tiller.

Arrests: Local security forces arrested Senator Hong Sok Hour from the opposition party, accusing him of treason for posting a fake Vietnam-Cambodia border treaty on his Facebook page. The arrest was carried out under the order of the Prime Minister.
On August 26, 2015, a police officer was killed and another injured when an old rocket exploded along Oddar Meachey province's border with Thailand.
On October 18, 2015, a farmer was injured when an old bomb exploded near his home in Sala Krao district, Pailin province.
One villager was killed and two more injured when their tractor rolled over a land mine.
A woman was killed and three of her family members injured following the explosion of a decades-old grenade.
On March 3, 2016, a soldier was killed in Samlot district, Battambang province, after driving over an old anti-tank mine in a tractor.

On 23 May 2016, in Ba Phnom district's Boeung Preah commune, Prey Veng province, police shut down a gathering of 30 people in a private home, saying the event organizers had failed to notify the district governor of the gathering beforehand. The event was a outing to discuss farmers' rights, quality of life and political empowerment.

On 1 June 2016, in Touch village, Bar Kaev district, Ratanak Kiri province, district police officers broke up a gathering (not a protest) of 50 ethic Jarai Christians because they had not sought permission from authorities to meet.
A man stepped on a landmine, damaging one of his legs so severely it had to be amputated.
Two children died and another was seriously injured by a landmine explosion.
A man was severely injured after stepping on a landmine in a stretch of undemarcated borderland between Cambodia and Thailand.
On September 6, 2016, a grenade was detonated in a residential area of Phnom Penh, injuring three.
A man stepped on a landmine, causing it to explode. The blast injured both of his arms and one leg.
A landmine blew off the foot of a border patrol police officer near the Thai border.
On December 20, 2016, two men were injured when an anti-tank mine exploded in a rice field in Samlot district of Battambang province.
A man was injured after stepping on an anti-personnel mine while hunting in the jungle near the border between Cambodia and Thailand. He lost one of his legs.
One British employee of a demining organization died and another was injured after an antipersonnel mine exploded while they were attempting to remove it.
On January 13, 2016, a deminer working for the NGO Halo Trust was killed and another injured in Bar Yakha commune, Pailin province, after a mine was detonated.
On February 2, 2017, villagers in Trapaing Prasat district, Oddar Meanchey province, detonated a landmine while they were digging up tree stumps. One man was killed and three were injured.
Property destruction: On 9 March2018, in 2 Thnou commune (Pir Thnou), Snuol district, Kratie security forces flattened and razed homes, threatening to kill villagers who did not leave.

Detonation: On 15-March-2018, a land mine exploded accidentally during a clearance training at a military base in western Cambodia's Kampong Speu province, killing two people, including an Australian trainer, and injuring three others.
On May 16, a farmer died in a landmine explosion when he drove his tractor over a landmine in Preah Vihear province's Rong Roeung II village.
Defusal: On July 10, Pailin provincial police recovered a dozen explosive devices under a bridge in Pailin town. Suspected that bombs were placed to create chaos during upcoming elections.

Arrests: Around 29 Nov 2018, the police's Counter Terrorism and Cross Border Crime Department arrested 232 Chinese nationals over online scams in Bati district (Takeo) and Tram Kak district (Takeo). They were deported to China on the 6 Dec.

Arrests: Around 29 Nov 2018, the police's Counter Terrorism and Cross Border Crime Department arrested 232 Chinese nationals over online scams in Bati district (Takeo) and Tram Kak district (Takeo). They were deported to China on the 6 Dec.
Arrests: On 11 Dec 2018, Paoy Paet, Banteay Meanchey district, the police arrested 55 Malaysian and Chinese nationals suspecting them of running an illegal gambling operation online.
Weapons seizure: On 19 Dec 2018, Ra village, Thipakdei commune (Koas Krala, Battambang), the police seized more than 300 AK 47 bullets that were found by a villager while digging her land.
Defusal: On 10 Feb 2019, in Paoy Paet, Paoy Paet district, Banateay Meanchey province, a bomb found in a casino was destroyed by the police without causing any injuries.

On 1 June 2019, a mine (unexploded ordinance) in Anlong Romiet commune, Kandal Stueng district of Kandal province, Cambodia, exploded, injuring two Cambodian civilians. The unexploded ordinance went off while the two were clearing a forest.
On 2 June 2019, a mine (unexploded ordinance) in Choam Ksant commune, Choam Ksant district of Preah Vihear province, Cambodia, exploded and injured a Cambodian civilian.
On 16 June 2019, grenades and mortars were found in O Smach commune, Samroang City, Otar Meanchey, Cambodia. A former Cambodian soldier has been arrested and is under investigation.
On 17 June 2019, more than 100 unexploded ordinances were found in Khna Krao village, Kantout commune, Svay Leu district of Siem Reap province, Cambodia.
On 31 August 2019, Cambodian and Laos military forces both withdrew from the disputed undemarcated Mom Bei area in Chhaeb district of Preah Vihear, Cambodia. Tensions had been rising since August 14.
On 7 October 2019, Cambodian Prime Minister ordered and authorized the military to carry out any necessary measures to attack and prevent the entry of CNRP leaders to Cambodia.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Khmer Times; Phnom Penh Post; Voice of Democracy (Cambodia)
NOTES: As of 10 November 2019, at least 65 CNRP activists have been arrested in an ongoing crackdown by the Cambodian government. Arrests have been made in Phnom Penh, Chbar Mon (Kampong Speu), Kampong Cham, Paoy Paet (Banteay Meanchey), Batheay (Kampong Cham), Banlung (Ratanak Kiri), Kandal, Kampot and Keo Siema (Mondulkiri). Seventeen CNRP activists have been released on bail.
On 13 December 2019, a farmer was seriously injured after driving over an old anti-tank mine planted in the field in Phnom Proek district of Battambang, Cambodia.
On 30 January 2020, a man was killed by an explosion after having attempted to dismantle an unexploded war remnant, in Memot district of Tboung Khmum, Cambodia.
On 7 February 2020, a military officer was seriously injured after having stepped on a landmine in Preah Vihear province of Cambodia.
On 14 February 2020, a military officer died after having stepped on a landmine that had been planted in Choam Ksant district of Preah Vihear, Cambodia, near the border with Thailand.

On 31 March 2020, the draft State of Emergency legislation was approved by the Cambodian cabinet in an attempt to counter the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. As of 11 April, the law has yet to be implemented. Religious gatherings have been banned since 17 March. Effective on 10 April, travels in and out, and between districts of Phnom Penh are prohibited, as well as travels between provinces.

On 29 April 2020, a woman was killed and three others were injured after a rocket, believed to be leftover from the civil war, exploded in Kandal village, Samraong commune, Ou Chrov district of Banteay Meanchey, Cambodia.

On 5 May 2020, villagers accidentally stepped on a landmine in Ta Tork commune of Samlout district, Battambang, Cambodia. The explosion killed one and injured 3 others. The landmine exploded in an area where fighting occurred in the 1980s.

On 5 May 2020, a villager sustained a serious injury after having accidentally stepped on a landmine in Sangkum Thmei village, Veal Veaeng district of Pursat province, Cambodia. The landmine exploded in an area where fighting occurred in the 1980s.
Around 20 May 2020 (week of), an old war remnant exploded in Ta Tok commune, Samlout district of Battambang, Cambodia. A civilian was seriously wounded.
On 27 May 2020, two men drove a tractor over an unexploded old war remnant in Huy Tbong village, Pailin province of Cambodia. Both were wounded.

On 8 June 2020, a woman accidentally burned an unexploded ordinance which was hidden among rubbish, causing an explosion that resulted in her death in Snuol district of Kratie, Cambodia. The explosive is believed to be from the Cambodian War.

On 10 June 2020, a man was killed and another seriously injured after having stepped on a landmine in Chhnal Moan commune, Koas Krala district of Battambang, Cambodia. The landmine is believed to be leftover from previous conflicts.

On 13 July 2020, an intoxicated civilian found a UXO in Pursat province of Cambodia. As he attempted to throw it into the river, it exploded and wounded him. Location coded at the capital of the province, Pursat. The UXO is believed to be a leftover from the Cambodian War.

On 3 August 2020, two farmers were killed by the explosion of a UXO believed to be a leftover from the Cambodian civil war in a plantation in Anlong Reab commune, Veal Veng district of Pursat, Cambodia.
On 13 August 2020, an unexploded war remnant exploded in Veal Veaeng district of Pursat, Cambodia, seriously wounding 4 civilians.

Explosive remnants of war: On 13 November 2020, a police officer stepped on an anti-personnel land mine and was seriously injured near a temple in Kantuot commune (Choam Khsant district, Preah Vihear). The explosive is believed to have been planted during the Thai-Cambodian border dispute in 2007.

Explosive remnants of war: On 13 February 2021, a man and a child were badly wounded as a war remnant exploded while they were clearing land in Lumtong Commune, (Anlong Veang district, Oddar Meanchey). The remnant is believed to be left from the Cambodian Civil War.

Property destruction: On 15 March 2021, unknown assailants set fire and burned down more than 50,000 saplings which had been planted in a ceremony presided by the PM at Techo Sen Russey Treb National Park in Chhaeb district (Preah Vihear). The authorities believed this incident was intentional and reflect hostilities towards the government. No injuries reported.

Explosive remnants of war: On 27 May 2021, a farmer was killed and another seriously wounded after having driven their vehicle over an anti-tank landmine in Sung commune (Samlout district, Battambang). The mine is a remnant of the Cambodia Civil War.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party; Former Government of Cambodia (1993-)
NOTES: On 23 July 2021, an activist and former Treng Trayoeng commune council chief from now-dissolved opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) was arrested at a grocery store in Traeng Trayueng commune (Kampong Speu) on charges of incitement related to her 2019 online posts supporting the return of CNRP leader Sam Rainsy, who had gone in self-imposed exile in Paris, to Cambodia. The activist fled to Thailand after a court summoned her for the posts. She was arrested and jailed after returning to the country, following Prime Minister Hun Sen's promise on granting exiled CNRP activists amnesty upon their return. Her arrest was the latest in a series of legal crackdown by the ruling Cambodia People's Party on political opposition figures and activists in the country.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former Government of Cambodia (1993-); CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party
NOTES: On 29 September 2021,Tum Bunthorn, a former commune councilor for the banned Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) was arrested in Phnom Penh for his reporting on corruption and land grabs. This is the latest in a series of arrests, judicial harassment and attacks against officials of CNRP, the banned opposition party known for its vocal critics of Prime Minister Hun Sen. Location coded as Prampir Makara.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former Government of Cambodia (1993-); CNRP: Cambodia National Rescue Party
NOTES: On 29 September 2021, Lak Keang, a commune chief of Preah Sihanouk province's Bit Traing and member of the now-dissolved opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party, was arrested in Preah Sihanouk and was brought to Phnom Penh for questioning by police. This is the latest in a series of arrests, judicial harassment and attacks against officials of CNRP. The banned opposition party known for its vocal critics of Prime Minister Hun Sen. Location coded as Sihanoukville.

Explosive remnants of war: On 8 October 2021, a mortar round exploded in Sala Visai commune, Prasat Balang district (Kampong Thom province), killing a boy and injuring two other children. The children found pieces of unexploded ordinance (UXO) when they went care for their cow, and they played with it, effectively triggering the explosion.
On 8 January 2015, the Indonesian military returned to Bini village, Kuala Kencana town, Mimika regency, Papua province, and burned down more of the Papuans' homes.
On 13 January 2015, the Indonesian military again returned to Bini village, Kuala Kencana town, Mimika regency, Papua province, and burned down more of the Papuans' homes.

On February 12, 2015, Indonesian police arrested 39 people, including members of FBR: Betawi Brotherhood Forum, who engaged in a riot a night before in Sentul, Babakan Madang, Bogor regency, West Java province. The riot was triggered by an anti-Shiah banner installed in front of a mosque.

Weapons seizure: On Apr 5, guns were seized by police forces from an armed group during a visit to Poso, Central Sulawesi. Police seized two M-16 assault rifles, hundreds of live bullets, bombs and sickles from the group.

Property destruction: On 21 July 2015, in Tlepok area (Purworejo, Central Java) a church was attacked and its entraces burned down in central Java by unidentified men, thought to be Muslim, following the attack on mosque in Christian majority province of Papua. No injuries reported.

Property destruction: On 21 July 2015, a church was attacked and its entraces burnt down in Yogyakarta area by unidentified men, thought to be Muslim, following the attack on mosque in Christian majority province of Papua.
On July 26, 2015, an unidentified armed group destroyed the PKB: National Awakening Party's office in Tasikmalaya city, West Java province. The motive of the destruction was unclear.
On August 19, 2015, Indonesian police confiscated weapons and 20 pipe bombs of MIT: East Indonesia Mujahidin in North Poso Pesisir district, Poso regency, Central Sulawesi province.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Indonesia (2014-) Mobile Brigade Corps
NOTES: Movement of forces: On Aug 20, the National Police Command has sent more personnel from the Mobile Brigade (Brimob) to Poso, Central Sulawesi, following a clash with members of an alleged militant group in the region.
Defusal: On Aug 29, the Jakarta Police's bomb squad defused a homemade bomb circuit found by a resident in Kali Malang, Cipinang Melayu, East Jakarta. The culprits are unknown.

Arrests: On Sep 27, the Lumajang Police in East Java arrested 36 people on suspicion of involvement in a deadly assault that claimed the life of a local farmer who had co-arranged a protest against invasive sand-mining in his village.
On October 13, 2015, Indonesian police arrested 45 people that were allegedly involved in a riot in Aceh Singkil regency, Aceh province, coded as Singkil district, earlier that day.

After 13 October 2015, thousands of migrant Christian Batak workers in Singkil city, Aceh Singkil regency, Aceh province, fled to North Sumatra following the act of a Christian church being burned by the Concerned Islamic Youth on 13 October.

On 19 October 2015, the local government in Singkil city, Aceh Singkil regency, Aceh province, began demolishing 10 churches, in addition to one burnt down by the Concerned Islamic Youth on 13 October, for violations of permits, as part of a previous agreement with local religious groups and officials.

On October 28, 2015, an unidentified armed group destroyed the headquarters of KNPI: Indonesian Youth National Committee in South Jakarta City, Jakarta province. The reason for the destruction was unknown.
On December 22, 2015, Indonesian police arrested 31 people involved in a post-election riot in Tanjung Selor district, Bulungan Regency, North Kalimantan province three days before.
Around December 25, 2015, a group of people burned down a police station in Kupang city, East Nusa Tenggara province. The reason was unclear. [size=no report]

On January 8, 2016, a group of people burned miners' houses at an illegal mining site in Srumbung district, Magelang regency, Central Java province. They also destroyed the mining facilities and the gate towards the mining site. The mining activity allegedly had caused environmental damage. [size=no report]

On 5 February 2016, at least 12 members, mostly women and children, of the Ahmadiyya religious minority have been forced to leave their homes in Srimenanti village in Sungailiat town, Bangka regency, Bangka-Belitung province by the district military command. The police escorted them away to a location that has not been made public, surrounded by 100 local residents that were opposed to the Ahmadiyya. Property destruction: On 28 January 2019, an explosion occurred early in the morning outside the Beringin Asri Housing Complex in Ngaliyan in Semarang city (Semarang, Central Java). An assailant on a motorcycle launched what was later identified as a Molotov cocktail at motorcycles that then burnt up. This is part of a string of 28 coordinated vehicular arson attacks by unidentified perpetrators in Kendal, Grobogan and the Semarang Regency since December 2018. Police suggest it is organized and by people specifically trained. They surmise it is to create fear before the presidential election and they have formed a special team to counter the acts of terror in Central Java.
