ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); OPM: Free Papua Movement
NOTES: On Dec 1, 2019, the Indonesian Police Mobile Brigade and Indonesian military arrested 54 indigenous Papuans in Kayauni and Kramonmongga district, Fakfak Regency, West Papua province, coded as Fakfak district, suspecting them of planning to raise the Morning Star flag at the regent's office. It was the commemoration of the Free Papua Movement anniversary. The police also confiscated sharp weapons during the arrest.

On Dec 7, 2019, Indonesian police raided an illegal weapon store in Lumajang city, Lumajang Regency, East Java, confiscated dozens of air rifles and bullets. The store often sold weapons to conflict areas such as Papua and Sulawesi.

Displacement: Around 15 December 2019 (month of), 1,237 Papuans from Intan Jaya Regency (Papua province) (coded to Sugapa town) were displaced after TPNPB killed two Indonesian soldiers. Two other clashes between TPNPB and Indonesian police and military forces, on 19 September 2020 and 2-3 October 2020 respectively, also caused internal displacement. By December 2020, the total number of IDPs from Intan Jaya is estimated at 13,000 people.

On 1 January 2020, Indonesian police started Tinombala Operation in Poso regency, Central Sulawesi province, coded as Poso city. The operation is targeting the remaining members of MIT and will be ongoing until 30 September 2020.

On Jan 11, 2020, the Indonesian military dispatched three warships to drive out dozens of boats from China that entered the North Natuna Sea, coded as Natuna Sea, Seleman district, Southeast Bunguran regency, Riau Islands province.

On Jan 18, 2020, an unidentified man burned a village administration office in Neglasari sub-district, Jatiwaras district, Tasikmalaya regency, West Java province. He threw a Molotov bomb through the window. The motive was unclear. The incident was likely related to the recent protests by people demanding budget transparency from the village administration.

On Jan 29, 2020, an unidentified armed group destroyed a small mosque in the Tumaluntung sub-district, Kauditan district, North Minahasa regency, North Sulawesi province. The mosque was built on disputed land.

On Feb 4, 2020, an unidentified armed group burned two elementary schools in East Barabai subdistrict, Barabai district, Central Hulu Sungai regency, South Kalimantan province. The motive was unclear. The school authorities managed to stop the fire before it got bigger.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 6 February 2020, TPNPB burned shops, heavy equipment, and village office building in Papua province (coded as Jayapura city).

Reported on Feb 11, 2020, a Papuan activist stated that 243 people, including 110 children, had died in Nduga regency, Papua province, as a consequence of military operations by security forces in the area between Dec 4, 2019, to Feb 2, 2020. Some of them died due to the lack of food, water, and proper shelter to live. Location coded at Kenyam.
Reported on Feb 13, 2020, the Indonesian government decided to deploy 700 troops to a military district in West Papua. Location coded at Manokwari.

Around 15 February 2020 (month of), Indonesian police destroyed civilian houses in Besipae village, coded as Soe district (South Timor Tengah regency, East Nusa Tenggara province). The police claimed the land belongs to the government, but the residents dispute this.

Property destruction: On 18 February 2020, an unidentified group threw rocks at the house of Alumni 212's leader in Cimanggis district, Depok City, West Java province. The incident might be related to the plan of Alumni 212 to stage a demonstration on 20 February.

ACTOR2: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: On Feb 22, 2020, a former supporter of TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army handed over his rifle and two 22-caliber bullets to the Indonesian military in Merauke District, Merauke Regency, Papua Province.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 5 March 2020, TPNPB burned a former church building in Blok A Opitawak village (Tembagapura district, Mimika regency, Papua province).

Displacement: Around 6 March 2020 (from 6 - 9 March), 1,752 Papuans were forced to leave their villages (Waa Banti, Kimbeli, Kali Kabur, and Banti) in the Tembagapura district (Mimika Regency, Papua province) due to conflict between the Indonesian military and police forces and TPNPB. They were evacuated to Timika by the Indonesian government and security forces, with the help of mining company PT Freeport Indonesia. Until November 2020, they were still unable to return to their villages. Civil society organizations mention a total of 2,114 IDPs who were taken to Timika on 2-8 March 2020.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 6 March 2020, TPNPB burned a civilian house in Blok A, Opitawak village (Tembagapura district, Mimika regency, Papua province).

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), the Indonesian Coast Guard (Bakamla) detained five Vietnamese fishing boats that illegally entered the North Natuna Sea, Southern Coast of Riau Islands. The police arrested nearly 70 boat crew members. Indonesia claims the southernmost region of the South China Sea as its exclusive economic zone.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), Indonesian police destroyed civilian houses in Besipae village, coded as Soe district (South Timor Tengah regency, East Nusa Tenggara province). The police claimed the land belongs to the government, but the residents dispute this.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 15 March 2020, TPNPB burned a state-owned health clinic in Opitawak village (Tembagapura district, Mimika regency, Papua province).
On March 19, 2020, Indonesian police announced restrictions on mass gatherings in Indonesia due to the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. Violation of the restrictions is considered as a crime.

On March 23, 2020, the association of online taxi drivers sent a letter to Indonesian president, coded in Gambir sub district, Gambir district, Central Jakarta city, Jakarta city, demanding the government ease the credit payment for them during COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak, as their income had significantly dropped. They didn't stage peaceful protest to comply with social distancing regulation.

On March 26, 2020, the government of Papua closed the Sentani airport in Sentani district, Jayapura city, Papua province, due to the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. The airport is the main entrance to Papua. It will be closed until April 9, 2020.
On March 26, 2020, the government of Bali ordered the residents to stay at home due to the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. The regulation is effective until March 30, 2020.

On March 26, 2020, the representation of mentally disabled community sent a letter to Indonesian president, coded in Gambir sub district, Gambir district, Central Jakarta city, Jakarta city, demanding the government take care of 3,000 mentally disabled people, who were shut-in at mental institutions during COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. They didn't staged peaceful protest to comply with social distancing regulation.

On March 27, 2020, the governor of West Papua ruled that non-West Papuan are not allowed to enter the area. Also, West Papuans are encouraged not to leave the province, due to COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.
Security measures: On 29 March 2020, the Aceh government set a curfew that bans people from leaving their house between 8:30pm and 5:30am to last until 29 May 2020.

On April 2, 2020, based on a report from Agrarian Reform Consortium, a company named PT MA, accompanied by Indonesian police forces, took over farming land of villagers in Sedang village, Suak Tapeh district, Banyuasin Regency, South Sumatra province. The company staff destroyed the farmers' huts and threw away rice paddies recently planted by the farmers. The land is in dispute between the villagers and the company.
Starting from April 2, 2020, Indonesia banned any foreigner entering the country due to COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak, until further notice. Location coded as Jakarta.
By April 3, 2020, Indonesian police close had closed 247 roads in East Java province due to COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On April 3, 2020, based on a report from Agrarian Reform Consortium, a company named PT SND, accompanied by Indonesian police forces, destroyed villagers' farms in East Luwu regency, South Sulawesi province. The land is in dispute between the villagers and the company.

On 10 April 2020, the Jakarta government imposed a Large Scale Social Restriction (PSBB) policy, valid for the next 14 days. All online motorbike taxis are not allowed to take passengers. Restaurants are only allowed to serve take-away. Update on 20 May 2020: the governor of Jakarta extended the PSBB from 22 May 2020 to 4 June 2020. Update on 4 June 2020: the Jakarta government extended the PSBB until 18 June 2020. Starting from 2 July 2020, the Jakarta government allowed people to stage demonstrations again, as long as they complied with social distancing guidelines. On 14 September 2020, the Jakarta government re-imposed the PSBB to curb the spread of coronavirus. The measure would last for two weeks and could be extended. Workplaces in 11 essential sectors remain open at 50 percent of capacity, while private companies and government offices must implement work-from-home policies.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Indonesia (2014-) Mobile Brigade Corps
NOTES: On 10 April 2020, a farmer found a 40-cm bomb in farming land in Matang Santot village, Tanah Jambo Aye district, North Aceh Regency, Aceh province. The police from the Mobile Brigade Corps had defused the bomb. It was allegedly planted during the insurgency in Aceh dozens of years ago.

Weapons seizure: On 13 April 2020, Indonesian police forces from Detachment 88 confiscated weapons from a group of JAD militants in the Muna regency (Southeast Sulawesi province) (coded to Katobu district), including firearms and knives. Four militants were arrested.

Displacement: On 16 April 2020, Papuan villagers fled their houses in Tikiemana village, East Aifat district (Maybrat regency, West Papua province), after police officers searched the KNPB office and multiple houses in Tikiemana village. It was related to the killing of a police officer in West Moskona district, Teluk Bintuni regency. The villagers sought shelter in the surrounding forest.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Indonesia (2014-) Mobile Brigade Corps
NOTES: On 16 April 2020, the Indonesian police force and Mobile Brigade Corps raided the secretariat of KNPB in Tikiemana district, coded as Kumurkek district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province. The security forces searched for members of KNPB in the residential area nearby. Some Papuans ran to the jungle and did not come back until 26 April 2020.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Indonesia (2014-) Mobile Brigade Corps
NOTES: On 18 April 2020, Indonesian police forces and Mobile Brigade Corps searched for Papuans with alleged links to KNPB from Tikiemana and Tiefromen villages. They raided houses in Trans/Yahi village, coded as Kumurkek district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Indonesia (2014-) Mobile Brigade Corps
NOTES: On 21 April 2020, Indonesian police forces and Mobile Brigade Corps raided Sasior Nafe and Sasior Frabuku villages in West Afat district, coded as Kumurkek district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province. Some Papuans escaped to the forest. They allegedly are connected to KNPB.

Security measures: On 24 April 2020, the Indonesian government restricted all passenger travel starting from April 24 until June 1, 2020, as the government attempted to prevent citizens from participating in the annual Ied Fitr tradition of mudik (exodus) to curb the spread of COVID-19 (Coronavirus). The ban imposed on all types of public and private transportation by air, sea, land, and railway.

Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), villagers from eight villages in East Aifat district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province, left their villages as the security forces raided them in pursuit of those who killed a member of Indonesian Police Mobile Brigade Corps in Bintuni in mid-April.

On 2 May 2020, Indonesian police detonated a bomb planted by an unidentified man at a mosque in Kuala Pembuang Satu subdistrict, Seruyan Hilir district, Seruyan Regency, Central Kalimantan. The police had arrested the man. His motive of planting the bomb was unclear.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Around 22 May 2020 (from 18 May - 25 May), TPNPB took over security forces posts in Nduga regency, Papua province, coded as Kenyam district, and stole the security forces ammunition. The police denied the statement and accused TPNPB was spreading propaganda.

On 27 May 2020, two unidentified men threw a Molotov cocktail at the house of a High Court official in Gunung Sulah sub-district, Sukarame district, Bandar Lampung City, Lampung province, damaging the house. The motive was unclear.

On 28 June 2020, two unidentified men threw a Molotov bomb at an army officer's house in Sidomulyo village, Biru Biru district, Deli Serdang regency, North Sumatra province. The officer was woken up by the sound of the explosion and called for help. The house was damaged.

On 18 July 2020, the Indonesian Coast Guard (Bakamla) detained two Vietnamese fishing boats that illegally entered the North Natuna Sea, Southern Coast of Riau Islands. Nearly two dozen Vietnamese and Cambodian nationals were arrested after 'wrestling' with the maritime authorities for two hours. One captain tried to attack the coast guards with scissors. A few crew members fell into the sea but were rescued. Indonesia claims the southernmost region of the South China Sea as its exclusive economic zone.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: PDI-P: Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle
NOTES: On 28 July 2020, unidentified people threw a Molotov bomb at the house of PDI-P party member in Megamendung district, Bogor city, West Java province. It didn't cause a fire but left black patches on the house.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: PDI-P: Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle
NOTES: On 29 July 2020, seven people, including two members of FPI, threw a Molotov bomb at the PDI-P party branch office in Cileungsi district (Bogor city, West Java province). The police said that the event was related with a flag-burning incident, but no further explanation provided.

Looting: On 8 August 2020, IS-linked militant group MIT intercepted Department of Health vehicles on Trans-Sulawesi Road on the way to Poso city (Central Sulawesi province) (coded to Poso city). They looted the health workers' money, food, and watch. There were no casualties.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 18 August 2020, TPNPB burned heavy equipment in Intan Jaya Regency (Papua province), coded as Bilogai village.

On 18 August 2020, Indonesian police destroyed 29 civilian houses in Besipae village, coded as Soe district (South Timor Tengah regency, East Nusa Tenggara province). The police claimed the land belongs to the government, but the residents dispute this.

Property destruction: On 18 August 2020, Indonesian police forces destroyed 47 houses of the Pubabu indigenous community in Besipae village (South Amanuban district, South Timor Tengah regency, East Nusa Tenggara) (coded to Soe city). Six hundred people fled their homes. The Besipae ethnic group has been engaged in a long-term land dispute with the government.

On 20 August 2020, the Indonesian Coast Guard (Bakamla) detained two Vietnamese fishing boats that illegally entered the North Natuna Sea, Southern Coast of Riau Islands. 24 Vietnamese nationals, including the two boat captains and their crew, were arrested. Unlike similar recent arrests, the boat crew did not resist arrest this time. Indonesia claims the southernmost region of the South China Sea as its exclusive economic zone.

On 22 August 2020, an unidentified group burned the main building of the Attorney General's Office complex in South Jakarta city (Jakarta province). The police stated the fire might be lit intentionally, linked to several ongoing corruption investigations.

Around 25 August 2020 (between 21 August and 28 August 2020), Indonesian police and military raided villages in Yahukimo Regency, coded as the Dekai district (Yahukimo regency, Papua province), in relation with the killings of civilians in Papua in August. Many people fled to the forest due to the raids.

On 26 August 2020, a vehicle of the Indonesian military ran over a melon plantation in Setrojenar village (Bulupesantren district, Kebumen Regency, Central Java province), destroying the plot. It was caused by a land dispute between the farmers and the military. The military claimed the land belongs to them, while the farmers insisted that the land belongs to the country and free to use.

Around 26 August 2020 (between 22 August and 31 August 2020), Indonesian police and military raided several locations in Dekai town (Yahukimo regency, Papua province), searching for the perpetrators who killed three people in Dekai in the second half of August. They arrested 18 people and confiscated farm tools and weapons.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: IPK: The Association for Youth Employment
NOTES: On 14 September 2020, three unidentified men burned a car owned by the leader of IPK in Bangun Jaya village, North Tambusai district, Rokan Hulu regency (Riau province), coded in Pasir Pengaraian sub-district. They were arrested by the police around 11 October 2020. They admitted that they were paid by an unidentified actor to commit the action. The motive of destruction was unclear.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 18 September 2020, TPNPB shot a plane carrying the body of a deceased military member, who died during an armed clash a day before in Sugapa district, Intan Jaya regency (Papua province), coded as Bilogai village.

On 2 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 61 Chinese workers and took them to the Immigration Detention Center in Delta Pawan district (Ketapang regency, West Kalimantan province), following a protest by local people a week earlier. The workers didn't have proper immigration paperwork.

ACTOR2: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 7 October 2020, Indonesian military forces fired warning shots as two men carrying rifles, allegedly rebels from TPNPB, were spotted coming out from a bush around at the Bilogai-Sugapa Airport (UGU) in the Sugapa district (Intan Jaya regency, Papua province). The armed men fled from the site. It was reported that the military thwarted an attack by the rebels as this incident follows threats by rebels to attack places such as airports.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: On 8 October 2020, TPNPB shot a plane in Bilogai airport in Bilogai village (Sugapa district, Intan Jaya Regency, Papua province).

On 8 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 75 students in Serang city (Banten Province), who were on the way to stage a protest in front of the Banten governor's office against the omnibus law of job creations.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KAMI: Action Coalition to Save Indonesia; Labour Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: On 12 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested the leader and two members of KAMI in Medan city (North Sumatra province). They were accused as the intellectual authors behind the riot against the ratification of the omnibus law of job creations.
On 12 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 73 students in Surakarta city (Central Java province). They were on the way to join a protest against the omnibus law in Surakarta city hall.

On 12 October 2020, Indonesian police intercepted a truck on Asahan Road, Nagori Bangun (Bangun) sub-district, Gunung Malela district, Simalungun Regency (North Sumatra province) and arrested 60 students. They were on the way to stage a protest in Pematang Siantar city.

On 13 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 155 students in North Jakarta city (Jakarta province). They were on the way to join a protest against the omnibus law in front of the Presidential Palace in Central Jakarta city.

On 13 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 50 students in Bekasi city, including Bekasi train station (West Java province). They were on the way to join a protest against omnibus law ratification in Jakarta city.

On 13 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 29 students on Baru Road, Tigaraksa district, Tangerang city (Banten province). They were on the way to join a protest against the omnibus law in front of the Presidential Palace in Central Jakarta city.

On 13 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 37 people, including students, in Sukmajaya district, Depok city (West Java province). They were on the way to join a protest in Jakarta city regarding the omnibus law of job creations.

On 13 October 2020, Indonesian police arrested 32 students in East Ciputat district, South Tangerang city (Banten province). They were on the way to join a protest in front of the Presidential Palace in Central Jakarta city.

Arrests: On 1 November 2020, the Indonesian police forces arrested 25 Vietnamese boat crew and detained two boats that illegally entered the North Natuna Sea (Southern Coast of Riau Islands). They initially attempted to escape. Indonesia claims the southernmost region of the South China Sea as its exclusive economic zone.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); Catholic Christian Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Arrests: On 17 November 2020, Indonesian police arrested 55 participants of a meeting organized by the Papuan People's Assembly (MRP) to evaluate 20 years of Papua special autonomy status at Grand Merauke Hotel in Merauke town (Merauke regency, Papua province). One of the arrestees was a Catholic priest.

Arrests: On 27 November 2020, Indonesian police arrested 36 people involved in protest and demonstration in Manokwari and Sorong, West Papua province (coded to Sorong city). They demanded a referendum on Papua independence.

Displacement: Around 28 November 2020 (between 27 November - 30 November), 150 Christian farmer families were evacuated from Lemban Tongoa village, Palolo district (Sigi regency, Central Sulawesi province), after MIT attacked their village on 27 November 2020. They were moved to a more populated area by the government.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Arrests: On 30 November 2020, Indonesian police and military forces raided the KNPB office in Merauke town (Merauke regency, Papua province), arrested six KNPB activists without a warrant, and allegedly damaged the office. The arrests were likely related to the commemoration of the West Papua anniversary the next day. Police later declared that the activists would be charged for treason.

Arrests: On 10 December 2020, Indonesian police arrested a suspected leader of JI during a raid at a house in East Lampung regency (Lampung province) (coded to Sukadana town). He was involved in the 2002 Bali bombings and 2003 JW Marriot attack in Jakarta. The JI network is linked to Al-Qaeda.

Property destruction: On 11 December 2020, an unidentified armed group burned three cars belong to supporters of a regency election candidate in Patoloan village and Sidomukti village, Bone-bone district (North Luwu regency, South Sulawesi province). The victims supported the incumbent regent for the next term. The regency held an election two days earlier.

Property destruction: On 13 December 2020, an unidentified actor threw a Molotov bomb at a police station on Sultan Hasanudin Road, Somba Opu district (Gowa regency, Sulawesi province). There were no officers at the station when the incident took place, but a few electronics were burned. The motive of the attack was unclear.

Property destruction: On 13 December 2020, an unidentified actor threw a Molotov bomb at a police station on the junction of AP Pettarani Road - Urip Sumoharjo Road, Makassar city (South Sulawesi province), damaging the building. The police found a note containing threats and curses against police forces. The motive of the attack was unclear.

Arrests: On 13 December 2020, Indonesian police arrested the FPI leader at the Jakarta police station in South Jakarta city (Jakarta province) for violating the social distancing restriction during the coronavirus pandemic. Earlier, the cleric had hosted a wedding party for his daughter in November, creating a new cluster of coronavirus. He had also held a gathering for a Muslim holiday celebration at the FPI headquarters in Petamburan. He was arrested after 11 hours of interrogation.

Property destruction: Around 15 December 2020 (month of), unidentified assailants damaged a car of Alumni 212 leader at his house in Cimanggis district, Depok city (West Java province). The motive was unclear.

Property destruction: On 17 December 2020, an unidentified actor threw Molotov bombs at the house of Muna General Election Commission's head in Katobu district (Muna regency, Southeast Sulawesi province), damaging the house. The motive of the attack was unclear.

Property destruction: On 24 December 2020, an unidentified actor threw Molotov bombs at a female journalist's house in Kampar regency (Riau province) (coded to Bangkinang town), burning her car. The motive was unclear. The police arrested four people who were involved in the incident five days later.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 3 January 2021, TPNPB damaged a telecommunication tower in Aminggaru village (Omukia district, Puncak regency, Papua province) (coded as Ilaga district).

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Arrests: On 4 January 2021, Indonesian police forces arrested the chairman of KNPB Intan Jaya in front of the Yapis University in Jayapura city (Papua province). He was charged with illegal use, possession, or distribution of firearms.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 6 January 2021, TPNPB damaged a telecommunication tower in Toegi village (North Ilaga district, Puncak regency, Papua province) (coded as Ilaga district).

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 6 January 2021, TPNPB reportedly shot a commercial helicopter hired by a mining company PT Freeport Indonesia in Tsinga village (Tembagapura District, Mimika Regency, Papua Province), around 50 km northeast of Timika. The helicopter was piloted by a foreign citizen. No injuries were reported.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 6 January 2021, TPNPB burned a plane of a Christian organization Mission Aviation Fellowship (MAP) at an airport in Pagamba village, Biandoga district (Intan Jaya regency, Papua province). The plane had just landed when the rebels ordered the pilot, a US-national, and passengers to step down before torching the plane. They also fired shots into the air. No injuries were reported. However, the TPNBP claimed they did not burn the plane but shot it when its engine was still running.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 7 January 2021, TPNPB burned down two telecommunication towers in Omukia district and Mabuggi district, Puncak regency (Papua province) (coded to Ilaga), cutting the phone and internet network in the districts.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 8 January 2021, TPNPB burned a communication tower in Duagi hill, Muara area, Mabugi district (Puncak regency, Papua province) (coded to Ilaga district).

Weapons seizure: Around 20 January 2021 (between 20 - 21 January), Indonesian police from the Detachment 88 forces seized bomb-making material during three raids in Aceh province (coded to Banda Aceh city). The first raid took place in Blang Bintang district, Aceh Besar regency, while the third one was in Langsa Lama district, Langsa city. The second raid location was unknown. The police also arrested five suspected militants, and confiscated IS study books.

Displacement: On 22 January 2021, Papuans villagers fled and vacated Ndugusiga village, Sugapa district (Intan Jaya regency, Papua province), after the military clashed with TPNPB in Intan Jaya a day earlier. The military forces reportedly threatened to shoot all people who stayed in the village.

Property destruction: On 23 January 2021, an unidentified armed group torched the house of the Yahukimo General Election Commission's head in Yahukimo Regency (Papua province) (coded to Dekai town). Several rooms of the house were damaged, but there were no casualties reported. The perpetrators were allegedly supporters of the defeated candidate on the Yahukimo regional election. The election result was announced the same day.

Property destruction: On 4 February 2021, unidentified assailants burned the car of a state-owned plantation company staff in the residential complex of palm oil factory PT Perkebunan Nusantara in Pagar Merbau II village (Pagar Merbau district, Deli Serdang regency, North Sumatra province). The motive was unclear.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 6 February 2021, TPNPB burned repair tools of a telecommunication tower in Toegi village (North Ilaga district, Puncak regency, Papua province) (coded as Ilaga district).

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 8 February 2021, TPNPB burned a worker camp of a company in Ilaga district (Puncak regency, Papua province).

Displacement: On 8 February 2021, 650 Papuan villagers from Bilogai, Kumbalagupa, and Puyagiya villages in Sugapa district, Intan Jaya Regency (Papua province) (coded to Bilogai village), fled their homes after TPNPB killed a kiosk owner in Bilogai. They were seeking shelter in Catholic church facilities in Bilogai. Due to the instability in the regency, the regency administration has not to worked from their office in Sugapa since early 2021.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 10 February 2021, TPNPB burned a camp and vehicles of a palm oil company PT Unggul in Ilaga district (Puncak regency, Papua province). The motive was unclear.

NOTES: Property destruction: On 12 February 2021, PP members attacked IPK headquarters in Rambah Hilir district (Rokan Hulu regency, Riau province). The PP members were offended because IPK members repainted buildings that PP had painted to show ownership. PP damaged the office and burned a vehicle that belongs to IPK. The IPK members fled the scene. The police later confiscated various weapons of PP, including swords and arrows.

Property destruction: On 13 February 2021, an unidentified armed group burned a car of the Ministerial Office of Forestry and Environment in Nanga Awin village (North Putussibau district, Kapuas Hulu regency, West Kalimantan province). The office staff parked the car on the main road near the village while they were securing the pieces of evidence of illegal logging. The motive of the property destruction is allegedly related to the illegal logging case.

Displacement: On 15 February 2021, around 400 to 500 Papuan villagers from Mamba village (Sugapa district, Intan Jaya Regency, Papua province) fled their homes due to the increasing activity of TPNPB in their village. They were seeking shelter in Catholic church facilities in Bilogai.

Security measures: Around 17 February 2021 (as reported), Indonesian police imposed a curfew for residents of Intan Jaya Regency (Papua province) (coded to Sugapa district) due to the increasing activity of TPNPB in the regency. Residents of Intan Jaya should stay home after 5 pm.

Defusal: On 18 February 2021, an unidentified armed group put a grenade under the car of Langsa Narcotics Prison Head in Sungai Lueng village, East Langsa district, Langsa city (Aceh province). The police confiscated and defused the grenade. The motive was unclear.

Weapons seizure: On 26 February 2021, Indonesian police forces from Detachment 88 confiscated weapons from JI militants in East Java province (coded as Surabaya city), including a gun, bullets, knives, swords, machetes, and arrows during raids in Sidoarjo, Surabaya, Mojokerto, and Malang. Twelve militants were arrested.

Property destruction: On 3 March 2021, seven unidentified people damaged the Asmat regent's office, regent's house, and the General Election Commission building in Agats town (Asmat Regency, Papua province) after the inauguration of the new regent and vice-regent. They threw rocks at the establishments.

Property destruction: On 5 March 2021, six unidentified men threw a Molotov bomb at an unidentified mass organization headquarters on Sumber Rejeki Road, Parigi Lama sub-district, Pondok Aren district, South Tangerang city (Banten province). The building was damaged. The motive was unclear.

Property destruction: On 5 March 2021, four unidentified men burned down an FBR office in Hankam Street, Parigi sub-district, Pondok Aren district, South Tangerang city (Banten province). The building was damaged. No casualties were reported. The motive of the destruction was unclear.

Property destruction: On 7 March 2021, an unidentified armed group burned down a PP office in Pondok Maharta residential complex, East Pondok Kacang sub-district, Pondok Aren district, South Tangerang city (Banten province). The building was damaged. No casualties were reported. The motive of the destruction was unclear.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Indonesia (2014-) Komando Pasukan Khusus
NOTES: Property destruction: On 15 March 2021, the Indonesian military forces from the Special Forces Command (Kopassus) burned PP headquarters and two PP vehicles in the West Bandung regency (West Java province) (coded to Ngamprah district). Earlier that day, PP members hit a soldier who tried to disperse a brawl between PP and a group of debt collectors from Mata Elang (Matel).

Defusal: On 29 March 2021, Indonesian police from the Detachment 88 police forces defused explosives found at a JAD militant house in Sukasari village, Serang Baru district, Bekasi city (West Java province), following a bomb explosion in Makassar, South Sulawesi. They also raided a house in East Jakarta. In total, the police arrested four people and defused five bombs.

Defusal: On 29 March 2021, Indonesian police from the Detachment 88 defused explosives found at a JAD militant house at a football field in Batu Alam Jaya Street, Batu Ampar sub-district, Kramatjati district, East Jakarta city (Jakarta province) (coded as Jakarta - East Jakarta). The Detachment 88 police forces raided militants houses in Condet, East Jakarta, and Bekasi, West Java, following a bomb explosion in Makassar, South Sulawesi. In total, the police arrested four militants and defused five bombs.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: FPI: Islamic Defenders Front; Muslim Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 31 March 2021, Indonesian police from Detachment 88 confiscated weapons from a house occupied by Muslim militants in Banjaran sub-district, Cangkuang district, Bandung city (West Java province), including 25 arrows and bows, catapult, rocks, sharp weapons. Police said the militants had attributes commonly linked to the FPI. Two people were arrested.
Property destruction: On 1 April 2021, unidentified assailants threw rocks at the house of Alumni 212 leader in Cimanggis district, Depok city (West Java province). The motive was unclear.

Property destruction: On 7 April 2021, an unidentified assailant damaged Aceh Party's headquarters on Mr. Muhammad Hasan Road, Banda Aceh city (Aceh province). The motive was unknown. The office was empty during the incident. A window was broken.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 8 April 2021, TPNPB burned three public schools in Beoga district (Puncak regency, Papua province).

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Other: On 9 April 2021, TPNPB took over the Beoga airport in Beoga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province). The Indonesian government had to pay ransom for landing a plane to evacuate two teachers killed by the rebels on 8-9 April 2021.

Displacement: On 10 April 2021, 14 Papuan villagers from Beoga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province) fled their homes due to the increasing activity of TPNPB in their village. They were seeking shelter in a secret location.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 11 April 2021, TPNPB burned a commercial helicopter in Aminggaru airport in Ilaga district (Puncak regency, Papua province).

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 11 April 2021, TPNPB burned nine rooms of a junior high school in Beoga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province).

Displacement: On 13 April 2021, 42 Papuan villagers from Beoga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province) fled their homes due to the increasing activity of TPNPB in their village. They were seeking shelter in military and police posts.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 13 April 2021, TPNPB burned two houses near Boega airport in Beoga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province). The houses belonged to a headmaster and a council member. The house owners were not home during the incident.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 15 April 2021, Indonesian police and military forces confiscated dozens of undocumented ammunition from a police officer in Nabire airport in Nabire district (Nabire regency, Papua province). The ammunition was allegedly meant to be transferred to the rebels.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 April 2021, TPNPB burned down four wooden houses belonged to the Dambet tribe leader and three teachers in Dambet village, Beoga district (Puncak regency, Papua province). They also burned an elementary school building and damaged its door.

Property destruction: On 21 April 2021, an unidentified assailant smashed and sprayed paint on the car of a Papuan journalist in Jayapura city (Papua province). The car's windows were damaged. The motive was unclear.

Property destruction: On 23 April 2021, an unidentified assailant threw a Molotov bomb at the village administration building in Keude Seumot hamlet, Lhok Seumot village (Beutong district, Nagan Raya Regency, Aceh province). The office was damaged. There were no casualties as the office was empty during the attack. The motive was unclear.

ACTOR2: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 24 April 2021, five TPNPB members reportedly denounced TPNPB surrendered and turned over their weapons, including four firearms and 11 sharp ammunition, to the Indonesian police forces in Yapen Islands police station in Serui town (South Yapen district, Yapen Islands regency, Papua province).
Property destruction: On 25 April 2021, Indonesian military forces allegedly burned five Papuan houses in Kindibam village, Nduga Regency (Papua province) (coded as Kenyam district).

Displacement: Around 27 April 2021 (as reported), Papuan villagers from Tagaloa, Wuloni, and Tuwunikime villages in Ilaga district and villagers from Akonobak, Paluga, Palumbur, Olenki, Duagi, and Mayuberi villages in North Ilaga district (Puncak regency, Papua province) (coded as Ilaga district), fled their homes to Kimak town and villages of Kimak, Kago 1, Kago 2, Wilembur, and Jenggerbaga, following the armed clash between TPNPB and Indonesian military and police forces in Puncak regency.

Displacement: Around 27 April 2021 (as reported), Papuan villagers from Upaga, Efesus, Tegelobak, and Misimaga villages in Gome district and villagers from Tobenggi I, Tobenggi II, Mundidok I, Mundidok II, and Welenggaru villages in North Gome district (Puncak regency, Papua province) (coded as Gome district), fled their homes to Gome town and Tanah Merah village, following the armed clash between TPNPB and Indonesian military and police forces in Puncak regency.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 2 May 2021, TPNPB burned down several public facilities in Mayuberi village (Ilaga district, Puncak regency, Papua province). They burned an elementary school, two teachers' houses, a health clinic, Kimak bridge, and damaged Tagaloa and Wuloni Pintu Angin roads. The buildings were formerly used as military command posts.

Property destruction: On 7 May 2021, Indonesian military forces reportedly fired shots at Papuan civilians' houses in Taitawa village, Intan Jaya regency (Papua province) (coded to Sugapa district), during a raid targetting TPNPB.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 8 May 2021 (as reported), TPNPB torched a public learning activity building in Kimak village (Ilaga district, Puncak regency, Papua province).

Property destruction: On 8 May 2021, Indonesian military forces reportedly fired shots at Papuan civilians' houses in Taitawa village, Intan Jaya regency (Papua province) (coded to Sugapa district), during a raid targetting TPNPB.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); KNPB: National Committee for West Papua
NOTES: On 9 May 2021, Indonesian police forces arrested the international spokesperson of KNPB in Jayapura city (Papua province). He was accused as the mastermind of series of riots in Papua in 2019.

Displacement: Around 9 May 2021 (as reported), Papuans fled from their houses in Taitawa village, Intan Jaya regency (Papua province) (coded to Sugapa district) due to the increasing activity of TPNPB and the Indonesian military forces.

Displacement: Around 14 May 2021 (as reported), 653 Papuans from Kimak, Tagaloa, Wuloni, and Jenggerpaga villages sought refuge at the Puncak regent's office in Kimak town (Ilaga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province) due to the increasing activities of TPNPB. Thousands of Papuans from Mabugi district, Paluga village, and Akonobak village were also believed to be hiding in churches and the forests in Bologobak village, Ilaga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province) due to the increasing activities of TPNPB.

Displacement: On 15 May 2021, Papuan villagers from Toegi, Ilaga district (Puncak Regency, Papua Province) fled their homes due to the increasing activity of the Indonesian military and police forces in their village. They went to Demaju and then Paluga village.

Property destruction: Around 15 May 2021 (from 15 - 16 May), an unidentified actor bombed villages in Gome district (Puncak regency, Papua province). A church and Papuan villagers' houses. The TPNPB and indonesian security forces blamed each other for the incident.

Displacement: Around 19 May 2021 (as reported), Papuan villagers from Dambet dan Tinggilibet villages in Beoga district (Puncak Regency, Papua province) fled their homes due to the increasing activity of TPNPB in their village. They were seeking shelter in Milawak village and the neighboring area.

Property destruction: On 31 May 2021, an unidentified perpetrator burned the car of a journalist in Dusun III hamlet, Pon village (Sei Bamban district, Serdang Bedagai Regency, North Sumatra province). The reason was unknown. There were no casualties reported.

Displacement: On 4 June 2021, Papuans from 10 villages around Eromaga village, Omukia district (Puncak regency, Papua province) (coded as Ilaga district) fled their homes towards Kunga ara due to the increasing activity of TPNPB in their village.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 4 June 2021, TPNPB burned down facilities in Aminggaru airport in Ilaga district (Puncak regency, Papua province). It damaged an airport tower and the waiting room. They also burned three housing areas for airport workers and a civilian's house.

Displacement: On 4 June 2021, Nipurlema villagers fled to Kago village, Ilaga District (Puncak Regency, Papua province) (coded as Ilaga district), following the shooting of the village head's family by the Indonesian military and police forces. Some villagers also fled to forests and gardens nearby.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: On 10 June 2021, Indonesian police and military forces arrested the head of the KNPB Merauke in Merauke district (Merauke regency, Papua province). He was accused of spreading false information, hoaxes, provocations, and hatred messages in Papua.

Property destruction: On 17 June 2021, nine armed men destroyed a semi-permanent restaurant building on Ir Sutami Road, Way Gubak sub-district, Panjang district, Bandar Lampung city (Lampung province). The men brought sharp weapons and asked the restaurant owner to move out because the building is located on disputed land.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: On 18 June 2021, Indonesian police forces arrested at least 32 KNPB members during a meeting in Ilekma, Napua district, Wamena town (Jayawijaya regency, Papua province). They were released shortly after.

Displacement: On 24 June 2021, Papuan villagers from Bingky village, Seradala district (Yahukimo regency, Papua province), sought refuge in Dekai town following an attack by TPNPB in their village killing five people.

Displacement: On 29 June 2021, 1,146 Papuans from Elelim district (Yalimo regency, Papua province) fled their homes. They sought shelters in military posts, police stations, and churches, following the burning of eight government buildings in the district.

Security measures: On 3 July 2021, the Indonesian president imposed the emergency social restriction (PPKM Darurat) in 122 regencies/cities in seven provinces in Java and Bali islands (coded as Jakarta) to curb the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. During the period, workplaces in essential sectors remain open at 50 percent of capacity, while private companies and government offices must implement work-from-home policies. Shops and malls should remain closed. Restaurants are not allowed to accept dine-in. Place of worship, art, culture, sports, and social activities are suspended. Long-distance travelers must show vaccination cards and negative coronavirus test results. People are not allowed to held public events or social gatherings.

Displacement: On 4 July 2021, 187 Papuan residents of Wandibet village and 868 Papuan residents of Kelandruma village fled their houses after the Indonesian military reportedly burned their villages in Beoga district (Puncak regency, Papua province).

Property destruction: On 4 July 2021, the Indonesian military reportedly burned the Papuan villages of Wandibet and Kelandruma in Beoga district (Puncak regency, Papua province). The reason was unclear. No casualties were reported.

On 19 July 2021, Indonesian police forces arrested 69 students in Tegal city (Central Java province). The students planned to join a protest opposing the emergency social restriction (PPKM Darurat) during the coronavirus pandemic. The protest never took place.

Displacement: On 5 August 2021, 251 Papuans from Sasawa village (West Yapen district, Yapen Islands regency, Papua province) fled their homes to the forest following an armed clash between TPNPB and the Indonesian police and military forces in their village. They returned to Sasawa on 15 August 2021.

Displacement: On 5 August 2021, Papuan residents of Kanawa village (Kosiwo district, Yapen Islands regency, Papua province) fled their houses after the Indonesian military raided their village in search of TPNPB rebels.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); Journalists (Indonesia); AJI: Alliance of Independent Journalists
NOTES: Property destruction: Around 7 August 2021 (between 7 - 8 August), unidentified perpetrators broke the window of a car belonged to a Papuan civilian, the head of journalists association AJI, on Hamadi port in Jayapura city (Papua province). The motive was unclear.
On 9 August 2021, Indonesian police forces arrested 113 East Timorese in Atambua city (Belu regency, West Nusa Tenggara province) who illegally entered Indonesia without documents.

On 15 August 2021, Indonesian police from Detachment 88 arrested the head of Syam Organizer in Soreang district (Bandung regency, West Java province). He allegedly collected donations to finance a militant group JI. The police confiscated over 1,500 donation boxes.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 16 August 2021, TPNPB burned a Papuan civilian house in Dekai district (Yahukimo regency, Papua province). The motive was unclear.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 August 2021, TPNPB burned a sawmill and two Papuan civilian houses on Paradiso Road in Dekai town (Yahukimo regency, Papua province). They also raised the Morning Star flag on Gunung Dekai Road.

Displacement: On 19 August 2021, Papuan villagers fled their houses in Mundidok, Jaiki, and Welengggaru villages in North Gome district, Puncak regency (Papua province) (coded to Mundidok district), after the Indonesian military forces burned down their houses.

Property destruction: On 19 August 2021, Indonesian military forces burned down Papuan civilians' houses in Mundidok, Jaiki, and Welengggaru villages in North Gome district, Puncak regency (Papua province) (coded to Ilaga). The reason was unknown.

Weapons seizure: On 27 August 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces from the Nemangkawi Task Forces arrested eight Papuans in Yahukimo regency (Papua province) (coded to Dekai district). According to Indonesian national media, the event occurred in Wusama district were the arrestees were based, and the security forces confiscated hundreds of arrows, nine machetes, a knife, and a gun during the raid. They allegedly supplied weapons and financed TPNPB. However, the pro-Papua independence media reported that the event took place in Dekai, and the arrestees were civilians without any affiliation with the rebel group. One of the arrestees was hit by a gun and sustained bleeding injury.

Displacement: On 2 September 2021, more than 2,768 Papuans fled their homes from 50 hamlets and villages in South Aifat, East Aifat, Far East Aifat, Central East Aifat, and Southeast Aifat district in Maybrat regency (West Papua province) (coded to Kumurkek district), following the killing of four soldiers by TPNPB in Kisor village. Some of them sought shelter in Aiyawasi, Kumurkek, Aitinyo, South Sorong, Bentuni, and Sorong regency. The data was reported by the Coalition of Civil Society Care for Maybrat Refugees (KMSPPM).

Property destruction: On 2 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilians' houses in Kisor village (South Aifat district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province) following an armed clash with TPNPB earlier that day. They suspected the rebels hid at civilians' houses. The officers shot and damaged the civilians' houses.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 8 September 2021, TPNPB burned a truck and two excavators of a state-owned construction company in Mangabib village, Oksebang district (Pegunungan Bintang regency, Papua province). They rejected the infrastructure development in Papua by the Indonesian government and demanded a Papua independence referendum.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 13 September 2021, TPNPB burned down several public facilities in Kiwirok district (Pegunungan Bintang regency, Papua province), including a public health clinic, Papua Bank building, the district administration building, an elementary school, and Kiwirok market.

Displacement: On 13 September 2021, 300 health workers were evacuated from Pegunungan Bintang Regency (Papua province) (coded to Oksibil district) following the TPNPB attack against health workers in Kiwirok.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 14 September 2021, TPNPB burned down several public facilities in Okikha district, bordering the Kiwirok district (Pegunungan Bintang regency, Papua province) (coded to Kiwirok district), including schools, a public health clinic, and houses of teachers, doctors, health workers, and civilians. The victims' ethnicity is unknown.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 14 September 2021, TPNPB burned down several public facilities in Kiwirok district (Pegunungan Bintang regency, Papua province), including schools, teachers housing, and villages administration buildings.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); Christian Group (Indonesia); KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Labour Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilian houses, Papuan organization KNPB office, shops, and church in Kisor (South Aifat district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province), suspecting it as TPNPB member hiding places. The officers demolished the houses, shops, and church. The village was empty as the villagers fled their houses in early September.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); Christian Group (Indonesia); KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Labour Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilian houses, Papuan organization KNPB office, shops, and church in Susumuk village (Aifat district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province), suspecting it as TPNPB member hiding places. The officers demolished the houses, shops, and church. The village was empty as the villagers fled their houses in early September.

NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilian houses, Papuan organization KNPB office, shops, and church in Sory (South Aifat district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province), suspecting it as TPNPB member hiding places. The officers demolished the houses, shops, and church. The village was empty as the villagers fled their houses in early September.

NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilian houses, Papuan organization KNPB office, shops, and church in Faan Kahrio village, East Aifat district (Maybrat regency, West Papua province), suspecting it as TPNPB member hiding places. The officers demolished the houses, shops, and church. The village was empty as the villagers fled their houses in early September.

NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilian houses, Papuan organization KNPB office, shops, and church in South Aifat district (Maybrat regency, West Papua province), suspecting it as TPNPB member hiding places. The officers demolished the houses, shops, and churches in Awet Main and Tahsimara villages. The villages were empty as the villagers fled their houses in early September.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); Christian Group (Indonesia); KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Labour Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilian houses, Papuan organization KNPB office, shops, and church in Sabah (South Aifat district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province), suspecting it as TPNPB member hiding places. The officers demolished the houses, shops, and church. The village was empty as the villagers fled their houses in early September.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Papuan Ethnic Group (Indonesia); Christian Group (Indonesia); KNPB: National Committee for West Papua; Labour Group (Indonesia)
NOTES: Property destruction: On 17 September 2021, the Indonesian military and police forces reportedly raided Papuan civilian houses, Papuan organization KNPB office, shops, and church in Kamat village (East Aifat district, Maybrat regency, West Papua province), suspecting it as TPNPB member hiding places. The officers demolished the houses, shops, and church. The village was empty as the villagers fled their houses in early September.

Property destruction: On 18 September 2021, unidentified perpetrators threw a Molotov bomb at the Yogyakarta Legal Aid office in Yogyakarta city (Yogyakarta province). They also allegedly damaged a CCTV. The motive was unclear. There were no casualties as the office was empty during the incident.

Displacement: Around 29 September 2021 (as reported), around 1,000 Papuan villagers from Kiwirok district (Pegunungan Bintang regency, Papua province) fled their homes following the TPNPB attack against health workers in their district. Around 400 people fled to the neighboring Oklib district, 100 other sought shelter in Oksibil and Oksebang districts, while several hundred others hid in the forest. A small number of villagers from Okhika district also fled their homes.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 1 October 2021, TPNPB reportedly burned Papuan civilians' houses and other buildings in Oklib district, Pegunungan Bintang regency (Papua province), located next to Kiwirok district (coded to Kiwirok district).

Weapons seizure: On 1 October 2021, the Indonesian police forces from Detachment 88 found 35 kilogram of Triacetonetriperoxide (TATP) explosives on the feet of Ciremai Mount in Karanglenang area in Bantaragung village (Sindangwangi district, Majalengka regency, West Java province). The explosives belonged to a JAD member, who was arrested in 2017, and was found after the militant informed the police forces regarding the location of the explosives. The police forces detonated 5 kilograms of the explosives on 5 October 2021.

Displacement: On 4 October 2021, around 1,000 Papuans fled their houses from Dekai district (Yahukimo regency, Papua province), following an attack by the Kimyal tribe in the district that killed 6 people.

Displacement: On 26 October 2021, 5,859 Papuans fled their homes from Kumlagupa and Bilogai villages, Sugapa district (Intan Jaya regency, Papua province), and sought shelter at a church in Bilogai, following armed clashes between TPNPB and the Indonesian military and police forces in their villages.

Displacement: Around 28 October 2021 (as reported), at least 2,000 Papuans fled their homes from Pegunungan Bintang Regency (Papua province) (coded to Oksibil district). Hundreds of them reportedly fled to Tumolbil, Yapsie sub-district, West Sepik province, Papua New Guinea following airstrikes in the regency by the Indonesian military forces.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 29 October 2021, TPNPB burned an ambulance, a water tank vehicle, a warehouse of Bilogai airport, and a civilian's house in Bilogai village (Sugapa district, Intan Jaya Regency, Papua province). There were no casualties. The ethnicity of the victim was unknown.

Property destruction: On 4 November 2021, unidentified perpetrators damaged the car of a journalist in Karang Rejo village (Stabat district, Langkat regency, North Sumatra province), broke the back window. There were no casualties. The motive was unknown.

ACTOR1: Defenders of the Homeland Militant Troops
NOTES: On 7 November 2021, two people from the Defenders of the Homeland Militant Troops mass organization threw a firework at a house of a female human rights activist's family in Jelambar Baru sub-district, Grogol Petamburan district, West Jakarta city (Jakarta province) (coded as Jakarta - West Jakarta). There were no casualties and no damage to the property. The activist, who is also a lawyer, is known for voicing her support for Papua independence.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 16 November 2021, TPNPB burned a solar fuel tank of a factory in Kenyam district (Nduga regency, Papua province). The motive was unknown.

Property destruction: On 17 November 2021, a local security forces (Linmas) member, who works under the municipal police forces, burned a civilian house in Kolokora sub-hamlet, Anakiala hamlet, Watumbelar village (Lewatidahu district, East Sumba regency, East Nusa Tenggara province). The victim and their family had recently voted for an election candidate who rivaled the perpetrator's sibling.

Property destruction: On 22 November 2021, the Indonesian police forces raided a Papuan student dormitory in Manokwari city (Manokwari Regency, West Papua province). They searched the rooms and broke a door. They confiscated the students' traditional weapons, gardening tools, and clothes with the Morning Star symbol. Ten students were arrested and questioned about KNPB. There was no proof regarding the connection of the students with KNPB.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 23 November 2021, TPNPB burned five shops in Suru-Suru district (Yahukimo regency, Papua province). An unknown number of Papuan civilians and health workers fled the district following the incident. Casualties were unknown. The ethnicity of the owners of the shops was unknown.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 1 December 2021, TPNPB burned a wood company in Kamundan village, East Aifat district (Maybrat regency, West Papua province). They also burned eight houses of the company's workers and several company vehicles. They claimed the Indonesian military forces owned the company. There was no proof to support the claim.

ACTOR1: TPNPB: West Papua National Liberation Army
NOTES: Property destruction: On 5 December 2021, TPNPB burned down a high school building in the Oksibil district (Pegunungan Bintang regency, Papua province). The motive was unknown. There were no casualties.

On 27 October 2010, four battalions of Lao troops and one Vietnamese Battalion were deployed to the Phou Bia region (Xaysombun Special Zones, coded for Xiangkhouang province), where the ethnic Hmong people are located.

On 29 December 2018, in Nakanong village (Phin, Savannakhet), the police demolished the stage of a church, cut off the power line, destroyed the sound system, and seized three mobile phones. The police officers also arrested seven Christians for conducting a non-authorized church service. The arrested have since been released.

On 13 September 2019, a Lao woman was arrested and detained at Champasak provincial jail in Pakse, Champasak, Laos. She had criticized the government's flood relief effort on social media and was charged of defaming the country.
On 21 September 2019, a Lao villager was killed after an unexploded ordinance from a previous conflict detonated in his garden in Nambak district, Luang Prabang province, Laos.

Security measures: On 30 March 2020, in an attempt to counter the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, the government imposed nation-wide measures restricting its people from leaving their residence unless essential, effective from 30 March to 19 April 2020. Borders were closed. Gatherings of more than 10 people were banned.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Bomb Disposal
NOTES: Defusal: On 13 January 2018, after arresting a suspected drug addict, police were led to a hand grenade the suspect had buried at a condominium in Kuala Lumpur city (KL, FTKL). It was successfully defused.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Counter Terrorism
NOTES: Arrests: On 15 March 2018, in Sabah state coded at Kota Kinabalu city (KK, Sabah), the counter-terrorism unit detained a suspect said to be a 'trusted lieutenant' in the Abu Sayyaf group in the Philippines.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (1957-2018) Bomb Disposal
NOTES: Defusal: On 26 April 2018, an unexploded mortar shell was found in a drain near Kampung Sungai Bedil Besar (Kuching, Sarawak) and was later defused by the Bomb Disposal Unit.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (2018-2020) Bomb Disposal
NOTES: Defusal: On 20 August 2018, the Tawau Bomb Disposal Squad successfully defused a mortar bomb in Landang Sahabat 17, Tungkunear in Lahad Datu town (Tawau, Sabah) that had been dropped by the Malaysian Armed Forces during their operation against Sulu intruders in Kampung Tanduobut in 2013.
On 25 Aug 2018, at Tanjung Nosong, Kuala Penyu district, Sabah state, the police arrested 36 Vietnamese fishermen for fishing in Malaysian waters and having invalid identification for their boats.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (2018-2020) Counter Terrorism
NOTES: Arrests: On 25 August 2018, the police counter terrorism unit arrested the mastermind of the Ar Rayah terror cell in Malacca city as part of its SOSMA sweep between 11 and 31 August.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (2018-2020) Bomb Disposal
NOTES: Defusal: On 27 November 2018, an active mortar bomb from the Ops Daulat in 2013 was defused by the police bomb disposal unit. It was found by the Malaysian Armed Forces on 25 November 2018 in Kampung Tanduo, in Lahad Datu district (Tawau, Sabah).
Arrests: On 17-18 Dec 2018, in Semporna (Tawau, Sabah), during a two-day raid, the police arrested 105 individuals, among them foreigners and a fisherman, for various drug related offences.

Security measures: On 18 Dec 2018, Subang Jaya (Petaling, Selangor) the police put around 400 policemen on standby in the area around Seafield Sri Maha Mariamman temple following the death of a firefighter in the riots in Nov.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (2018-2020) Eastern Sabah Security Command
NOTES: Security measures: On 10 Jan 2019, in Sabah state, the police extended the curfew in the waters of the Eastern Sabah Security Zone until 26 January. The curfew is in place from 6 pm to 6 am and covers the waters of the Tawau, Semporna, Kunak, Lahad Datu, Kinabatangan, Sandakan and Beluran districts.

Looting: On the weekend of 17 February 2019, a group of villagers from Sungai Lingkau cut off from their Native Customary Lands by timber companies and plantations spent the day harvesting palm fruit and loaded it in to one vehicle in Simunjan district, Sarawak province. They were then stopped by aggressive Indonesian plantation workers armed with parangs, knives and pikes, and had their fruit forcefully removed by them. The villagers' truck was damaged in the process. The 'Police Bantuan', auxiliaries hired by plantations to look like law enforcement, said they were present to prevent people from being hurt in the clash, but villagers said they favoured the mob and helped them leave with their fruit. Actual law enforcement arrived 2 hours after the event. [size=no report]

On 22 March 2019, Perlis Mufti's official car was set on fire at his residence at Jalan Persiaran Wasawan in Kangar city, Perlis state. The Mufti alleges it was the work of militants however the police deny this allegation.
On April 14, 2019, Malaysian police arrested 25 men in a special drug operation in Kota Tinggi, Johor. Drugs were also seized during the raids.

On April 16, 2019, the Malaysian anti-corruption commission (MACC) detained 31 individuals in George Town, Penang. They are related with corruption case, allegedly protecting lorry drivers who violated traffic laws.

On April 18, 2019, department of immigration arrested 67 illegal immigrants from Thailand, China, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Myanmar and India in Camerons Highlands, Pahang. Among them, there were 17 women.
On April 18, 2019, Malaysian immigration department detained 45 illegal immigrants from the Philippines in Tawau, Sabah. They were held at the temporary detention center.

On April 24, 2019, the Immigration Department of Malaysia (JIM) detained 102 illegal immigrants at a plywood factory in Pasir Puteh, Kelantan. About 70 Indonesians and 32 Filipinos were detained because the factory workers had been employed without a valid permit.

On April 28, 2019, an independent preacher Muhammad Zamri Vinoth Kalimuthu was arrested by cops in Arau, Perlis, after several police reports were lodged against him for allegedly insulting Hinduism. A total of 867 reports have been lodged nationwide against the preacher.
On May 8, 2019, Malaysian police arrested 41 illegal immigrants from Indonesia who were trying to exit the country without proper papers in Hutan Melintang, Bagan Datuk district, Perak.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Malaysia (2018-2020) Bomb Disposal
NOTES: On June 22, 2019, Malaysian police bomb disposal force detonated a bomb leftover from the World War II period in Kota Belud, Sabah. The bomb was founded by construction workers, who were clearing the area for telecommunication tower construction.
On June 29, 2019, 34 foreign women from Vietnam, Thailand, and Indonesia, who offered sex services, were detained by Malaysian police in Petaling Jaya, Selangor.
On 5 July 2019, as well as July 11 2019, Kuala Lumpur city police and the Immigration Department arrested 166 foreigners from 13 countries without valid travel documents in Kuala Lumpur.
On July 10, 2019, a seminar to promote Sunni-Shia unity in Kuala Lumpur was canceled following a bomb threat received from a Facebook user named 'Gerakan Banteras Syiah' (Anti-Shia Movement).

On July 21, 2019, Malaysian police arrested 88 people, including four Malaysian and 84 Indonesian, at a family entertainment outlet in Puchong, Selangor, for illegal drug use. Most of those arrested are laborers, cleaners, and factory workers.
On August 12, 2019, two unidentified men set fires at two mosques in Kampung Rambai and Pendang in Alor Setar, Kedah. The motive was unclear.
On Nov 9, 2019, Malaysian police detained 37 people, including 12 foreigners, in Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, for drug-related offenses.

ACTOR2: BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani
NOTES: On Jan 20, 2020, BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani and the Thai government held a peace talk in Kuala Lumpur to resolve the armed conflict in the Muslim-majority provinces of Pattani, Yala, Narathiwat, and Songkhla in southern Thailand.

On Feb 10, 2020, a molotov cocktail was tossed by an unidentified armed group into the compound of a house belonging to a state customs officer in Perupok, Kelantan. The fire damaged the house and two cars parked inside.

On March 1, 2020, the president of BERSATU took the oath as the eight Malaysian Prime Minister in Kuala Lumpur. Bersatu, UMNO and PAS subsequently formed a coalition government called Perikatan Nasional (PN).

ACTOR2: BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional Melayu Patani
NOTES: Around 3 March 2020 (from 2 March - 3 March), the southern Thailand rebel group BRN: Barisan Revolusi Nasional held peace talks with the Thailand government in Kuala Lumpur.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Malaysia (2020-2021); Military Forces of Malaysia (2020-2021)
NOTES: Security measures: On 18 March 2020, the Malaysian government imposed Movement Control Order (MCO), due to the coronavirus outbreak. Location coded at Kuala Lumpur. It will last until April 14. Violation of the MCO is considered a crime. The military will assist the police in enforcing the MCO. Until mid-April, the cumulative number of people detained for defying MCO was 9,090. The MCO was modified and extended several times between 30 March to 10 June 2020, when the Recovery MCO (RMCO) was implemented. On 28 Aug, the RMCO was extended until 31 December 2020. On 14 Oct, the government imposed a Targeted Enhanced MCO (TEMCO) in Kuala Lumpur. Non-essential businesses were required to close and movement in and out of the affected districts was prohibited. On 27 Oct, the Conditional MCO (CMCO) for Kuala Lumpur was extended until 9 Nov. On 9 Nov, the CMCO was extended across the entire country except in three states (Perlis, Pahang and Kelantan). The CMCO will last until 6 Dec. On 5 Dec, the CMCO was extended for Kuala Lumpur, Sabah, and six of Selangor districts until 20 December 2020.

SOURCE: Free Malaysia Today; New Sarawak Tribune
NOTES: On 24 March 2020, the Sarawak government began enforcing a curfew for its residents from 7 pm-7 am until March 31. Location coded at Kuching. The curfew is in line with the Movement Control Order imposed by the Federal Government due to the coronavirus outbreak. Residents are also banned from traveling to other areas in Malaysia. On 1 October 2020, the Sarawak government announced to close its border posts until 3 December 2020.

On 25 March 2020, in Sabah, the local government suspended activities in the mosques. The Malaysian government has implemented a Movement Control Order (MCO) from March 18 to 31, due to COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak. Location coded at Kota Kinabalu. On 4 July 2020, the Sabah government started allowing government and private bodies to hold events with a maximum capacity of 250 people.

Security measures: On 26 March 2020, the government of Johor implemented an enhanced Movement Control Order (MCO) in two areas until April. Location coded at Johor Baharu. The measures include a strict curfew for 14 days, while health officers search house-to-house for Coronavirus cases. Under the enhanced order, people have to remain indoors. All businesses will be closed, and food will be provided by the Welfare Department. The road will be closed. On 9 Nov, the government extended the CMCO (Conditional Movement Control Order) in Johor until 6 December 2020.
As of April 1, 2020, the Malaysian police have blocked 687 roads across the country, as part of Movement Control Order (MCO) due to COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak.
As of April 3, 2020, Malaysian police have arrested 4,189 people for violating Movement Control Order (MCO). The MCO has been enforced since March 18, 2020, due to COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak.

On April 13, 2020, Malaysian police arrested 62 Myanmar men suspected of being involved in a water festival Songkran in the compound of a factory workers' hostel in Bandar Baru Salak Tinggi, Sepang, Selangor. They were violating the Movement Control Order imposed by the government since March 18, 2020 to curb the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On April 13, 2020, Malaysian police arrested 25 people, including 22 Indonesians, who were riding a bus in Seremban, Negeri Sembilan. They were violating the Movement Control Order imposed by the government since March 18, 2020 to curb the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.

On April 16, 2020, Malaysian police arrested 26 people who attended a family funeral in Taman Intan, Kapar, Selangor. They were violating the Movement Control Order imposed by the government since March 18, 2020, to curb the COVID-19 (Coronavirus) outbreak.
