NOTES: On 20 June 2020, suspected NPA militants carried out an arson attack on a quarry site in Barangay Sinabuagan, Valencia, Bukidnon. The militants reportedly burned and destroyed several equipment, including payloaders, a dump truck, a backhoe, and a mini dump truck.

On 23 June 2020, the military discovered a suspected NPA bomb depot in Barangay Maasin, Esperanza, Agusan del Sur, following tips from locals, and recovered several weapons, explosives, and bomb-making materials, including anti-personnel and anti-tank mines.
On 28 June 2020, the military recovered anti-personnel mines planted by suspected NPA militants in Barangay Lower Olave, Buenavista, Agusan del Norte, following tips from locals.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: On 3 July 2020, a suspected BIFF militant transporting an improvised, mobile-phone activated bomb on motorbike was intercepted and arrested at a joint police and military checkpoint in Barangay Madia, Datu Saudi-Ampatuan, Maguindanao. It was not clear where the he intended to bring his bomb to.

On 3 July 2020, Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte in Manila signed into law the Anti-Terrorism Act of 2020. The law, supported by the country's security establishment, has also led to protests and condemnation, with critics saying that the law, which expands the scope of warrantless arrests, would be used to target activists, exacerbate State red-tagging, and quash legitimate dissent.
On 17 July 2020, 35 drug suspects were arrested by the police in a drug raid in Barangay Balibago, Angeles, Pampanga.

SOURCE: Philippine News Agency; Mindanao Goldstar Daily
NOTES: On 19 July 2020, the military overran an NPA hideout in Barangay Diatagon, Lianga, Surigao del Sur, and seized anti-personnel mines, bomb-making materials, two AK 47 rifles, ammunition, and other items. The military also recovered the bodies of two suspected NPA militants killed during a clash on 7 July 2020.
On 21 July 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing several high-powered weapons in Barangay Pange, Siayan, Zamboanga del Norte.
On 27 July 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing several explosives and ammunition in Mabini, Davao de Oro.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Around 30 July 2020 (as reported), 1,588 families evacuated from five barangays in the neighboring towns of Datu Salibo and Shariff Saydona Mustapha in Maguindanao amid fighting between the BIFF and the military in the vicinity.
On 1 August 2020, the military recovered an NPA explosives cache containing 4 kilos of IEDs in Barangay Napnapan (Pantukan, Davao de Oro, Davao Region).
On 5 August 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing two IEDs in Barangay Balukbukan, Kitaotao, Bukidnon.
On 5 August 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing IED components, a rifle, magazines and ammunition in Barangay Sinaysayan, Kitaotao, Bukidnon.
On 7 August 2020, the military discovered and overran an NPA hideout in Barangay Tandong, Kitaotao, Bukidnon. The military retrieved an NPA anti-personnel mine.
On 8 August 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing IEDs, anti-personnel mines, and other bomb-making materials in Barangay Kiadsam, Senator Ninoy Aquino, Sultan Kudarat.

On 20 August 2020, 150 NPA members and alleged supporters surrendered to military and government officials during a formal ceremony in Barangay Poblacion (Carmen, Agusan del Norte, Caraga). The former NPA members and supporters pledged allegiance to the government.
On 20 August 2020, the military recovered an NPA explosives cache containing 5 kilos of IEDs in Barangay Napnapan (Pantukan, Davao de Oro, Davao Region).

On 21 August 2020, the military recovered grenades and bomb-making materials, as well as illegal drugs, during a raid at the residence of an alleged Dawlah Islamiyah bombmaker in Barangay Lapu (Polomolok, South Cotabato, Soccsksargen). The alleged bombmaker escaped.
Around 21 August 2020 (19-23 August), 366 drug suspects were arrested in simultaneous law enforcement operations across Central Luzon.

On 24 August 2020, Yulo clan militiamen reportedly destroyed farm plots and harassed and forcefully evicted farmers from Sitio Buntog and Sitio Bangyas in Barangay Canlubang, Calamba (Laguna, Calabarzon). After forcefully evicting the farmers, the militiamen reportedly blocked the farmers' access to the area. The area is reportedly slated for development as a residential subdivision.

On 26 August 2020, two buildings and a cottage belonging to the Mindanao Interfaith Services Foundation Inc. (MISFI) Academy, an independent Lumad school, were destroyed by suspected Magahat Bagani paramilitaries in Barangay Matupe (San Fernando, Bukidnon, Northern Mindanao). The school buildings were allegedly destroyed to give way to State-sponsored infrastructure projects. Independent Lumad schools have also previously been red-tagged and denounced as hotbeds of NPA recruitment by the government.

SOURCE: ABS CBN; Philippine Star; Manila Bulletin; Rappler; CNN
NOTES: On 1 September 2020, a local court in Olongapo (Zambales, Central Luzon) ordered the early release of a US marine convicted of killing a Filipino transgender woman in 2014, supposedly due to the US marine's good behavior in detention. The US marine, who has been held in a local facility since 2014 and was meant to serve a 10-year sentence for homicide, was in the country as part of the Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA) between the Philippines and the United States. The court order has been criticised by several groups including the Office of the President, and it has reignited debate on the VFA, which President Duterte originally wanted to abrogate earlier this year, but the abrogation was postponed due to the pandemic. On 7 September, President Duterte granted the US marine an absolute pardon amid widespread criticism, rendering moot legal challenges to the early release and triggering several protests over the issue. On 13 September, the US marine was flown out of the Philippines.

On 12 September 2020, the military discovered and seized an alleged NPA bomb-making facility in Barangay Mabini (Basey, Samar, Eastern Visayas). The military said it retrieved bombs, bomb-making materials, and other items at the facility.
On 15 September 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing weapons and other items in Barangay Dalwangan, Malaybalay (Bukidnon, Northern Mindanao).
On 15 September 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing weapons and other items in Barangay Kaatuan (Lantapan, Bukidnon, Northern Mindanao).
On 15 September 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing weapons and other items in Barangay Lacolac (Baungon, Bukidnon, Northern Mindanao).
On 15 September 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing weapons and other items in Barangay Alanib (Lantapan, Bukidnon, Northern Mindanao).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: On 16 September 2020, government soldiers retrieved an IED suspected to have been left by BIFF militants in Barangay Pimbalakan (Mamasapano, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
SOURCE: Philippine Daily Inquirer; ABS CBN; GMA News
NOTES: On 19 September 2020, the military discovered and disposed of a bomb left by unidentified assailants at the pier area in Barangay Walled City (Jolo, Sulu, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).
On 20 September 2020, the military retrieved IEDs planted by suspected NPA militants in Barangay Cabuyuan (Mabini, Davao de Oro, Davao Region).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: On 22 September 2020, the military seized a BIFF hideout and retrieved improvised bombs and bomb-making materials in Barangay Saniag (Ampatuan, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of the Philippines (2016-); NTF-ELCAC: National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict
NOTES: On 22 September 2020, 26 alleged members and supporters of the NPA surrendered to military and government officials during a formal ceremony organized in coordination with NTF-ELCAC in Masbate province (Bicol Region). The former NPA members and supporters surrendered weapons to authorities and pledged allegiance to the government.
On 22 September 2020, the military recovered IEDs and other weapons left by suspected NPA militants in Barangay Sanghay, Mati (Davao Oriental, Davao Region).
On 23 September 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing weapons and other items in Barangay Buenavista, Guihulngan (Negros Oriental, Central Visayas).

Around 24 September 2020 (as reported), 25 alleged members and supporters of the NPA surrendered to military and government officials during a formal ceremony in Santa Maria town (Ilocos Sur, Ilocos Region). The former NPA members and supporters pledged allegiance to the government.
On 25 September 2020, the military recovered an NPA arms cache containing rifles, a grenade launcher and other weapons in Barangay Guibo (Siayan, Zamboanga del Norte, Zamboanga Peninsula).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: On 25 September 2020, the military recovered a BIFF explosives cache containing 50 kilos of ordnance in Barangay Salman (Ampatuan, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

On 27 September 2020, an Abu Sayyaf bombmaker - the alleged right-hand man of Abu Sayyaf top bombmaker Mundi Sawadjaan - was arrested by the police in Barangay Recodo, Zamboanga City (Zamboanga del Sur, Zamboanga Peninsula). Police also reported retrieving explosives and bomb-making materials from the militant, who has also been linked to high-profile bombing attacks by the Abu Sayyaf in the past. Some reports also identified the arrested bombmaker, as well as Mundi Sawadjaan, with Dawlah Islamiyah.

On 27 September 2020, police disposed of unexploded rifle grenades discovered to have been left by unidentified assailants at a garbage dump in Barangay Baliwasan, Zamboanga City (Zamboanga del Sur, Zamboanga Peninsula).
On 2 October 2020, the military retrieved 5 kilos of IEDs discovered by a civilian and suspected of belonging to the NPA in Barangay Rajah Cabungso-an (Lingig, Surigao del Sur, Caraga).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
SOURCE: Philippine News Agency; Philippine Daily Inquirer
NOTES: Around 2 October 2020 (2 or 3 October, according to conflicting reports), the military discovered a BIFF campsite and seized IEDs, bomb-making materials and other items in Barangay Salman (Ampatuan, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

On 6 October 2020, suspected NPA militants burned down three privately-owned dump trucks and a bus used for ferrying workers of Del Monte Philippines, Inc. in Barangay Bulahan (Claveria, Misamis Oriental, Northern Mindanao).

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Dawlah Islamiyah; Military Forces of the Philippines (2016-) Coast Guard
NOTES: On 9 October 2020, police seized an improvised explosive device (IED), bomb-making materials, grenades and other weapons from suspected Abu Sayyaf militants in Barangay Lower Calarian, Zamboanga City (Zamboanga del Sur, Zamboanga Peninsula). Police said that the explosives were intended for fresh bombings in Zamboanga. 3 Abu Sayyaf militants - also reportedly members and financial conduits of Dawlah Islamiyah - were arrested during the operation. One of the arrested militants also turned out to be an officer of the Philippine Coast Guard.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: On 10 October 2020, the military seized a bomb vest with 2 pipe bombs, as well as other bomb-making materials reportedly intended for future Abu Sayyaf attacks, during a raid in Barangay San Raymundo (Jolo, Sulu, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao). 3 Abu Sayyaf members - including an alleged Indonesian would-be suicide bomber - were also arrested during the raid. The 3 were also reportedly the wives of Abu Sayyaf militants.

Weapons seizure: On 14 October 2020, soldiers and police officers intercepted a truck believed to be carrying IEDs and other items for the NPA at a checkpoint in Barangay Zone III (Lanuza, Surigao del Sur, Caraga). The driver and 5 passengers of the truck were also arrested.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of the Philippines (2016-); NTF-ELCAC: National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict; Police Forces of the Philippines (2016-)
NOTES: On 20 October 2020, 39 alleged supporters of the NPA from NPA 'mass organizations' surrendered to military, police and government officials and pledged loyalty to the government during a formal ceremony organized in coordination with the local arm of NTF-ELCAC in Barangay Salincub (Santiago, Ilocos Sur, Ilocos Region).

Around 22 October 2020 (from 21-23 October), 793 drug suspects were arrested by the police in a three-day Simultaneous Anti-Criminality Law Enforcement Operation (SACLEO) across Central Visayas. Police said that among those arrested were high-value targets.

Explosive remnants of war: On 26 October 2020, a civilian was killed while another was wounded when a vintage bomb left by unidentified actors during an earlier unidentified conflict exploded at a junkshop in Barangay San Isidro (Zaragoza, Nueva Ecija, Central Luzon).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: On 30 October 2020, the military retrieved and disposed of an IED planted by suspected Abu Sayyaf militants near a village road in Barangay Timbangan (Indanan, Sulu, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao). The military said that the IED was going to be used by the Abu Sayyaf in an imminent bomb attack.

SOURCE: Bulatlat; ABS CBN; Philippine National Police; Sunstar (Philippines); Rappler; HRW
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 10 November 2020, controversial police official Debold Sinas became the new chief of the Philippine National Police (PNP), after being appointed by Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte the day prior. Duterte instructed Sinas to intensify the government's war on drugs. Human rights organizations said that Sinas's appointment will lead to further human rights violations. Sinas is also controversial for going unpunished despite his violation of COVID-19 quarantine protocol. Location coded to the PNP headquarters at Quezon City (Metro Manila, National Capital Region).

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of the Philippines (2016-) Citizen Armed Force Geographical Unit
NOTES: Defusal: On 23 November 2020, soldiers and active auxiliaries of the military's Citizen Armed Force Geographical Unit (CAFGU) found and disposed of two anti-personnel mines in Barangay Ginatilan (Pikit, Cotabato, Soccsksargen). Authorities said that the mines were likely planted by the BIFF and were intended for soldiers conducting road security checks.

Other: On 20 December 2020, an off-duty police officer shot 2 of his neighbors during an altercation over a personal dispute in Barangay Cabayaoasan (Paniqui, Tarlac, Central Luzon). The shooting was captured on video and provoked nationwide outcry and protests, amid allegations of heightened police brutality in the context of the government's war on drugs. The police officer was arrested.

Agreement: On 26 December 2020, on the occasion of the Communist Party of the Philippines' 52nd anniversary, 32 alleged members of the NPA formally surrendered to the police at a ceremony at the regional police headquarters in Butuan (Agusan del Norte, Caraga). Police said that the former rebels also handed over several firearms.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Defusal: On 4 January 2021, the military discovered and defused a reportedly 'powerful' IED suspected of being planted by BIFF militants in Barangay Salman (Ampatuan, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Defusal: On 12 January 2021, the military discovered and defused unexploded ordnances suspected of being planted by BIFF militants in Barangay Pandi (Datu Salibo, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao). Police said that the defused explosives were a thrown hand grenade and a bomb that failed to explode.

SOURCE: Abante; Philippine News Agency; Rappler; Sunstar (Philippines); Philippine Daily Inquirer
NOTES: Other: On 15 January 2021, the Department of National Defense (DND), headquartered in Quezon City (Metro Manila, National Capital Region), unilaterally abrogated the 1989 UP-DND Accord (based on the Soto-Enrile Accord), an agreement of the DND with the University of the Philippines (UP) that prohibited State forces from entering UP campuses around the country without prior notification of the university administration. The DND said that the abrogation, announced on 18 January, was meant to combat Communist recruitment in UP campuses. However, the university community, activist groups, and opposition politicians - including Vice President Leni Robredo - protested the abrogation, seeing it as part of a crackdown on dissent and academic freedom.

Arrests: Around 23 January 2021 (from 22 - 24 January), 159 drug suspects were arrested by the police during a three-day Simultaneous Anti-Criminality Law Enforcement Operations (SACLEO) in Cavite province (Calabarzon) (coded to Imus).

Property destruction: On 23 January 2021, suspected armed hands of the Yulo clan burned the houses of two farmers in Sitio Buntog, Barangay Canlubang, Calamba (Laguna, Calabarzon), within the boundary of Hacienda Yulo, amid an ongoing land dispute between the hacienda and farmer tenants.

Arrests: Around 3 February 2021 (from 3 - 4 February), 136 drug suspects were arrested by the police during a two-day 'intensified anti-criminality operation' in Laguna province (Calabarzon) (coded to Santa Cruz).

Defusal: On 6 February 2021, police recovered and defused a hand grenade that failed to detonate, after being thrown by unidentified assailants hours earlier in front of the town mayor's residence in Barangay San Josef (Jaen, Nueva Ecija, Central Luzon). The town mayor who was presumably targeted in the attack was caught up in a heated dispute with a rival over the 2019 election results for the town's mayoral post. The Commission on Elections and the regional trial court recently had a series of conflicting rulings on the dispute.

Agreement: Around 7 February 2021 (as reported), 36 alleged members of the NPA formally surrendered to the police at a ceremony at Camp Kangleon in Palo town (Leyte, Eastern Visayas). Police said that the former rebels also handed over several firearms.

Arrests: Around 14 February 2021 (from 13 - 15 February), at least 209 persons were arrested by the police in synchronized operations in Cavite province (Calabarzon) (coded to Imus), for reportedly violating coronavirus quarantine measures.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: SOS: Save Our Schools Network; Catholic Christian Group (Philippines); Lumad Ethnic Group (Philippines); Refugees/IDPs (Philippines); Teachers (Philippines)
NOTES: Other: On 15 February 2021, police and Department of Social Welfare and Development employees carried out what they called a 'rescue mission' of more than 20 Lumad bakwit (refugee) youth reportedly kidnapped and held hostage at a retreat house in the University of San Carlos, a Catholic university in Cebu City (Cebu, Central Visayas). However, spokespersons for the Lumad, as well as Save Our Schools Network and the Society of the Divine Word and the Catholic Archdiocese of Cebu, refuted the police's allegations, saying that the Lumad were forcibly taken by the police against their will. They also said that the Lumad and their makeshift school had been hosted there for months after being stranded due to the outbreak of COVID-19. Police maintained, however, that the Lumad were kidnapped and were being held captive by Communist recruiters. Police arrested the adults in the group, including teachers. The police operation provoked demonstrations and widespread condemnation.

Other: On 16 February 2021, the Philippine Supreme Court based in Manila (Metro Manila, National Capital Region) upheld the 2016 electoral victory of Vice President Leni Robredo and unanimously dismissed the electoral protest filed that year by former vice presidential candidate Ferdinand 'Bongbong' Marcos, Jr., an ally of President Rodrigo Duterte.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Defusal: On 18 February 2021, police recovered and defused an IED planted by unidentified assailants on a highway in Barangay Satan (Shariff Aguak, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

Property destruction: On 24 February 2021, suspected NPA militants burned down heavy equipment owned by a private contractor constructing a road in Barangay Doro (Malimono, Surigao del Norte, Caraga) (reported as Barangay Binocaran, its former name).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Displacement: Around 3 March 2021 (as reported), at least 1000 residents of Barangay Sukaten evacuated from Barangay Sukaten, Sumisip town (Basilan, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao) (coded to Sumisip town), amid heightened tensions between the military and the MILF following a firefight on 1 March.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of the Philippines (2016-); NTF-ELCAC: National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict; Police Forces of the Philippines (2016-)
SOURCE: Philippine Daily Inquirer; Cebu Daily News; Manila Times
NOTES: Security measures: On 5 March 2021, during a meeting of the National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict (NTF-ELCAC) in Cagayan de Oro City (Misamis Oriental, Northern Mindanao), Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte ordered the police and military to kill all armed Communist rebels, even outside the context of direct armed clashes. Duterte told State forces to 'ignore human rights,' promising them protection from legal or human rights-based challenges.

SOURCE: Manila Bulletin; Rappler; Philippine Daily Inquirer
NOTES: Movement of forces: On 7 March 2021, some 220 vessels believed to be manned by Chinese maritime militias were spotted by the Philippine military at the Julian Felipe Reef (Kalayaan, Palawan, Mimaropa Region), an area in the disputed Spratly Islands claimed by the Philippines to be within its Exclusive Economic Zone. The presence of the Chinese vessels was reported in the media over the weekend of 20-21 March, raising tensions in the region and leading the Philippines to file a diplomatic protest against China. The Philippine military said that it would carry out air and sea patrols in the area. As of 23 March, at least 183 Chinese vessels were reported to still be in the area. Several countries expressed concern over the development.

Elections/referendum: On 13 March 2021, locals of Palawan province (Mimaropa Region) (coded to Puerto Princesa) participated in a plebiscite on the proposal to split Palawan into three new provinces. The proposal was rejected, with the 'no' vote prevailing.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Displacement: Around 20 March 2021 (from 18 - 23 March), at least 5,000 families evacuated to various evacuation sites in Datu Saudi-Ampatuan, Shariff Saydona Mustapha, Mamasapano, and Shariff Aguak towns (Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao), amid nearby fighting between the military and suspected BIFF militants.
Arrests: Around 24 March 2021 (from 24 - 25 March), 75 drug suspects were arrested by the police during simultaneous anti-drug operations across Cavite province (Calabarzon) (coded to Imus).

On 26 March 2021, 19 alleged NPA militants and 285 alleged NPA supporters surrendered to military officials during a formal ceremony in Barangay Ibuan (Las Nieves, Agusan del Norte, Caraga). The alleged former NPA militants and supporters pledged allegiance to the government.

Weapons seizure: On 31 March 2021, police officers seized an IED, bomb-making materials, and other weapons from 2 suspected NPA militants on a motorcycle intercepted at a checkpoint in Barangay Poblacion II (Santiago, Agusan del Norte, Caraga). Police said that the interception foiled an NPA bombing plot. The suspected militants were arrested.

Non-violent activity: On 8 April 2021, a Filipino civilian vessel carrying Filipino journalists was chased down by Chinese military vessels near Philippine-occupied Ayungin Shoal (Kalayaan, Palawan, Mimaropa Region), an area in the disputed Spratly Islands claimed by the Philippines to be within its Exclusive Economic Zone. The Filipino vessel was initially chased by a Chinese Coast Guard patrol craft for an hour. Afterwards, 2 faster Chinese Navy missile attack crafts continued chasing the Filipino vessel toward mainland Palawan, before turning back toward Chinese-occupied Mischief Reef. The chase provoked outcry in the Philippines and the military expressed concern, amid already heightened tensions in the South China Sea over the presence of Chinese maritime militia vessels near Julian Felipe Reef - also claimed by the Philippines - since March.

Property destruction: On 12 April 2021, suspected NPA militants set fire to heavy equipment owned by a private construction firm in Barangay Mapawa, Surigao City (Surigao del Norte, Caraga). The private construction firm was constructing a farm-to-market road in the area.

Property destruction: On 13 April 2021, suspected NPA militants set fire to 3 privately-owned backhoes parked along Hacienda Buenos Aires in Barangay Consing (Enrique B. Magalona, Negros Occidental, Western Visayas).

SOURCE: Philippine Star; ABS CBN; Philippine News Agency
NOTES: Non-violent activity: Around 21 April 2021 (week of), the Philippine military conducted military drills near the coast of Pag-asa Island (Kalayaan, Palawan, Mimaropa Region), a disputed area in the Spratly Islands claimed by the Philippines to be within its Exclusive Economic Zone, amid heightened tensions over the continued presence of Chinese vessels near Julian Felipe Reef - also claimed by the Philippines - since March. The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson called on the Philippines to 'stop' such actions as it asserted sovereignty over the disputed areas; the Philippines responded by filing another diplomatic protest over the spokesperson's remarks, adding to the daily protests that the Philippines has been filing for weeks over the issue.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
SOURCE: GMA News; Manila Bulletin; Manila Times
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 22 April 2021, the military discovered and defused 4 IEDs suspected of belonging to the Abu Sayyaf in Barangay Cambug (Al-Barka, Basilan, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao). The military also recovered other bomb-making materials. The military said that the discovery and defusal of the IEDs foiled an Abu Sayyaf bombing plot.

SOURCE: Philippine Daily Inquirer; Rappler; ABS CBN; Manila Bulletin; Philippine Star; Philippine News Agency
NOTES: Non-violent activity: On 24 April 2021, the Philippine military conducted military drills around Panatag Shoal (Masinloc, Zambales, Central Luzon), a disputed area in the South China Sea claimed by the Philippines to be within its Exclusive Economic Zone, amid heightened tensions over the continued presence of Chinese vessels near Julian Felipe Reef - also claimed by the Philippines - since March. The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson called on the Philippines to 'stop' such actions as it asserted sovereignty over the disputed areas; the Philippines responded by filing another diplomatic protest over the spokesperson's remarks, adding to the daily protests that the Philippines has been filing for weeks over the issue. On 3 May 2021, the Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs said that the Chinese Coast Guard had carried out 'shadowing, blocking, dangerous maneuver, and radio challenges' against the Philippine Coast Guard during the latter's military drills around Panatag Shoal. The Philippines filed a protest against the 'belligerent actions'.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Military Forces of the Philippines (2016-); NTF-ELCAC: National Task Force to End Local Communist Armed Conflict; Police Forces of the Philippines (2016-)
NOTES: On 3 May 2021, 69 alleged NPA militants and supporters belonging to NPA 'underground mass organizations' surrendered to local government, military, police and NTF-ELCAC officials during a formal ceremony in Barangay Paoc Norte (Santa Lucia, Ilocos Sur, Ilocos Region). The alleged former NPA militants and supporters pledged allegiance to the government.

Property destruction: On 8 May 2021, suspected NPA militants detonated an IED to destroy heavy equipment owned by a private construction firm in Barangay Macabug (Aroroy, Masbate, Bicol Region). The private construction firm was constructing a barangay road in the area.
Defusal: On 12 May 2021, police discovered and defused an IED planted by unidentified assailants near the bus terminal of General Santos City (South Cotabato, Soccsksargen).

Weapons seizure: Around 15 May 2021 (weekend of), the military found a suspected NPA arms cache in Barangay Dibuluan (San Mariano, Isabela, Cagayan Valley) and retrieved 28 IEDs and other bomb-making materials.
Arrests: Around 1 June 2021 (as reported), 30 drug suspects were arrested by the police during simultaneous anti-drug operations across Pampanga province (Central Luzon) (coded to San Fernando).
Property destruction: On 6 June 2021, suspected NPA militants set fire to a Globe Telecom cell site in Barangay Homapon, Legazpi City (Albay, Bicol Region).

Explosive remnants of war: On 6 June 2021, a suspected World War II-era bomb of unclear provenance exploded in Barangay District I (Sibalom, Antique, Western Visayas). There were no reported casualties in the explosion, which appeared to be minor.

Non-violent activity: On 7 June 2021, the chief of the Armed Forces of the Philippines, accompanied by other top military officials, visited Pag-asa Island, Barangay Pag-Asa (Kalayaan, Palawan, Mimaropa Region) in the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, following weeks of tension between the Philippines and China over the presence of Chinese maritime vessels in areas claimed by the Philippines as within its EEZ. The Philippine military noted that its visit to Pag-asa Island was not challenged by the Chinese, as was usual. The Philippine military officials were transported by a C-130 military plane.

SOURCE: Amnesty International; Bulatlat; Sunstar (Philippines); Karapatan; Philippine Star; Rappler
NOTES: Other: On 14 June 2021, the International Criminal Court prosecutor requested judicial authorization to proceed with an investigation into the crime against humanity of murder in the Philippines (coded to Manila), particularly in relation to the Duterte government's war on drugs. The ICC prosecutor noted that members of the Philippine National Police killed thousands to tens of thousands of civilians during the period in question. Human rights groups and support groups for victims of the war on drugs celebrated the ICC announcement, while the government criticized it and said that it will not cooperate with the investigation.

Weapons seizure: On 19 June 2021, the military seized hundreds of weapons from an NPA arms cache in Barangay Disulap (San Mariano, Isabela, Cagayan Valley), including 205 rifle grenades, after the location of the weapons was reportedly revealed to the military by 6 NPA 'supporters' who had just surrendered.

Property destruction: On 19 June 2021, suspected NPA militants allegedly destroyed a prawn farm in Barangay Pili (Malimono, Surigao del Norte, Caraga) by opening its water gates. Authorities said that the NPA militants destroyed the prawn farm after its operator refused the NPA's extortion demands.

Displacement: On 23 June 2021, at least 22 families evacuated from Lumad communities in Barangay Diatagon (Lianga, Surigao del Sur, Caraga) amid recent military operations against the NPA in the area, which led to civilian deaths on 15 June 2021.

ACTOR2: CPP-NPA-NDF: Communist Party of the Philippines-New People's Army-National Democratic Front
NOTES: Other: On 23 June 2021, the government of the Philippines (coded to Manila), through its Anti-Terrorism Council, designated the National Democratic Front (NDF) as a terrorist organization. The designation was announced on 19 July 2021. The NDF is the Communist Party of the Philippines' political wing, representing the CPP in peace talks with the government.

On 25 June 2021, 28 individuals were arrested by the police during simultaneous police operations across Zambales province (Central Luzon) (coded to Iba). Among those arrested were an unspecified number of drug suspects, from whom police also reported retrieving several sachets of shabu (crystal meth). Illegal logging and illegal gambling suspects were also arrested.

Detonation: On 8 July 2021, an explosive planted by unidentified assailants detonated in a mild explosion - causing no casualties or physical damage, though causing a panic - at the city bus terminal in Kidapawan City (Cotabato, Soccsksargen). The explosive detonated outside a bus where authorities later found additional incendiary bomb components.
Displacement: Around 10 July 2021, 308 families evacuated from Barangay Hitapi-an (Catubig, Northern Samar, Eastern Visayas), amid nearby fighting between the military and suspected NPA militants.
Displacement: Around 10 July 2021, 200 families evacuated from Barangay San Jose (Catubig, Northern Samar, Eastern Visayas), amid nearby fighting between the military and suspected NPA militants.

Property destruction: On 15 July 2021, suspected NPA militants set fire to 6 backhoes owned by contractors of the Platinum Group Mining Corporation in Barangay Cagdianao (Claver, Surigao del Norte, Caraga).

Property destruction: On 29 July 2021, suspected NPA militants set fire to 9 pieces of heavy equipment owned by MDU Construction in Barangay San Francisco (Las Navas, Northern Samar, Eastern Visayas).
On 30 July 2021, 32 drug suspects were arrested by the police during simultaneous anti-drug operations across the Caraga region (coded to Butuan).

SOURCE: Philippine Daily Inquirer; Mindanao Goldstar Daily
NOTES: Displacement: On 21 August 2021, 406 families evacuated from Barangays Pelingkingan and Lindongan to Barangays Bayabao and Tangcal Proper in Tangcal town (Lanao del Norte, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao), amid the nearby week-long fighting between the IS-affiliated Dawlah Islamiyah (Maute Group) and the military.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Defusal: On 24 August 2021, government soldiers defused 3 fragmentation grenades planted by unidentified assailants next to the highway in Barangay Pura (Datu Blah T. Sinsuat, Maguindanao, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

Displacement: Around 26 August 2021 (week of), some 400 families evacuated from Barangays Kanipaan and Napnapon in Palimbang town (Sultan Kudarat, Soccsksargen), amid nearby fighting between warring MILF factions.

On 27 August 2021, at least 282 alleged members and supporters of the NPA surrendered to the military in Silvino Lobos town (Northern Samar, Eastern Visayas). The alleged former NPA militants and supporters pledged allegiance to the government.

Weapons seizure: On 3 September 2021, a joint military and police team seized 4,800 pieces of live ammunition, 2 rifle grenades, and other items from 3 suspected NPA couriers who were apprehended at a checkpoint in Barangay Pianing, Butuan City (Agusan del Sur, Caraga). The 3 couriers - one of whom was also a barangay councilor - were arrested.

Explosive remnants of war: On 4 September 2021, 7 civilians were wounded when a vintage bomb left by unidentified actors during an earlier unidentified conflict exploded in Barangay Santa Juliana (Capas, Tarlac, Central Luzon).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of the Philippines (2016-) Bureau of Fire Protection
SOURCE: ABS CBN; Bulatlat; Philippine News Agency; Rappler
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 10 September 2021, in Manila (Metropolitan Manila, National Capital Region), Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte signed as law the Bureau of Fire Protection (BFP) Modernization Act, which contained a provision establishing the BFP Security and Protection Unit (SPU) in every region and every city, thereby allowing a limited number of firefighters (14 for every SPU) to carry firearms. The government claims that arming firefighters supports its fight against criminality, illegal drugs, and terrorism, though the Commission on Human Rights had previously opposed the move as possibly causing more harm than good.

Around 10 September 2021, during late-night police simultaneous anti-drug operations extending to the next day, 30 drug suspects were arrested by the police across Cavite province (coded to Imus). Police also reported retrieving shabu (crystal meth) from the arrested suspects.

SOURCE: Kodao Productions; Philippine Daily Inquirer; Manila Bulletin; ABS CBN; Rappler; Karapatan; CNN
NOTES: Other: On 15 September 2021, the International Criminal Court (ICC), finding reasonable basis, announced that it has opened its investigation into the crime against humanity of murder as allegedly committed in the Philippines (coded to Manila) between 1 November 2011 and 16 March 2019 in the context of the government's war on drugs. The ICC investigation covers crimes allegedly committed during the period of Duterte's early presidency until the country's withdrawal from the ICC, as well as similar crimes allegedly committed in Davao City during Duterte's earlier mayorship there. Human rights groups and support groups for victims of the war on drugs welcomed the start of the investigation, while the government criticized the announcement and vowed not to cooperate. The ICC prosecutor had previously requested judicial authorization to open the investigation on 14 June.

Weapons seizure: On 28 September 2021, the military seized 15 anti-tank mines, 20 anti-personnel mines, and 340 rounds of machine gun ammunition from an NPA arms cache it had discovered in Barangay Umiray (General Nakar, Quezon, Calabarzon).

SOURCE: Mindanao Goldstar Daily; ABS CBN; Sunstar (Philippines)
NOTES: Defusal: On 29 September 2021, a grenade was thrown by unidentified assailants at the residence of House of Representatives Deputy Speaker Rufus Rodriguez in Barangay Nazareth, Cagayan de Oro City (Misamis Oriental, Northern Mindanao), but did not explode. City police said that the grenade had been 'demilitarized' and could no longer explode. The Deputy Speaker said that the attack could be election-related, given the approaching election season.

SOURCE: Manila Bulletin; Mindanao Goldstar Daily; Philippine News Agency
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 8 October 2021, the military seized 1076 dynamites from an NPA arms cache it had discovered with a former rebel's tip in Barangay Kalusangay, Malaybalay City (Bukidnon, Northern Mindanao). The dynamites are reportedly used by the NPA to make anti-personnel mines.

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
NOTES: Defusal: On 10 October 2021, the military retrieved and defused 2 IEDs planted by suspected Abu Sayyaf militants in Barangay Mangal (Sumisip, Basilan, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao). 1 IED was found outside a construction site, while another was found near a pineapple farm.

Weapons seizure: On 14 October 2021, police seized 750 kilograms of ammonium nitrate, an explosive chemical used in bomb-making, and 1000 improvised blasting caps from an unidentified armed group in Barangay Bacao II, General Trias City (Cavite, Calabarzon). Police said that the group manufactures explosives for sale and were likely preparing explosives to be used for attacks related to the upcoming May 2022 elections. The seizure took place during what was originally an anti-drug operation; 2 drug suspects were also arrested.
Defusal: On 14 October 2021, a joint police and military bomb disposal team defused an IED planted by suspected BIFF militants in Barangay Poblacion 3 (Midsayap, Cotabato, Soccsksargen).

ADMIN1: Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao
SOURCE: Philippine News Agency; Philippine Daily Inquirer
NOTES: Defusal: On 15 October 2021, a joint police and military bomb disposal team defused an IED planted by suspected Abu Sayyaf militants in Barangay Sengal, Lamitan City (Basilan, Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao).

Weapons seizure: On 20 October 2021, the police seized 111 Nitro EM 1000g metro explosive emulsion dynamites, 2 anti-personnel mines, and other bomb-making materials and weapons from an NPA arms cache in Barangay Segunda (Esperanza, Agusan del Sur, Caraga).
Around 4 November 2021 (from 1 - 7 November), 340 drug suspects were arrested by the police during anti-drug operations across the National Capital Region (coded to Manila).

Explosive remnants of war: On 9 November 2021, at least 8 children were wounded when a 40 mm grenade cartridge for an M203 grenade launcher, left behind by unidentified actors, exploded in Barangay Candadam, Baybay City (Leyte, Eastern Visayas). The children found the grenade cartridge in an abandoned karaoke bar and played with it.
Around 11 November 2021 (from 8 - 14 November), 374 drug suspects were arrested by the police during anti-drug operations across the National Capital Region (coded to Manila).

SOURCE: Philippine Daily Inquirer; Philippine News Agency; Cebu Daily News; Rappler
NOTES: Other: On 16 November 2021, China Coast Guard vessels blocked and used a water cannon against Philippine military supply boats on their way to resupply a Philippine Navy outpost at the Ayungin Shoal (Kalayaan, Palawan, Mimaropa Region), in the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea. The Philippine supply boats aborted their mission and turned back. The Philippine government vehemently condemned the incident and said that China has no law enforcement rights in the area, which falls within the Philippines' EEZ. The Philippine government also affirmed that resupply operations will continue. Meanwhile, China asserted that the Philippine vessels trespassed. The US expressed support for the Philippines and invoked its mutual defense commitments to the Philippines under the Mutual Defense Treaty.
On 16 November 2021, 27 drug suspects were arrested by the police during simultaneous anti-drug operations in Cavite province (Calabarzon) (coded to Imus).

On 21 November 2021, representatives of the rival Jakilan and Lajid clans signed a peace agreement in Isabela City (Basilan, Zamboanga Peninsula) putting an end to the rido (clan blood feud) between the two clans, which had led to violence in the past. The military facilitated the signing of the peace agreement to promote peaceful conduct between the two clans during the 2022 elections.
Around 26 November 2021, during an overnight operation, 46 drug suspects were arrested by the police during simultaneous anti-drug operations in Cavite province (Calabarzon) (coded to Imus).

Weapons seizure: On 27 November 2021, the military seized 4 grenades, a 40-millimeter grenade launcher ammunition, and guns from an NPA arms cache in Barangay Palo (Tampakan, South Cotabato, Soccsksargen).

On 27 November 2021, 49 alleged NPA rebels surrendered to the police across the Caraga region (coded to Butuan) during a one-day police Simultaneous Anti-Criminality Law Enforcement Operation (SACLEO) across the region.

SOURCE: Manila Bulletin; Manila Times; Karapatan; Bulatlat
NOTES: Other: On 9 December 2021, the Philippines' Supreme Court in Manila (Metropolitan Manila, National Capital Region), ruling on legal challenges to the Anti-Terrorism Act of 2020, found that most of the law was constitutional, only finding unconstitutional two brief sections that would punish dissent in case it led to certain outcomes, and that would allow the Anti-Terrorism Council to adopt other jurisdictions' or supranational jurisdictions' request for the designation of terrorists. The Anti-Terrorism Act was signed into law by President Rodrigo Duterte on 3 July 2020.

Other: On 19 May 2020, members of the East Timor National Parliament in Vera Cruz, Dili, shouted in protest and threw chairs in opposition of a vote to remove the President of the National Parliament. The police intervened to end the disorder.

On 3 June 2020, the National Police of East Timor arrested three men suspected of instigating general violence and plotting a possible coup in East Timor. The men allegedly spread information on social media to create division between the people of East and West Timor and were held in Dili as police investigated their actions.

Non-violent activity: On 1 September 2020, the armed forces command sent a military contingent around the PTT headquarters by the Government Palace located in Vera Cruz, Dili, after a movement group announced plans for a protest against the President for alleged violations of the Constitution. According to the PTT leader, she had been threatened by the military for planning to hold a peaceful protest and considered the military action a form of intimidation. Event coded at the capital, Dili.

On 14 March 2021, the National Police of East Timor engaged in mass arrests of over 200 people in Dili for perceived violations of coronavirus measures such as failure to wear a mask or gathering in groups outside.

Other: On 29 April 2021, a National Police of East Timor officer and a Community Policing Council (KPK) member, attacked a man in Kulu-hun, Dom Aleixo, Dili. There were no fatalities. [police brutality]
Other: On 22 May 2021, a National Police of East Timor officer physically attacked a man in Kulu-hun, Dom Aleixo, Dili. There were no fatalities. [police brutality]

Other: On 23 May 2021, National Police of East Timor officers attacked two coconut street vendors in Tasi Tolu in Dom Aleixo, Dili, after a misunderstanding between the workers and the law enforcement authorities. There were no fatalities. [police brutality]
Other: On 13 March 2020, a woman held a one-person protest at the Harbourfront Tower One in Singapore (Central Singapore) regarding climate change. It was part of the Fridays for Future campaign.

Other: On 13 March 2020, a man staged a one-person demonstration outside a police station in Kallang, Singapore (Central Singapore), to express his anti-government views. He broke the building's glass panels and burned several items that he brought from his home in front of the building. The police intervened and arrested him.

Other: Around 15 March 2020 (month of), a protester held a protest in front of the Harbourfront Tower 1 in Singapore regarding the climate change and criticizing an oil company. She held a placard and her picture was circulated online. She was later investigated by the police for holding an assembly without permit.

Other: On 22 March 2020, a man held a one-person protest in front of the Toa Payoh Central Community Club and Toa Payoh Neighborhood Police Center in Toa Payoh Central Road in Singapore (Central Singapore) regarding climate change. It was part of the Fridays for Future campaign.

Other: On 28 March 2020, an activist hold a one-person protest outside Toa Payoh Neighborhood Police Centre in Singapore, holding a placard with a smiley face drawn on it. He was later investigated and charged by the police for holding an assembly without permit.

Other: Around 3 April 2020 (as reported), a protester held a one-person protest in a public space in Singapore regarding the climate change. He held a placard and his picture was circulated online. He was later investigated by the police for holding an assembly without permit.

Security measures: On 3 April 2020, the Singaporean government imposed 'circuit breaker' orders throughout Singapore to curb the spread of the coronavirus. It was slated to end on May 4. Public gatherings are forbidden. On 21 April 2020, the Singaporean government extended the 'circuit breaker' orders until 1 June 2020. From 2 June 2020 onward, restrictions will ease in three phases, although public gatherings remain banned. On 19 June 2020, the Singaporean government loosened movement control restrictions and people are allowed to meet in groups of up to five in public.

Other: On 20 June 2020, a member of parliament held a one-person protest in Yishun Park Hawker Center in Singapore. He held a placard with writing encouraging people to visit the hawkers and a smiley face. The police later investigated him for holding an assembly without a permit.

Other: On 1 May 2021, a protester held a one-person protest in front of the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) building in Singapore (Central Singapore), demanding the government ban flights from India due to the surge of coronavirus cases in the country. He held a placard outside the building.

Defusal: On 2 August, two unexploded bombs, weighing 125kg and 250kg respectively, were found among sand transported from the Hau river to another building materials warehouse in Bac Lieu Province and defused by military forces (assumed).

Defusal: Reported on 13 August, a 125kg unexploded bomb has been found in the southern province of Bac Lieu by workers at the Khanh Tam building material warehouse, triggering the intervention of military forces.

A hundred policemen stormed the house of writer Huynh Ngoc Tuan and his two children who are bloggers in Central Vietnam on December 2 to confiscate material and give them a fine, tearing their clothes and arresting a cousin.

Defusal: As reported on 6 March, a 227kg bomb was uncovered in the bed of the Bac Lieu-Ca Mau canal along National Highway 1A in the southern province of Bac Lieu. It was successfully defused by the provincial Military Command engineers.

On 10 April, a bomb exploded during construction work taking place on a section of National Highway 1A in Nghi Yen commune, Nghi Loc district, in the central province of Nghe An. No reported fatalities.
On 11 April, sappers of the Military Command of southern Can Tho city successfully defused two bombs on the embankment of Hau River in Cai Khe ward, in Minh Kieu district, in Can Tho.

On 16 April, a grenade left over from the Vietnam war exploded and took the life of two elementary school students in Thuan An area, Dak Mil district, the Central Highlands province of Dak Nong, when they played with it.

Defusal: On 21 April, sappers from the Thai Binh Provincial Military High Command have succeeded in disabling a 500-pound bomb. The bomb was unearthed by an excavator whilst building a sea dyke in Thai Thuong commune, Thai Thuy district, northern Thai Binh province.

Reported on 11 May, a bomb left from the American War killed one person and seriously injured another when it unintentionally exploded in the central province of Quang Tri Province's Huong Lap Commune.
Defusal: on 26 June, sappers from the Yen Bai Provincial Military Command succeeded in disabling a 750-pound (340-kg) bomb in the Phuc Loc area of Yen Bai District/Province.
Defusal: As reported on 12 August, Two Exploded Ordnance Disposal (EOD) teams from Peace Trees Vietnam have removed two cluster bombs in the central province of Quang Tri province.

Defusal: on 18 October, a bomb weighing more than 500 kilogrammes was safely disabled by un exploded ordnance disposal teams from Peace Trees Vietnam in Huong Hoa district of the central Quang Tri province.

Defusal: on 17 March, a bomb weighing 2,000 pounds (907 kg) was safely deactivated in Hong Kim commune, A Luoi district, in the central province of Thura Thien-Hue by sappers from the province's Military Command and the APOPO mine clearance agency.

On 18 April, a 250kg fragmentation bomb was safely moved away from a residential area in the southern province of Ba Ria-Vung Tau to the Tam Phuoc shooting range for defusing, assumed by military forces.

Arrests: As reported on 15 May, police in the central province of Ha Tinh have arrested and started legal proceedings against a public disorder case in the Vung Ang Economic Zone in Ha Tinh, arresting 76 people on charges of causing public disorder, destroying property and stealing assets.
Arrests: As reported on 15 May, the Police Agency of southern Binh Duong province has arrested more than 800 suspects following disturbances at industrial zones in a locality in Binh Duong.

Arrests: Between May 13 and 15, 302 rabble rousers and asset destroyers were arrested for three cases involving public disorder and intentional destruction of assets of businesses in Nhon Trach and Trang Bom districts and Bien Hoa city in southern Dong Nai province.
Non-violent activity: Police officers broke into the house of activist Le Thi Cong Nhan's mother without a warrant in Hanoi city on Feb 4 and dragged her and a daughter by force outside.
A pregnant woman was blinded by an explosion outside of her house. The explosion is being attributed to a bomb left from the Vietnam War.
The provincial police headquarters in Dak Lak were shook by an explosion, killing three and damaging some houses.
On February 13, 2017, inter-religious leaders were traveling together to mark a holiday when they were stopped and detained by authorities at Vinh Long. Both buddhists and Caodaoists were present.
Property destruction: Thien An Monastery was damaged by about 100 unknown assailants, including a security officer, in Thua Thien-Hue province on June 29.
On June 20, a explosion outside a police station in Vietnam's southern Ho Chi Minh City injured an officer. Cause and actor unknown.

Arrests: On Aug 9, Huynh Thuc Vy, a well-known human rights advocate and co-founder of the advocacy group Vietnamese Women for Human Rights, was taken into custody after refusing summons for questioning regarding her advocacy work in Buon Ho town (Buon Ho, Dak Lak).
Defusal: On 13 Oct 2018, police and soldiers found and deactivated 2kg of explosives hidden at two ATMs in Yen Thanh Ward, Uong Bi City, Quang Ninh.

Land seizure: On 16 November 2018, about 500 people, including policemen and security guards, attempted to forcibly evict seven families and demolish their homes in the Catholic community in Cam Le district (CM,DN) to make way for an ongoing ecotourism development project. Two families including at least 10 people were detained.

Security measures: On 19 Dec 2018, in Hanoi, the police raided a gathering of registered NGOs and closed down their annual civil society workshop. The authorities accused the NGOs of not informing local authorities of their meeting 24 hours.

On 8 January 2019, police and civil defense forces demolished nearly 112 houses in the Catholic residential neighborhood in Phuong 6, Tan Binh district of Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam. The residents, many of whom are political dissidents or veterans of the former South Vietnam army, were evicted without any warning. Two residents were detained by the police. Authorities claim that only illegally built houses had been taken down.
On 22 June 2019, the Vietnamese police force arrested more than 30 people for cockfighting in Vinh Long province, Vietnam.
On 22 June 2019, Vietnamese police force arrested 66 people for cockfighting in Hoa Binh province, Vietnam.
On 6 October 2019, an unexploded bomb, believed to be left since the Vietnam War, was found and disposed of in Ha Long, Quang Ninh, Vietnam.

On 1 April 2020, a national social distancing campaign was established in Vietnam. Gatherings of more than 2 people were banned and residents were encouraged to stay indoors. The campaign is expected to last 15 days.

On 5 June 2020, around 200 men armed with iron batons stormed a restaurant in An Lac A, Binh Tan district of Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam, and smashed multiple objects. One man sustained minor injuries. The authorities said the attack to stem from a conflict between two local gangs.

Property destruction: An M79 grenade was fired at the National Broadcasting Television station on Vibhavadi Rangsit road in Bangkok. There were no injuries. In later investigation, officials believe the attack was by the same group behind unrest incidents during the United Front of Democracy Against Dictatorship (UDD) rallies last summer.

Property Destruction: in Yi-ngo district of Narathiwat, an office of Chang Pheuk Tambon Administration Organization was burnt to the ground by suspected militants, while tyres were set ablaze along with a roadside pavilion in tambon Laharn. This was linked to a series of violent events that occurred in six districts of the province over the weekend, aimed a creating disturbance during Ramadan.

Property Destruction: a phone booth in Ra Ngae was lit on fire by suspected militants in Narathiwat province. This was linked to a series of violent events that occurred in six districts of the province over the weekend, aimed a creating disturbance during Ramadan.

Property destruction: In Pattani's Mueang district, a closed-circuit television camera, a high-voltage power line and a public telephone booth were set ablaze in tambon Tanyong Lulo. The suspected militants also set fire to car tires on Pattani-Narathiwat road and cut down trees to block different parts of the road. These attacks were part of others that occurred in the district.
